PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
1. That we strongly object to the contents of the film ``The Last Temptation of Christ''
2. That the film is blasphemous, grossly offensive and obnoxious
And your petitioners pray that the Senate take all necessary steps to require the Film Censorship Board to prohibit the release of this film for showing or sale in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
X-rated video material contravenes Christian moral beliefs in that,
1. the status of both women and men are degraded by the material,
2. children could gain access to the material, much to the detriment of their moral development,
3. the material often promotes and encourages criminal acts.

Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to put pressure on the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X-rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: First World Zone of Peace, Tibet
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, urge the Australian Government to undertake all steps within its power in support of the First World Zone Of Peace in Tibet, as proposed by His Holiness the Dalai Lama of Tibet.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Helsham Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the Federal Government decision to ban future development in 80% of the Helsham Inquiry area and rob Tasmanians of hundreds of jobs in the forest and associated industries is wholly unacceptable.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the Federal Government abide by the majority decision of the Helsham Inquiry.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Judeo-Christian Values
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are concerned that the Judeo-Christian moral values which have been fundamental in our laws and education systems since the foundation of the country are now being undermined in the current practice of law making, and we are concerned that the values of the secular-humanistic philosophy have taken their place therefore jeopardizing the moral climate of our society and contributing towards immorality and violence in our society.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate for the restoration of Judeo-Christian laws and moral values.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in vitro fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in vitro fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples. 1 in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: How to Vote Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Millions of dollars of taxpayers money is spent at each Federal election in Australia in the drafting, production and distribution of How-to-Vote cards which are unnecessary and pollutant and that this waste is not desirable or essential in assisting the electorate to vote informatively for their parliamentarians.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

Urge the Government to introduce legislation which requires that the registered How-to-Vote cards of all political parties and candidates for political office must be placed under glass in every polling booth within obvious sight of all voters, thus making it unnecessary for How-to-Vote cards to be distributed at future federal elections.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we are:
1. Opposed to the Government's decision to cut funding to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in real terms for the sixth year in succession;
2. Greatly concerned with the ramifications of these funding cuts in terms of reductions in staff numbers and research capacity;

3. Greatly concerned with the ramifications of these cuts on rural research in Queensland and on the long term economic well being of the rural sector, which makes a significant contribution to Australia's export income.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

That we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Pulp Mill, Wesley Vale, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

That we oppose the siting of a paper pulp mill at Wesleyvale in Tasmania. That we are concerned about the environmental impact of the mill on both the forests of Tasmania which are listed on the Register of the National Estate and the quality of the air, soil and waters in the vicinity of the proposed mill.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should:
Ensure that licences for the proposed paper mill at Wesleyvale not be granted while there is any doubts as to the environmental safety of the mill.

We ask that the Senate as an independent body, investigate the likely environmental effects of pulp mills on the Australian environment and report to Parliament before allowing any new licences to proceed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

INTERJECT.PARA: The resolutions of the Senate declare that the intentional giving of any evidence which is false or misleading in any material particular is a contempt. —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it the view of the Government that the Yugoslav security officer who shot an Australian protester committed an offence under Australian law? Was not the officer therefore liable to be arrested if and when he left the consular premises? Does the Government argue that when it chose to abandon that option-some might say obligation-and to expel the consulate, it then assumed an obligation under international law to protect the officer, even against arrest for breaches of criminal law previously committed? Has not the Government now set a precedent whereby consular officers who shoot protesters on Australian soil will not be prosecuted? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the circumstances of this whole affair are well enough known to Senator Hill for me not to need to retail them in any detail. It has been the view of the Government, and it remains its view, that an offence was committed for which no claim of diplomatic or consular immunity could have been made. But there was, of course, the de facto immunity associated with the person's remaining in the shelter of consular premises, which made impossible the practical arrest of that person until, arguably, such time as he moved out or the status of the consulate changed.

ANSWER.PARA: However, when we made the decision, for reasons that I do not think I need again to retail, to go down the road of closing the consulate and, in effect, terminating the functions of all the consular officials, which is necessarily involved in such a closure, we found ourselves committed by the terms of article 26 of the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations to ensure safe passage of all the staff and dependants of the consulate out of the country.

As I made clear at the time, the circumstance was regrettable. As I also said publicly last week, in some sense the circumstance was also ironical in that the act of closure and expulsion thus acquires, under this interpretation and application of the Vienna Convention, a greater degree of immunity after that decision is made than was the case before. But that is a consequence of the strict application of article 26. We were encouraged in our reading of article 26 in those terms by about the only text book that apparently has ever been written on the subject of the Vienna Convention-one that seems to have escaped, along with most other things, the attention of Mr Spender-that is, Dr Lee's book of 1966 on the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, which makes the point, quite specifically canvassing this sort of situation where a consular official is properly gaoled or subject to gaoling, whether or not the circumstances of the closure of his mission and the termination of his functions would require an obligation of safe passage under article 26 to be exercised. The answer given by Dr Lee is yes.

I acknowledge, as a lawyer, that an alternative construction is possible when one looks at article 26 and weighs and measures it against the possible application of article 41, which is the one that deals with the possible application of criminal law when offences are committed. But it is a legal argument that would have been, as a practical matter, extremely difficult to test in an environment that was extremely volatile, as I think we are all well aware. Moreover, Australia is very conscious of its international reputation in its observance of the consular and diplomatic conventions and very conscious of the international perceptions of the way in which this article should be applied. There is no doubt that the perception of the international lawyers associated with the Department and all those whose views they were able to canvass were along the lines that Australia had such an obligation.

The conventions are based on centuries of diplomatic practice and comprise a major principle of diplomatic law, whether we like it or not, in its application in this case. So all those views were well canvassed last week, both internally within the Government and in discussions I had with the New South Wales Government. They were amicably canvassed with the New South Wales Premier, Mr Greiner, with whom I had a further round of discussions. He took the view, as I did, that the Commonwealth Government had no alternative but to follow the course that it did. He offered the cooperation of the New South Wales police authorities, and I am very glad that that cooperation was received.

I can understand Mr Howard reacting, as he apparently did this morning, to shore up the lame, the halt and the blind among his shadow Ministers and I can understand his feeling the need to leap to the defence of Mr Spender, who leapt into the fray with such enthusiasm on the subject last week. But I regard what he said as being at odds with his very strong, very unambiguous, very unequivocal support for the Government's expulsion ultimatum that was made last week and everything else that went with it. I think it is regrettable that this matter is being pursued in this half-baked way by the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot expect Senator Hill to appreciate fully the legal niceties of this question if his own Queen's Counsel in his front bench ranks cannot appreciate the niceties himself. Once one closes a consulate and terminates the consulate officials, the difficulty is that the obligation of safe passage applies to all members of the consulate concerned. As to the setting of precedents, one hopes of course that this situation will not recur. It is not the first time it has occurred. An analagous situation has occurred in the past. It will be recalled that Britain, in the case of the Libyan murder that occurred there, was in a similar situation for a different set of legal reasons. But the result was the same: Britain felt that it had no course open to it other than to expel the whole Libyan Embassy staff, knowing perfectly well that one of the people it was throwing out was in fact the murderer. We have had enough hypocrisy and superficial indignation from the Opposition on this matter. Honourable senators opposite are incapable of any careful and considered response to a delicate diplomatic situation or any other matter involving good government. I, for one, shall not be taking any notice of the barrage of cat calls I am getting at the moment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to a statement made by Senator McLean, as reported in the Canberra Times of 28 November, suggesting that there were disadvantages to veterans following the sale of the Defence Service Homes Corporation. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the current position and whether the honourable senator's concerns are justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand Senator Gietzelt's concern. It is very unfortunate that Senator McLean made this prediction without any factual basis at all. I am sure that many veterans would have been concerned by the statement that was made that there was some doubt as to the future of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I am sure that Senator Macklin was also concerned that the Canberra Times reported him as making this claim. I can certainly assure Senator Gietzelt and, indeed, Senator McLean, that this prediction is no more than a figment of Senator McLean's imagination. Last year when the Prime Minister announced new administrative arrangements in the Public Service he gave an absolute commitment to having a separate Department of Veterans' Affairs. At that time, the Prime Minister said that there would be a separate department for as long as was necessary. I think we can all appreciate that it will be necessary to have a separate department to care for the needs of the veterans community for many years to come. It is important to go beyond that assurance because obviously it is an issue of concern to all honourable senators and many veterans. I would like to draw to the attention of honourable senators the fact that only last week the Department of Veterans' Affairs released its corporate plan which sets out its broad direction for the next five years. It is patently apparent that a department that has just released its corporate plan is in no danger of disappearing.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that Senator Gietzelt will be pleased to note that last week, in fact on 30 November, the terms of reference for a major review of the health program of the Department of Veterans' Affairs was announced. This issue is of great importance and one that I know was very close to Senator Gietzelt's heart when he was Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I absolutely assure Senator Gietzelt that the Department will remain. I thank him for the opportunity to clarify this issue on behalf of Minister Humphreys. I hope that the next time Senator McLean gazes into his crystal ball he will at least try to check the facts.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer him to the document headed `Ministerial Submission Number 5851' dated 29 August 1988 which Senator Tate tabled in the Senate last week. I refer the Minister specifically to references to attachments 1 and 2 covering the Budget submission by the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation and providing a background history of the organisation. Why were the attachments not tabled? Will the Minister now please do so?

—The attachments to which Senator Crichton-Browne referred are not in my possession. I do not have any clear and precise information about them. I will seek to obtain them during Question Time and have them for the honourable senator, if I can, by the end of Question Time.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security seen a report in the West Australian which claims that the nation's pensioners and single parents are better off not working? Following this and other recent public comment on poverty traps and effective marginal tax rates, can the Minister say what action the Government has taken to raise living standards without discouraging people from developing their independence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article to which Senator Giles referred. Unfortunately, like a number of other articles which examine this issue, it does so without a full examination of the issues involved. It ignores some of the most recent government initiatives in this area, initiatives that have been geared towards alleviating the sort of problems that the article refers to. The Government's policies in this area are designed to improve disposable income. In doing so, there are two considerations about which we are concerned. We are concerned about enhancing independence, and we are concerned about increasing participation in the community by those whom these policies are geared to assist. We are also well aware that there are some groups which suffer a particular disadvantage more than other groups.

ANSWER.PARA: With this in mind the Government has implemented numerous reforms over the last few years which are designed not only to improve disposable income, but also, as I said, to enhance people's capacity and opportunity to participate in the community. It is this whole range of initiatives and decisions that this article, like others, completely ignores. The first and most important is the Government's introduction in 1987 of the family allowance supplement (FAS). That supplement is now being paid in respect of almost 360,000 children. It is paid at the same rate as the additional pension or benefit. Part of the aim of the initiative is to smooth the transition from income support to employment for these people. Integration of child payments with beneficiaries also significantly improves this transition.

I also note in respect of the family allowance supplement that as from January 1989 most families will continue to receive FAS for up to 12 months, regardless of changes in income. Already, it should be noted that income can change up to 25 per cent without persons losing their entitlement to FAS. It should be noted that with this one initiative we have already dampened the impact of effective marginal tax rates on people receiving FAS. But that has not been the only initiative the Government has taken. There is a list of others, and I can refer to six or seven of them. The child-free areas in the income test were raised--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't get too far away from your script, Nick, or you'll make a mistake.

—If Senator Puplick wants an explanation, I can give him one. Pensioner earnings credits were also introduced to allow pensioners much greater flexibility in earning non-pension income. Changes have been made to fringe benefits to ensure that pensioners can now retain a fringe benefit for three months after their income increases up to 25 per cent. A recent change was made this year where pensioners entitled to any part of a pension tax rebate are exempted from provisional tax.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the Opposition that seems to be concerned about families and the quality of life. I am explaining some of the initiatives this Government has taken in real terms to address those problems. There were two other major initiatives taken in this year's Budget which were geared towards addressing the problem which Senator Giles raised, a problem which was not canvassed adequately by the article to which she referred. The jobs, education and training for sole parents (JET) scheme is geared specifically to assisting sole parents in their transition to employment. Individual JET advisers are being programmed to assist sole parents in a whole range of areas not only with training but also with child care.

ANSWER.PARA: The other major initiative that was introduced in the Budget was the New Start program. That program is geared towards assisting the long term unemployed. All six programs are geared towards addressing the particular problems raised in the article but, unfortunately, in a spirit of biased reporting, the article did not acknowledge in any way the importance of these initiatives in ensuring that the traps to which it referred are redressed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer whether he is aware of a survey of Australia's leading corporations, conducted by the Australian newspaper, which showed that `interest bearing debt as a proportion of their total liabilities'-that is, of the corporations surveyed-`has grown from 23 per cent in 1984 to almost 40 per cent this year'. Will the Minister comment on statements by Jeff Patterson, the Managing Director of Australian Ratings, that in Australia `there is probably a good case for there being no AAA rated corporations' and that `while debt has increased at an annual rate of 47 per cent for the past four years, productivity has grown at a rate of less than 3 per cent a year in the same period'? Does the Minister know whether the Reserve Bank of Australia will be able to prevent the major banks endangering their depositors' money by chasing higher profits and lending at high interest rates to already indebted and risky companies? Apropos the last part of the question, I refer the Minister to comments made by Richard Shephard, a Macquarie Bank Ltd Executive Director, as quoted in Business Review Weekly:

QUESTION.PARA: Under the new rules-
that is, the capital adequacy provisions-

a loan to BHP will be assessed to carry the same risk weighting as a loan to Equiticorp, and the banks will have the same capital requirement in each case. But the loan to Equiticorp will earn the bank more because the margin is greater for lending to a riskier company.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly did not get down a note of all of the questions, but I did note the earlier ones. If there is anything that the Treasurer wishes to add to the later specific questions, I will pass that on if he provides it. I have not seen a report of the survey which was conducted by the Australian in which, if I got it down correctly, debt as a proportion of equity in Australian corporations has grown from 23 per cent to 40 per cent over some extended period. I recall last week, I think, giving an answer to a similar question that touched on that issue in which I pointed out that fashions change-even among the same group that is making the judgments-as to whether equity or debt is to be preferred. It was the almost ubiquitous fashion in the 1960s that debt was to be preferred to equity. It was enshrined in government regulations, if not in legislation, supported by all the major political parties-and, as far as I know, the minor particular parties as well-that there should be a minimum Australian equity content in development, particularly of large mining ventures.

ANSWER.PARA: It flowed inevitably from that, due to the small size of the Australian capital market, that those mining ventures had to be financed predominantly by debt, usually borrowed from foreign banks. I do not know whether that was a good thing or not, but that was the generally supported policy at that time. My own view, as I said the other day, is that it would be better to have more equity and less debt. It was my view a very long time ago, too-not just when the fashion changed in the late 1970s or, more particularly, in the late 1970s and the mid-1980s. But in the end, that is a judgment about which there is no unequivocal right or wrong answer.

In regard to the statement that there should be no AAA ratings for corporations, that is a judgment which should be made by the people who are giving the AAA ratings. I do, however, make the point that when a bank-particularly a foreign bank-is lending to an Australian corporation, or any other corporation, it is making an assessment not just about likely movements in exchange rates, given the currency in which the loan might be denominated, but also the risk of default. That is not a question which is applicable to public debt, at least not for a country like Australia-or a debt incurred by the Commonwealth Government anyway. There have never been any serious doubts about whether there would be a default on those debts. The judgments, therefore, are made on the basis of likely exchange rate variations, rather than on the matter of default.
I will see whether the Treasurer has anything to add to the other specific queries which Senator Haines raised; in particular, about the power of the Reserve Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Minister seen the article by Richard Farmer in the Australian of 1 December titled, `The truth about wine rorts', which refers to the standard of export wine compared with wine sold locally? Is the Minister satisfied with Australian export requirements for wine? Does the Minister believe that existing State regulations protect the Australian wine-buying public adequately?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the article in the Australian of 1 December. This is not directly apropos Senator Childs's question, but Richard Farmer makes an important observation, in which he says:

ANSWER.PARA: Another important part of Mr Kerin's philosophy is that such bodies as the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Corporation (AWBPC) should be both representative of their industry and composed of the best people available.

When Mr Kerin came in, political patronage went out. There are no jobs for the boys under his administration. He advertises vacancies and plays no part in determining who fills them other than insisting that there's an interviewing committee competent to sort out who's suitable.
Thus it is that the AWBPC does not even have one member who's publicly associated with the Labor Party.

The article goes on to extol the impartiality of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and how the judgments that it makes are free of criticism or interference by Ministers or the bureaucracy in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very different from Queensland.
—Very different from Queensland. Senator Walsh is absolutely right.
—Or Western Australia.
—No, it is not different from Western Australia. So I have seen the article of 1 December.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Childs also asked whether the Minister was satisfied with Australian export requirements for wine. I am satisfied. Under the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation export regulations, wine for export must be-as is described in the Act-`sound and merchantable and meet the standards and requirements of the country to which it is being exported'. The export standards are rigorously administered by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation through a system involving the licensing of exporters; sensory evaluation and analysis of samples prior to export; and subsequent random testing to check that the wine continues to be compatible with the original samples.

Thirdly, Senator Childs asked whether I believe that existing State regulations protect the buying public adequately. The domestic standards for wine, as for other food and beverages, are set out in the State laws. Those standards are developed under the umbrella of the National Health and Medical Research Council. All States have agreed to introduce uniform standards prepared by the Australian Food Standards Committee, which includes representatives of industry, the States and consumer bodies. The enforcement, though, of the domestic food standard is a matter for each of the States.

In view of the allegations which have now come to light and the actions taken in respect of one company, Tyrrell's Vineyards Pty Ltd, it is the intention of the Commonwealth to raise with the States, at its next meeting with the States on this matter, the question of compliance with domestic wine standards.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Why did Mr Don McDonald not attend the meeting in the office of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs with representatives of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO) in August this year, given that the tabled briefing said that he would be present and that he was, in fact, present in the Minister's office? Will the Minister confirm, as stated in Mr McDonald's tabled memo of 31 August, that it was Mr Hand personally who told him of the decision to fund NAIHO to the tune of about $180,000?

—In respect of the first part of the question, I do not know why Mr McDonald did not attend the meeting in Mr Hand's office. If there is any information as to why he did not attend that meeting, obviously we can obtain it. In respect of the second part of the question, as to whether Mr Hand personally or otherwise spoke to Mr McDonald, I think the documents that were tabled here on Thursday night addressed that question. In fact, I think they answer very well the question Senator Boswell raised.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy been drawn to recent media reports of animals and birds being smuggled into Australia in breach of the Quarantine Act? Are these reports accurate? What action does the Government intend to take in relation to such breaches of quarantine?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had my attention drawn to an article which appeared in the Queensland Sunday Mail on 27 November. The article features a photograph of what it describes as a `harmless looking, slow loris', which is a monkey-like creature that is a prime carrier of rabies. The article also features a photograph of two star tortoises, which can act as intermediate hosts for rabies. The slow loris was smuggled into Brisbane. Because it is a potential host for rabies and is suspected of being a rabies carrier, its source of origin was checked. It is suspected of having come from Vietnam or the Philippines and its movements while in Australia are being tracked. If it has bitten anyone, it could cause a serious rabies outbreak in Australia. Prosecution of the smugglers is likely under the quarantine, Customs and wildlife protection legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: This is yet another example of what is, unfortunately, a problem for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service-continual efforts at smuggling by various individuals into and out of this country. Recently smuggled from Papua New Guinea was the dead skin and plumage of a bird of paradise. As well, someone recently tried to smuggle into Australia a stuffed cobra whose venom and fangs were still intact. Recently there was an attempt to smuggle in seven exotic parakeets. Recently, two nursery operators tried to smuggle in through the post from New Zealand 29 cuttings of magnolia and birch trees. That resulted in quarantine officers having to destroy over 200 trees following an outbreak of exotic fungal disease. The Quarantine Act provides for fines of up to $50,000 and/or imprisonment for up to 10 years for the illegal importation of birds and plants. We have been concerned that the gravity of the act of smuggling is not always taken into account when people are before the magistrate after being convicted of smuggling.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is boring.

—I will indicate to Senator Walters that it is not boring because Australia's agricultural output is at risk if this type of activity continues unchecked. For example, 37 per cent of Australia's gross export revenue, and some 5 per cent of gross domestic product, is the contribution that agricultural industry makes to the economy of this country. If there were one outbreak of foot and mouth disease, it could cost this country in a single year between $1 billion and $2.5 billion. If honourable senators think there is a rare chance of that occurring, let me say that last year in Italy, a prime source for a number of travellers into Australia over the last year, there were 100 outbreaks of foot and mouth disease. If there were one outbreak of newcastle disease or foul plague because of birds or eggs smuggled into Australia, it could result in considerable damage also to our $900m a year poultry industry.

ANSWER.PARA: I have asked the officers of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to ensure, when charges are preferred against people caught smuggling and when convictions are recorded, that they brief the prosecutors thoroughly so that, at the point of delivering sentence, the magistrate understands fully the implications of and the dangers caused by people who engage in smuggling. One of the criticisms often made is that sometimes the sentence may not reflect the financial reward that smugglers may obtain. This has resulted recently in two aviculturists, convicted of the import of finches from Bangkok, having had their sentences increased upon appeal by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service from a two-year good behaviour bond to fines totalling $6,000 and $5,000 respectively.

This is a serious matter. It is not a matter to be treated lightly. It is not a matter to be ridiculed. It is a bit like a person falling from a 20-storey building; as he goes past the tenth floor window he says, `Well nothing has gone wrong yet'. We have a huge industry in Australia which will be at risk if something does go wrong. These penalties need to be fully enforced to guarantee that nothing does go wrong.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is it a fact that the meeting of 8 November between the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the five officers, to arrive at an official version of the status of funding for the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO), occurred only after the matter had been raised by the honourable member for Higgins, Roger Shipton, in a question in the House of Representatives? Is it further a fact that the minuting of that meeting occurred only after Mr Shipton and I had raised the issue in both the House and the Senate last Thursday, 1 December? Exactly when and where did the five senior officers gather last week to put together their versions of the 8 November meeting? Did any one of them or the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs make contact with Mr Don McDonald on 1 December or early on 2 December to check his version of the events of 8 November?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Hand has provided me with information which canvasses the questions raised by Senator Tambling and I think it would be appropriate to detail that now. Mr Hand says that, in answer to a question put to him by the honourable member for Higgins on 8 November, he told the House:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . I have met with representatives of that body and have discussed funding arrangements for the future. I am yet to make a decision.
Mr Hand further states:

On Thursday, December 1st I stated that I stood by that statement of November 8th. I stand by that answer and will demonstrate that there is nothing to substantiate any claim to the contrary. I have not made any Ministerial decision on the funding of NAIHO. This does mean that I have not discussed possible financing of NAIHO. I told the House last Thursday that discussions included mention of a figure of about $180,000 to $200,000.

It is necessary to examine the discussions about the future of NAIHO in a proper context. My consistent position has been that unless NAIHO undertook restructuring it would not be considered for funding. This was stated in a letter to NAIHO on February 15 this year. This letter was tabled in the Senate last week. On August 1st I received a submission from NAIHO and in response to that I met with representatives of the organisation on August 31st to discuss restructuring and possible funding. It was agreed at that meeting that NAIHO again look at funding proposals as their claims were unacceptable.

The following day, September 1st, an officer of my Department, Mr McDonald, wrote a file note which he claimed recorded a brief conversation he had with me following that meeting. He was not present at the meeting. Mr McDonald's recollection was noted in a note from a Senior Officers Meeting held on September 5th. This note, which I became aware of following the question from the member for Higgins on November 8th, stated that: `The Minister directed that NAIHO receive $180,000 this year in funding.' This statement was incorrect and Mr McDonald agrees that my answers to Parliament are correct.

Mr McDonald acknowledged that my answer of November 8th was correct during a telephone conference call that afternoon. This followed a meeting in my office when the question and my answer were discussed with Senior Officers. This meeting led to my re-entering the House following Question Time to clarify the nature of a report about which Mr Shipton had also sought information in his question. It was decided at this meeting that I telephone Mr Shipton to clear the situation regarding the Auditor's report of NAIHO. I did this.

Also at that meeting with Senior Officers, it was quite obvious that then was the time to make any further correction to the information I had provided to the House, if such action was considered necessary. The Senior Officers confirmed my version of events and no addition or correction was necessary. The Senior Officers at that meeting signed a note on December 1st confirming this and this note was tabled in Senate last week. As can be seen clearly, there is no indication from any of this that I misled the House about there being no decision to fund NAIHO. There has been no decision.
. . . I now go to further information about the continuing discussions concerning the restructuring and possible funding of NAIHO.

In a minute dated September 8th reference was made to an Auditor's report on NAIHO. This report was compiled before I was Minister and this was the first time it was drawn to my attention. In response to this minute my office wrote back to the Department asking if the problems highlighted had been corrected. The following day the Department responded by stating that all of the information indicated that `nothing had been done to correct the problems highlighted' but that there had been no first-hand discussions with NAIHO on the subject. This, as with all of the other available information, is entirely consistent with what I have stated all along. That is that no decision on funding for NAIHO was taken at the August 31st meeting with NAIHO. What has happened since then has been for myself and my office to continue to discuss with NAIHO the progress of restructuring and possible funding if that restructuring was acceptable. Before coming to the central point used by the Opposition in relation to this matter-that is the now discredited note by Mr McDonald-I would like to mention one other document. On September 1st I received a letter from NAIHO which discussed possible funding. This letter, which was not sought by me, talked of an agreement being reached at the August 31st meeting. This agreement was that the matter be further discussed. This letter also talked about an `indicative figure' of $193,000. This figure is NAIHO's figure. It does, however, fit within the broad range of $180,000 to $200,000 I stated in my answer last week. I see this letter as part of the continuing representation from NAIHO for funding for specific purposes.

The material used by the Opposition last week centres on the recollection of Mr McDonald. As I have said, Mr McDonald has confirmed that my answer was accurate and consistent with his recollection of my advice to him on August 31st. This is stated in a note [dated 2 December] from Mr McDonald to the Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Bill Gray.
I table that note, together with the other letter. The relevant paragraph of this note states:

The Minister then read me the text of an answer he had given earlier that day to a question about his `decision' to fund NAIHO. I confirmed that the answer was accurate and consistent with my recollection of his advice to me after his meeting with NAIHO some weeks earlier. I have since read the relevant Hansard, which was consistent with the Minister's earlier reading to me, and have no reason to change my view of the accuracy of his reply.
The Minister continues:

Everything I have said and done in relation to this has been consistent. The record shows that since February this year I have been concerned about the whole matter. There is no material from myself to suggest action on funding of NAIHO could proceed. This is confirmed by Miss Glenda Humes who took over the handling of this matter from Mr McDonald in October. A file note to this effect has been tabled.

Finally, it is important to state where things stand at the moment. On November 8th I asked if my request that NAIHO files be secured and set aside for investigation by the Auditor-General. This had been done and that is where things stand.

While I do not back away from the fact that I have discussed possible funding for NAIHO the record stands. No decision has been taken. Therefore I totally refute any suggestion that I have misled the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I raise two points. Before asking my supplementary question, I would ask that the statement from which the Minister read be tabled.
—There is no problem with that.

—Whilst I respect that the Minister gave comprehensive information from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, he completely missed and avoided the questions that I asked. I repeat them. Is it a fact that the meeting of 8 November between the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the five officers to arrive at an official version of the status of funding for NAIHO occurred only after the matter had been raised by the honourable member for Higgins in a question in the House of Representatives? Secondly, is it further a fact that the minuting of that meeting occurred only after Mr Shipton and I had raised the issue in both the House and the Senate last Thursday, 1 December? Thirdly, exactly when and where did the five senior officers gather last week to put together their version of the 8 November meeting? Fourthly, did any one of them or the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs himself make contact with Mr McDonald on 1 December or early on 2 December to check his version of the events of 8 November? Finally, I further ask: how did the Minister, and in what form, confirm Mr McDonald's advice, just mentioned in the official version?
—I think, in respect to the first two parts of Senator Tambling's question, they were in fact addressed by the answer I gave. With respect to when and where--
—You have not answered about the minute.

—I think sequentially, if one looks at the statement I have made, one sees that it is quite obvious when the minute was made and, also, when contact was made. As to the questions thereafter, I will seek to obtain further information.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware that as a result of recent racially biased local government elections in South Africa a number of newly elected conservative councils have reimposed so called petty apartheid? What action, if any, has the Australian Government taken to express its strong opposition to these regressive and oppressive actions in South Africa?

—The reported moves by newly elected municipal councils dominated by the conservative party in South Africa to reimpose so-called petty apartheid are, all too unhappily, predictable in the light of conservative gains in the recent municipal elections. However, reports of boycotts of white businesses by black consumers and of the severing of links with the municipalities in question by business and sporting organisations suggest that this turning back of the clock will not be cost free. Nonetheless, it is deplorable that these council moves, as humiliating as they are futile, have taken place. The South African Government professes to regret these moves, but the solution is in its hands. The Australian Government calls on it to repeal the Reservation of Separate Amenities Act, which allows municipal councils in that country to impose these insulting and racist restrictions on the non-white population. I hope that the Opposition would join in, in a bipartisan way, and express its own objections to these developments. I have to say that I do not expect it to do so, not least in an environment in which it finds it possible to go on repeating, as it did yesterday in that load of reactionary flummery that was dropped, its objections to sanctions, the only available mechanisms that exist around the world to impose significant pressure on the racist regime of South Africa.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to newspaper reports about proposed changes to the subsidised private overseas student program. Does the Minister agree that any system of government-to-government scholarships can be undermined by patronage and discriminatory policies towards ethnic and racial minorities pursued by the recipient government? Is it not true that Australia is unable to guarantee that the recipient governments will distribute scholarships for education in Australia fairly to their most able and deserving citizens? Given this problem, is it not desirable that some mechanism be retained for delivering subsidies to private overseas students, possibly in the form of Commonwealth funded scholarships administered by tertiary education institutions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a view that I am happy to take into account in the decision making in this matter, which still has some considerable distance to go. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: OFFICE OF THE SUPERVISING SCIENTIST FOR THE ALLIGATOR RIVERS REGION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Does the Minister agree that the functions of the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region (OSS) are to investigate and research the long term effects on the environment of the Alligator Rivers Region of uranium mining, to protect the interests of the Aboriginal people of the region, and to ensure the adequacy of the regulatory arrangements governing the mining? What credence does the Minister give to the report by ERA-Ranger which suggests that the function of the OSS might well be taken over by either the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) or the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)? Does the Minister agree with the criticism by ERA-Ranger of the relevance of the work of the OSS, in particular, that it duplicates work that is or could be done by the Northern Territory? Does he agree that the work done by the OSS should be of immediate benefit to ERA-Ranger? Does he intend to make significant changes to the size, function or functions of the OSS in the near future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been informed of the following, which may be of benefit to Senator Dunn and the rest of the Senate: The functions and responsibilities of the Supervising Scientist are set out in the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act 1978, and by undertaking these functions the Supervising Scientist enables the Government to assure Parliament, the Aboriginal traditional owners and the public that the environment of the region, including Kakadu National Park, is being adequately protected. The provision of technically sound independent advice on the achievement of this high level of protection of the environment of the region is primarily the responsibility of the Supervising Scientist.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of proposals to merge elements of ANSTO, CSIRO and OSS. These issues will be taken up in the forthcoming review. This is to be an internal Government review on the functions and role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Research is essential to ensure that measures implemented to protect the environment, particularly in the long term, are soundly based. Because of its unique role in the region and, indeed, in Australia, the OSS has highly developed experience, expertise and research facilities not found in other agencies such as ANSTO, CSIRO or the Northern Territory supervising authorities. For example, competence in freshwater aquatic ecotoxicology, essential for the control and monitoring of any release of mine site waste water to the environment, has not been established in any Northern Territory Government agency, nor are facilities comparable to those built up by the Supervising Scientist at Jabiru available to ANSTO or CSIRO. I think I might be assisting the Senate if I ask for the next four paragraphs to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows-

The environment must not only be properly protected while mining is active; the disposal of uranium mill tailings, of low grade radioactive ore and of huge quantities of waste rock has very important implications for the long term future. The Supervising Scientist is a crucial element in the process leading to the decisions that must be made in decommissioning of Ranger and rehabilitating the site acceptably when mining is complete.

ERA's claim that OSS duplicate the work of the Northern Territory suggests that ERA does not understand the role the Commonwealth expects of the OSS. It also appears to be unaware of the efforts made in the early days of the establishment of the Office to ensure that overlap and duplication between the OSS and the other bodies, including the Northern Territory authorities and mining companies, was minimised. The Government seeks from the Supervising Scientist independent assurances that the highest level of protection is being achieved in the region. In this role there is no overlap and there is certainly none in the area of environmental research.

It is most important to distinguish this kind of environmental research carried out by the Supervising Scientist from the development of mining and milling techniques and processes of direct interest to a mining company. The OSS was set up to satisfy the environmental concerns of the community, not to carry out applied research and development into engineering solutions to operational problems facing the mining companies.
All these matters will, however, be assessed again in a review of the OSS I propose be conducted in the near future as one of a number of reviews I am carrying out of agencies in my portfolio.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is there any record in existence of the meeting of 8 November referred to in the tabled minute of 1 December other than the 1 December document itself? If so, will the Minister table that record or those records?
