—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why did the officers wait 22 days before making a record of that meeting?

—In response to an earlier and very full and adequate answer, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, canvassed this particular item very well. In so far as there is anything to say on this, I have already answered it.

—I have a very difficult question for the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. Can the Minister inform the Senate how many additional jobs have been created in Australia since the Hawke Government assumed office? Can the Minister indicate what benefits this employment growth has produced in terms of the overall welfare of Australian families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that a copy of Future Directions is being held up to me. I hope that it lasts longer than `Incentivation' did. `Incentivation' was buried within 48 hours, as I recall, but I expect Future Directions-back to the past-to last for a few weeks.

ANSWER.PARA: I also notice that the Opposition finds the question of job growth, employment growth, or reduction a matter for some mirth. Let it be noted for the record that in the last 15 months of the Fraser-Howard Government 200,000 people lost their jobs. Senator Stone told us of the mess that the economy was in when the Fraser-Howard Government was finally ignominiously thrown out of office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go and ask John Halfpenny why.

—Senator Stone asks why I do not ask John Halfpenny, by which he means the metal working unions principally. I say to Senator Stone that that is a very important point because the wages system he advocates and which the Opposition seems to be advocating, even though Senator Stone has been sacked from the front bench, is one which very likely would reproduce the circumstances which led to the wages blow-outs of 1981 and 1982. The Opposition never learns anything from history. The Opposition is very keen on looking backwards to the past, but it never learns anything from it. That is why those opposite are sitting in opposition and we are sitting here.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked what the growth in employment has been since this Government was elected. Between April 1983 and October 1988 total employment increased by 1.145 million; that is an increase of above 18 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us how many were full time.

—I will tell Senator Messner how many of those jobs were full time. Nearly 72 per cent of those extra jobs are full time jobs. I thank Senator Messner for asking the question. As I have already said, that is in marked contrast to the record of the Fraser-Howard Government in its dying days and in very considerable contrast to the record of the Fraser-Howard Government in its previous 5 1/2 years before it went into its terminal decline. In addition to more jobs, since 1983 we have seen an end to short time working and a dramatic increase in overtime opportunities.

ANSWER.PARA: On the effects of employment growth and employment decline on the welfare of Australian families, I would like to quote from an article that appeared in the London Economist of 26 November. The article was headed `Welfare and work'. Opposition senators will never learn anything while they are talking all the time. The only way they will ever learn anything is by listening and reading. The trouble is that they are always talking; that is why they never learn anything. The London Economist said:
Even the most generous welfare system is unlikely to be as good a cure for poverty as a job. It is work-
in the context of this article what that means is the unequal access to work-
that has made the distribution of household incomes more uneven.

Nothing could make the distribution of household incomes more uneven or contribute more to the average decline in household incomes than the loss of 200,000 jobs in the last 12 to 15 months that the Opposition was in government. The article continues:

The contrast is less between families with a well paid and a badly paid breadwinner, more between two-income households and those with one income or none. It is work that has created the richest-ever generation of pensioners-and that now threatens to create a new generation of pensioner-poor-
this, of course, is in the context of the United Kingdom where retirement incomes are related to lifetime earnings-

The people who have retired early after long spells out of the job market in the 1980s. It is work that offers the only way to get a lone mother a decent life, without paying her so much in welfare that she is discouraged from marrying for fear of losing her benefit.

It is work that this Government has provided at an almost uniform rate over 5 1/2 years at a sustained rate of employment growth. That is without precedent in Australia since reliable statistics have been kept, and that is in marked contrast to the 200,000 people that lost their jobs in the last 15 months of the Fraser Government.

I think Senator Stone, by way of interjection, said something about foreign debt. Let me remind Senator Stone again that the Fraser-Howard Government in its terminal year chalked up a current account deficit of 4 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) while simultaneously driving the country into the worst depression that it had seen since the 1930s. It takes real skill both to record a huge current account deficit of 4 per cent of GDP at the same time as one is presiding over a depression. I suggest that no other government in Australia's history has ever been able to do that.

If the Opposition is really interested, as distinct from mouthing rhetoric about the welfare of Australian families, I suggest it concentrate more on employment creation, on giving Australians the greatest opportunity that they could have to lift their living standards and get out of poverty, and that is the opportunity to get a job. The Opposition will learn something about that if it takes notice of what this Government has done and it looks back, instead of to the 1950s, to 1981-82 and tries to avoid repeating the mistakes that it made then. Unfortunately, there is no indication yet that it has any intention of doing so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 November Senator Macklin asked me a question about the export enhancement program and what action had been taken by the Prime Minister in relation to that program, particularly with President Reagan. The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question: Since 1983 the Prime Minister and the Government have actively sought to influence United States policy on agricultural subsidies and other protectionist measures which affect Australia's trade performance. The Prime Minister has personally raised the issue of the export enhancement program with President Reagan on six separate occasions-four of those occasions in letters and two in personal discussions with the Prime Minister and the President. I seek leave to incorporate the details of the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
(i) In a letter dated 6 June 1985 which urged that the EEP be targetted in a way which minimised damage to efficient and competitive supplier countries such as Australia.
(ii) In a letter dated 20 January 1986 which raised concerns about the US Farm Bill including the impact of the EEP on the world wheat market.

(iii) In a letter dated 25 March 1986 which noted US Administration efforts to limit the impact of subsidised US agricultural export sales on Australia's exports, and indicated that remaining concerns, principally with wheat and beef, would be raised during the Prime Minister's forthcoming visit to the US.

(iv) During White House discussions with President Reagan on 17 April 1986 at which it was requested that EEP wheat sales be targetted away from Australian markets and those of other non-subsidising exporters and that recipients of EEP sales be asked to ensure that imports from non-subsidisers were not reduced.
(v) In a letter dated 21 July 1986 which expressed concern at possible extensions of the EEP to the USSR and China.
(vi) During White House discussions with President Reagan on 23 June 1988 which referred to Australian concern about rumoured EEP wheat sales to Indonesia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 November 1988 Senator Haines asked me a question about corporate taxation paid by the Bond Corporation. At the end of that answer I said that I would seek additional advice from the Treasurer regarding the matter. The Treasurer makes the point, which I think I made on that occasion, that it is not possible to comment on the taxation affairs of an individual company because the provisions of the taxation laws prevent the Commission of Taxation releasing such information other than for prescribed purposes.

ANSWER.PARA: I did say something about the Cook Islands as a tax haven and the fact that that had been closed off, we believed, in the context of the May statement this year. There is a somewhat lengthy answer about that. Again, I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

As announced in the Treasurer's statement of May 1988 it is proposed that income from that source will be taxed much more severely from July 1989 as accrued taxation rather than as repatriated. The Treasury has been involved in consultation over the proposed arrangements and a final announcement as to the provisions that will apply in July 1989 has not yet been made.

As to the question why the Government has decided to reduce the rate of company tax it must be remembered that this is proposed as part of a revenue neutral tax reform which will also see a substantial broadening of the business tax base. The taxation measures announced in the May Economic Statement included the removal of 5/3 accelerated depreciation, the termination of the income tax exemption of the gold mining industry, and the imposition of an accruals tax regime on income generated by Australians through overseas tax havens.

Apart from the more efficient tax system and economic structure which will flow from these reforms, it can be expected that the burden of tax will be imposed more fairly as a result. The reduction in the company tax rate virtually by definition, is only of benefit to those who have been paying tax, while the base broadening measures will often mean an increase in tax for those who have borne a lower effective rate, or paid no tax at all, in the past.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER HEALTH ORGANISATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to a resolution of the Senate last Thursday afternoon that a number of documents be laid on the table, I now seek leave to comply with part (a) of the resolution.
—Order! You do not need leave to table the documents.

—The report by Arthur Andersen and Co. of the review of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO) was undertaken on a confidential basis by that company for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I now table that report and, in doing so, I wish to state that it is not an unusual practice for reputable accounting firms to be engaged for these special tasks. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) is concerned that the release of a confidential report such as this could jeopardise his Department's ability to use this company or similar companies in particular circumstances in the future. I seek leave to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I shall also table a couple of documents. One document relates to a question asked by Senator Crichton-Browne during Question Time. I think the other set of documents have already been given to Senator Tambling, who may have shown them to Senator Chaney. I table the minutes of a meeting on 31 August with Mr Shane Houston, Ms Margaret Culbong and Ms Chris George of NAIHO-this is document No. 1 that Senator Crichton-Browne asked for-and also attachment 2, which Senator Crichton-Browne also asked for. I draw the attention of the Senate to a further document dated 3 December received today by the Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs from Mr McDonald. I table the document dated 3 December from Mr McDonald to the Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I also table a minute dated 8 September from Mr McDonald to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs attaching the audit report of NAIHO. I also table a minute from the Minister's office to Mr McDonald dated 26 September 1988.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the key issue involved that appears within the documents. The question is whether the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs misled the Parliament in his answer to a question on 8 November asked by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton). The document I have just tabled answers this key question. At paragraph 8 of his memo, Mr McDonald states:

As I indicated in my note to you of 2 December, I agreed in our conversation that the Minister's answer was `consistent' with my recollection of the 31 August meeting. I thought then, and still do, that the answer the Minister gave in the House was loose enough to be `consistent', particularly in view of the possibility--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we should acknowledge here that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has asked that these documents be tabled without any request or demand made by members of the Opposition, probably without their knowledge that they existed. I think that that should be acknowledged in the spirit in which it is given. Paragraph 8 of Mr McDonald's memo continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . loose enough to be `consistent', particularly in view of the possibility of DEET funding and the doubts which had probably been raised in the Minister's mind by the audit report.

Mr McDonald therefore again asserts that the Minister's answer of 8 November was correct. I also draw the Senate's attention to paragraph 5 of the document in which Mr McDonald makes a revealing comment about the accuracy of the minutes of the senior officers meeting of 5 September and upon which the Opposition relies to allege that the Minister misinformed the Parliament. Paragraph 5 states:

The minutes of the Senior Officers' meeting of September 5 are partly in error. My recollection is that I reported that the Minister had decided to fund NAIHO. There was some comment from several other officers including a question about the cost of this decision. I believe that I estimated the cost would be `about $180,000' but do not agree that I said that the Minister had `directed that NAIHO receive $180,000'. As you know, the SOM minutes are a much edited version of proceedings and should not be regarded as anything like a verbatim record.

Again, inaccuracies are identified by Mr McDonald in relation to a key document upon which the Opposition relies to bring its case against the Minister. Finally, the memo provides confirmation yet again that the Department had not received any written confirmation from the Minister concerning the alleged decision to fund NAIHO. The simple reason is that no decision had been taken and the Department has no formal decision which would authorise it to fund NAIHO. I remind the Senate of the original questions put by the honourable member for Higgins on 8 November. In summary, he asked the Minister: `Did the Minister's predecessor stop funding NAIHO? Has the Minister recommenced funding of NAIHO? Was his predecessor wrong in stopping the funding of NAIHO? Will the Minister have NAIHO investigated by the Auditor-General?'

The Senate should note the answers given by the Minister to those questions on 8 November. In precis they were: `Yes, my predecessor did stop funding following a critical audit report. No, I am yet to make a decision'. No specific answer was given in respect of question 3. Fourthly, he said, `The NAIHO issue will be examined by those people who are undertaking the investigations'. The evidence shows that the Minister answered accurately and honestly in respect of these questions and it is clear that the Parliament has not been misled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement and papers.

Clearly the Opposition will want some time to examine the rather detailed papers which have been tabled. However, I must say that a few preliminary comments are called for. Firstly, how would anyone here like to be in Mr McDonald's shoes? He has his Minister, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), giving this extraordinary answer in the House of Representatives, and then this call from the Minister and his senior officers to clarify the accuracy or otherwise of Mr McDonald's sundry minutes and comments on this matter. The thing which leaps from the pages that have been tabled by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus)-no doubt there are many other matters which will come out quite apart from the extraordinary comment that the Minister read that the reply of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was loose enough to be accurate, or words to that effect-is the letter from the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO) dated 1 September. This letter was written by that organisation immediately after the meeting with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Here we have the Minister and the Minister's surrogate asserting in the Senate that there was no agreement with respect to funding, and yet we find that on 1 September the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation was writing in very intimate terms to the Minister:
Dear Gerry,

I am writing to follow on from the discussions of yesterday relating to the funding of NAIHO. In undertaking the fine tuning of the agreement reached yesterday, I would ask that we consider the following points.
Then follow requests from NAIHO about some particular items of expenditure. The second last paragraph of the letter says:
Bearing in mind the budget position as discussed, we would seek your agreement to a small increase in the indicative figure of $193,000 of $5,000.
With this additional amount we could absorb the costs associated with the above matters, bringing overall cost in under the broad limits we discussed.

This letter bears out the obvious and clear meaning of the documents which were tabled last Thursday by Minister Tate, the surrogate who is not available to us today, unfortunately, for reasons of ill health. But in reality it is quite apparent that these documents confirm not only in the mind of Mr McDonald, because of what the Minister told him, but also in the mind of the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation that it had an agreement which required some fine tuning. Of course that is utterly appropriate with the other documents tabled last Thursday. We find, for example, in the handwritten minute signed by Glenda Humes and dated 18 October exactly the same clear meaning. Glenda Humes says in that minute:
I raised the question of NAIHO funding again with Harriet Swift who apologised for the delay in sending the Department relevant information concerning the funding. She said-
I quote this part with some care-
there is some concern about the precise amount needed . . .

It is quite clear on the face of the documents we have that the Minister changed the decision of the previous Minister, which flowed from the appalling auditor's report on this organisation, and agreed to fund the organisation subject to some of the fine tuning and argument about details that had to come forward. We find a very grateful National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation recording in this same letter this changed relationship with the Government. After all, it had just been given the heave-ho by the previous and now discredited Minister, Clyde Holding. What did NAIHO say on 1 September? It said:
Both Margaret and I saw yesterday's discussion as frank and productive and certainly a change from the melee and suspicions which have dogged past negotiations.

The fact is that this brand new Minister re-established contact and communications with NAIHO, an organisation which had been thoroughly discredited by an independent auditor's report, and it is quite clear on the face of the document I have quoted from that there was agreement that this organisation would be funded again.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the agreement the Minister conveyed to Mr McDonald.

—I thank Senator Stone. That is precisely the agreement that was conveyed to Mr McDonald. Clearly, a great deal of careful examination is required of these documents. I welcome one point that has been raised by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the minute of Mr McDonald, although if the Minister does not like what I am about to say perhaps he will require a minute from Mr McDonald varying Mr McDonald's statement of what the Minister has said. In Mr McDonald's minute to the Secretary dated 2 December he says, in the final paragraph in which he refers to discussions he had had with the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: We then had a short general discussion about our respective recollections of the meeting and the Minister commented that I may be called upon to repeat my recollection to one of the inquiries that were in place.

I raise that now because I think that if there is any failure on the part of the Government to dispel the clear suspicions which now exist about the whole handling of this matter, and if the Minister defies convention by refusing to resign, it may well be that the Minister's statement to Mr McDonald is one that we should heed-that is, this matter should be dealt with by one of the many inquiries into the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, whether it is the parliamentary inquiry or some other inquiry. We cannot have the continuing situation which we have faced day after day, week after week, in this place in which we cannot rely upon information given to the Parliament with respect to the operations of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

There are two matters now which, on the face of the evidence given to the Parliament, we have been forced to send to the Standing Committee on Privileges. In other words, on the face of it it would appear that the Government and its instrumentalities, through the Government's agents, its public servants, have not been able to give us accurate information on these matters which are of so much concern to the Senate. This is a most serious challenge to the capacity of the Parliament to do its duty both with respect to the legislation that is before it-the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation-and with respect to the extraordinarily large sums of money that have been allocated for expenditure by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) in the current financial year.

On the face of the documentation which the Government keeps producing in response to the demands of the Senate and in response to the questioning of honourable senators on this side of the chamber who are concerned to see this matter cleaned up-Senator Tambling, Senator Short, Senator Peter Baume, Senator Boswell, Senator Crichton-Browne and many other honourable senators have been pursuing this matter-on too many occasions the results of our inquiries have been lies and inaccuracies. In those circumstances we believe that the Minister has totally failed to live up to his responsibilities and that he should not hold office. We cannot debate this matter in a full and final way because as a group we have not had a chance to peruse carefully the further papers which have just come to hand.

I want to speak on this matter now because it is apparent that the Ministers who are dealing with this matter are not taking the trouble to examine the material before it is brought into this place and do their duty as Ministers of the Crown to try to ensure that the Senate is properly informed. Last Thursday Minister Tate, a man who was dean of a law school and who we are assured by his colleagues is a man of the highest reputation and capacity, tabled in this place a document which was, on the face of it, doctored. That was a case of gross and easily avoidable negligence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did that doctored document come from?

—In fact, I think it was Senator Collins who made available to the Minister the complete version of the document which was tabled in a doctored form. I do not believe that any competent lawyer could have spent 30 seconds on the examination of that page without seeing that it raised serious questions that should have been answered not after the tabling of the document but before.
—Where did that doctored document come from?

—I do not know. It is my understanding that it came from the office of the Minister but I cannot be sure. That is something that no doubt we will be enlightened on before this matter runs its course. Today, Minister Bolkus came in here and made statements in defence of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand. Senator Bolkus has tabled documents which again, on their face, raise serious doubts about the accuracy of the assurance that he has given on behalf of Minister Hand.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a serious matter. It is not just a matter of a principal and agent relationship between the Ministers in this place and Ministers in the other place. The Ministers in this place have a duty, as senators, to exercise their judgment. Senator Bolkus, I understand, is legally qualified. I stand to be corrected if I am wrong. He is not a person, allegedly, without the training to enable him to encompass what is contained in written documents and to determine what value should be placed on them. I ask how Senator Bolkus can come in here and give us the sort of assurances that he has-assurances that the Minister did not mislead; assurances that there was no agreement arising from the discussions of August-and contemporaneously table this letter of 1 September.

Again we see gross neglect. I do not know whether it is sloth or a lack of concern, but the fact is that Ministers in this place, together with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, stand condemned for their pathetic failure to do their duty as Ministers and to ensure that we get accurate, factual material before us so that we can consider these matters. I think that the Government has to be on notice that the Opposition will not tolerate the slack approach which has been adopted by both the Ministers that we have dealt with over the last two sitting days in the Senate. I think it is pathetic, and I ask Minister Bolkus to ensure that, before he answers the various questions that were put to him in Question Time today, which he undertook to answer as soon as possible, he understands that it is his responsibility to get accurate answers and not just to feed up the pap which comes, whether by negligence or design, and which then has to be challenged.

I ask the Minister also: will he consider a couple of questions which, because of the filibustering of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), were not able to be asked today-the question which was to be asked by Senator Short and the question which I was to ask on the same area? I put the Minister on notice that we will be seeking answers to these questions not later than tomorrow. I ask: has he noted the reference in the tabled handwritten note dated 18 October from Ms Glenda Humes, which I have quoted from already in this debate, that Ms Harriet Swift from the office of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs had advised:
. . . there is some concern about the precise amount needed and that 2 staff positions (TAP funded by DEET)-
that is, the Department of Employment, Education and Training-
needed to be sorted out eg how long would they be funded under DEET.

Does the Minister agree that in discussing only the level of funding, not whether NAIHO was to be funded, Ms Swift effectively confirmed the accuracy of the various minutes from Mr Don McDonald about the Minister's decision to fund that organisation, despite his assertion three weeks later that no such decision had been made? I further ask the Minister: Does he agree that minutes by Mr Don McDonald of 1 September, 15 September, 22 September and 13 October this year-not one minute from the hapless Mr McDonald, but minutes from 1 September, 15 September, 22 September and 13 October-plus the minutes of the senior officers meeting of 5 September, plus a note from Ms Glenda Humes dated 18 October to which I have already referred, all accepted the fact that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs had approved funding for NAIHO and that the only question remaining was the precise level of such funding? I add to that question, which is the question I was going to ask before I received these tabled documents: Does not that letter from NAIHO of 1 September also make it absolutely clear that the only question remaining was the precise level of such funding?

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed. NAIHO's letter throws one element of doubt. It states that it was not $180,000, it was $193,000, and it wants another $5,000 to round it off to $198,000, which no doubt could be rounded off to $200,000. I further ask the Minister: If it is alleged that such a decision had not been taken, was there no action to challenge or correct the six separate documents before the alleged meeting of 8 November 1988?

SPEECH.PARA: I put those questions to the Minister and ask him, as a trained lawyer, as a person who has sworn certain oaths with respect to his duties as a Minister and as a senator, to consider those matters and the quite extraordinary circumstance that minute after minute, letter after letter can be written confirming the existence of an agreement and that it is only when Mr Roger Shipton raises the matter in the House of Representatives that we get this revision of history.

There is something inherently improbable in the matters which the Minister is putting forward. The reason I labour this point is that it is not for Minister Tate or Minister Bolkus to escape responsibility for inaccuracies, misrepresentations and even lies which they may transmit to this place and merely use the defence: `That is what I have been told'. That is not good enough. We are asking the Ministers of this Government to understand that they are responsible for the hundreds of millions of dollars which are being maladministered. Senator Crichton-Browne has talked of thousands of programs which are not being subject to any proper accounting. This is totally unsatisfactory. If Minister Bolkus brings more papers into this place and makes statements which are inconsistent with those papers, he need not think that it will be only Mr Gerry Hand's resignation which we will be seeking; it will be his as well.

There are various matters which are within the capacity of the Opposition to bring forward. As I have said, I do not wish to have a prolonged debate on this matter now because I think all Opposition senators would like the opportunity to consider these documents in detail. I, therefore, seek leave to continue my remarks later.

I do not think one could have got a better indication of why it is an urgent matter that the Senate consider this than the answer which was given in the Senate today by Senator Walsh, who as usual used the Senate's time not to consider the matters which are of concern to the men and women of Australia but simply to indulge in an orgy of backward looking abuse of the previous Government, to attack the Opposition, with no sense of concern for the failures of the present Government, and to indulge in the usual self-praise which is such a feature of the Hawke Government-we cannot hear a Minister speak without him telling us how good he and his colleagues are-and which, in a sense, was typical of the arrogant and out of touch approach of this Government to the things that are concerning the people of Australia.

I want to talk about that a little, because the two things are closely interrelated. We cannot improve the lot of the people of Australia if the Australian economy is not going in the right direction. We cannot increase living standards unless we increase productivity in the economy generally. The truth of the matter is that the approach of this Government has put it beyond its capacity to deliver what the people of Australia want-which is a better direction and a better life for themselves. When one listens to the smugness of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the complacency of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and the vitriol of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), one could almost imagine that the Australian economy is an economy in a strong position and proceeding in the right direction.

I want to say a couple of things about why it is that the people of Australia are feeling this extraordinary pressure under this present Government; why it is that the burdens on Australian families have been so increased. The fact is that the crisis that we have had in Australia in 1986, the crisis that was acknowledged even by Mr Keating when he talked about Australia becoming a banana republic, the crisis that we were having to buy from abroad so much more than we were making in Australia and selling abroad, is a crisis which has got worse instead of better. The fact is that the complacency of this Government, and, indeed, the complacency of some of the big businesses in this country is underpinned by one factor only; that is, the increase in the prices that we get for our commodities. During 1985 and 1986 Treasurer Keating-would be Prime Minister Keating-talked of nothing else but the declining terms of trade which were causing such hardship in Australia. Since 1986 we have fully recovered those dramatic losses of the previous years. Our terms of trade are now as good as they have been since the mid-1970s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wool is higher.

—Senator Walters interjects that wool is higher. So many of our commodities are better. The truth is that our balance of payments position has slightly improved solely because of that change in the prices we get for our Australian commodities. If one were to look at the actual physical trade in goods and services, one would find that each year since 1986 our trade has worsened. The gap between what we buy and what we sell is bigger today than it was in 1986. In those circumstances Australia is in a very perilous condition indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, when one looks at our economic prospects, one finds that our inflation rate is nearly twice as high as that of our trading partners generally. Our wage rises go up two or three times as fast but, of course, our employees, our workers, our wage and salary earners, do not benefit from those big increases in wages because the sad fact is that inflation outstrips those rises. Our inflation rate is so much higher than the rest of the world. Our interest rates are at 15 per cent while those of the United States are at 10 per cent and those of most other countries are much lower. Our tax rates are uncompetitive, our productivity is stagnant, declining in many areas, and overall, is about half the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) rate. We have a high foreign debt which continues to climb. Last week we heard very little from Minister Walsh and Treasurer Keating about the fact that our foreign debt had reached $120 billion-a fantastic figure for Australia to service and a very good indication of just how much trouble we are in.

It is not in those macro-terms that the problem is considered by the voters and the people of Australia. The reality that they face is a decline in their living standards under Labor for a whole series of reasons. This Government simply refuses to address the reality that faces middle income earners in this country. This Government has treated middle income earners with contempt; it has treated, in particular, families with dependants with contempt. The people who have felt the squeeze the greatest under Labor are those who are bringing up children, buying a home, and doing the things which are essential to the maintenance of our society. When I raise this with Labor people and Labor audiences, they say that I am talking about a minority. They wipe off the concern of the Liberal and National parties of people marrying, having children and playing their part in continuing our society and ensuring its continued health-that part of the life of nearly every Australian.

Let us look at the key factors which have affected and now affect individuals under this Government. Look at the central interests of Australians in owning a home, in having decent accommodation. If one chooses, as the Government might like to do, to start with those Australians who are least well off, the Australians who cannot afford to buy a house-because of Labor's policies there is an increasing proportion of those in our community-one asks: How have the people who cannot afford to buy a house fared under Labor? The sad fact is that when this Government came into office in 1983 there were 100,000 Australians on the welfare housing list-100,000 Australians could not get public accommodation although they qualified for it. Now, after 5 1/2 years of Labor Government, 160,000 Australians are on those waiting lists. Those people who were most in need of government assistance have seen a 60 per cent worsening of their position under the Labor Government-a splendid achievement! I note that not one Labor Minister is prepared to debate these issues. I have no doubt that the Labor speakers will express their pride in increasing the number of people on waiting lists for welfare housing by 60 per cent!

In terms of that majority of Australians who have an ambition to purchase their own home, the simple fact is that the income required to buy an average priced first home has doubled since Labor came to power. In fact it has doubled since early 1985. In 1985, if a family were earning $23,000 a year it could afford to buy an average-priced first home. In 1987 a family is required to have an income of $46,000 a year. That is what this splendid Government has achieved for the people of Australia over a period of three years-a doubling of the income required to purchase a house.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're supposed to represent the workers.

—Senator Boswell says that the Labor Government is supposed to represent the workers. Yet average home loan repayments have gone from $350 a month in March 1983 to $711 a month in June 1988. However one looks at it, whether it be at the interests of middle Australians, that broad spectrum of Australia that believe that to buy and own a home is a central part of living the sort of life that they wish to lead, we see this doubling of the burden which has been imposed during the period of this Labor Government. That is one area of concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the tax burden. One of the reasons that we have a problem in respect of the declining living standards in this country is that people are called upon to pay a higher and higher proportion of their incomes in tax. Again, this is the Government which is supposed to be concerned with the people of Australia. On 1 July this year, the Government introduced a 10c reduction in the rate of company tax. It went from 49c in the dollar to 39c in the dollar. The wage and salary earners of this country, who have been paying an increasing proportion of their incomes in income tax year by year-each year a little more of their income is taken by the Commonwealth in income taxes-were told by this Government that they would have to wait until the next financial year, until just before an election, before they were entitled to have any form of tax relief. That is the approach of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before they go out of office.

—Senator Chapman reminds me that it is just before it goes out of office. That is absolutely right. The sad fact is the wage and salary earners must continue to bear this pain. In fact, it is a pain which will worsen as bracket creep worsens between now and the next financial year. Yet the Government, in pursuit of its failed economic policies as it happens, can hand out an earlier tax cut to business. The marginal tax rate is now higher than it was when Labor came to office; the average tax rate is now higher than it was when Labor came to office; and the tax share of our gross domestic product (GDP) is now at a record high. The Prime Minister, in his airy fairy way, promised a few years ago that the Government would not take an increased proportion of the GDP in tax. What has he done? He has increased the proportion of what we produce that has gone in tax. Once again, we cannot take any notice of what Mr Hawke says. His statements are utterly unreliable.

SPEECH.PARA: Take health care which is of concern to the people of Australia. Health costs are going up at about twice the inflation rate. Taxpayers pay a compulsory Medicare levy. Again, the poorest in the community are suffering the most. We find lengthy public hospital queues. We find that that 18 per cent of people who had private insurance can no longer afford it. They therefore have to become a further burden on the public hospital system. The Government is squeezing not the middle class, not the better off in this community, but it is squeezing out the poor. This Government has taken 18 per cent of people out of private insurance because it has made it much more costly to privately insure health. It has ensured that people pay twice for their health care if they insure privately. Once again, it is not just that 18 per cent of people who have found that they can no longer afford to insure who are damaged; it is also those people who are poorest in the community. And the pensioner community, who are almost totally reliant upon public health care, can wait two years for a hip operation. I say to Senator Cook that that is a brilliant success. Although Senator Cook's responsibilities are not in aged care, he might talk to his colleagues about the pride they no doubt feel in holding up pensioner operations in that way.

I turn to family assistance. This issue will be dealt with in much more detail by Senator Puplick. I remind the Senate of what the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) identified so clearly and what we have been talking about ever since the Government put its total emphasis on the family allowance supplement: this Government has made it tougher for all families with children except the bottom 20 per cent. Every other family has seen its position worsened under Labor. As identified very clearly by EPAC in its report entitled Income Support Policies, Taxation and Incentives, Australians on incomes varying between about 60 per cent and 90 per cent of average weekly earnings-in other words, the great bulk of hard working families on relatively modest incomes-pay marginal tax rates of sometimes over 100 per cent. By focusing assistance on income tested programs, by removing assistance under the family allowance supplement, the family allowance itself, the Medicare levy, and so on, the Government actually produces tax rates on people who have incomes of around $300 a week in excess of 100 per cent.

That is this Government's extraordinary achievement-to lock low income families into poverty and to treat all but low income families with absolute contempt and to refuse to extend them any assistance at all during the last 5 1/2 difficult years. Family allowance has been removed from people on higher incomes; people on middle incomes have received no increase at all either in their family allowance or their dependent spouse tax rebate.

In terms of what has been done for the workers, this Government is a gigantic confidence trick. In Senator Cook's State of Western Australia there was a 23 per cent swing in the electorate of ex-Premier Burke and a 15 per cent swing in the electorate of the ex-Deputy Premier. That vote adequately reflected the understanding in the community that it has been treated with contempt by this Government which hobnobs with the rich and powerful and does not give a damn for the middle income people of this country.

Yesterday, John Howard made it quite clear that the directions which are required to be set by this country are utterly different. John Howard made the point that we would be guided in the next government by five key principles. They are the strengthening of the family, restoring Australians' control over their own lives, providing more incentive and choice, ensuring a fair go for all, and building one Australia. I do not have time in this debate to go into the whole of the detail of what has been put forward by John Howard on behalf of the Liberal and National parties, but whatever aspect of government policy we look at, those principles need to be applied. Let me take tax policy. The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) would like to interrupt me, but I will not be interrupted because if we note what has happened in the tax system under Labor, we find that the increased tax burden which is being borne by all Australians is borne most heavily by families with dependants. In other words, those who are most vulnerable pay the most. I remind the Senate that the tax policies put forward by the Liberal and National parties, both in 1984 and in 1987, made it quite clear that our tax policy will discriminate in favour of Australians who are meeting their responsibilities to their dependants. I mark that as one of the key areas which mark us off from Labor. Labor has made the tax system more burdensome for families with dependants and for individuals with dependants, and it has made the tax system comparatively easier for those who are not meeting their responsibilities.

As to building one Australia, there is another fundamental difference between the Opposition and the Government. The Opposition will ensure that all sectors of the Australian community are treated equally. I want to say two things about that. The first is that to any of us who come from Western Australia it has been glaringly obvious that the Labor Party stands for a better deal for its friends than for the community generally. One of the extraordinary changes that have been achieved in Western Australia under five years of Labor rule, principally under Premier Burke but now under Premier Dowding, is that there is no longer equal treatment of the people. The fact is that if one is part of the inner circle, if one is part of the select coterie, a better deal is available. One of the things that the Liberal and National parties stand for, both in Western Australia and nationally, is equal treatment. We will ensure that that is brought about. It is long overdue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like you got in Queensland over a long time.

—We will see in Queensland a coalition government which will be governed by exactly the same principles, and I look forward to that. I believe that it is in that area of ensuring that Labor's mates do not get the fair deal and everybody else gets no deal at all that we will mark out a great difference between ourselves and the present Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I want to make is that, under the Liberal and National parties, trade unions will be given the same equality of treatment as afforded other interest groups in the community. They will no longer call the shots in a way which is quite out of line with our democratic and basic traditions. It is clear that it is time for new directions in Australia. We believe that this Government has lost the confidence of the people of Australia, and we look forward to the next election when it will be thrown out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a motion of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting: the Opposition brings forward a motion of urgency, yet when a speaker from this side rises to debate the matter it does its best to drown out that speaker. I will not be drowned out. I will put the Government's case. I will show that this motion contains a series of platitudes. It would be no surprise to anyone that I oppose a motion which starts:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of Labor's economic and social policies which have increased the burden on all Australian families . . .

Assertions have been made by the Opposition this afternoon. It is very easy for the Oppositions to make assertions about the Hawke Government's alleged inactivity in relation to the Australian economy and to say that this inactivity affects Australian families. It is another matter to prove that these assertions are correct. I claim that the Opposition is on thin ice when it speaks of Labor's failure with its economic and social policies. Indeed, there is a sharp and marked contrast when one looks at the woeful record of the previous Liberal-National Government-I refer, of course, to the Fraser Government-and when one compares that record with what Labor has done to rectify the situation since it became the Government in March 1983.

When Senator Chaney was addressing the Senate, an Opposition senator asked a Minister across the chamber what he had ever done for the workers. The Minister retorted, `We've given the workers jobs'. This is very important for all Australian families. If we are to strengthen families, surely one of the major concerns is employment. When a family's breadwinner is unemployed, the quality of family life is diminished. Not only is it diminished in an economic sense but also a family's social life becomes limited. Instead of enjoying life, some family members are overcome by despair.

Against that background it is pertinent to examine the job creation records of the Hawke Government and the Fraser Government. In the period from 1983, when the Hawke Government came to office, to now, 1,179,700-almost 1.2 million-jobs have been created. This is a massive number, and it does not occur unless the Federal Government has taken positive steps to create an economic climate which is conducive to job creation. The Hawke Government has done just that. I remember the parlous situation in Australia when we came into government in 1983 in terms of jobs for ordinary people-family members. In the 12 months prior to our coming into government, the situation had became worse and worse. We as a government had the trust placed in us to provide jobs for Australian people. That trust has not been misplaced. We went about that matter with vigour and we have provided those jobs. As Senator Cook said in response to an interjection, we have helped the families of Australian by providing them with jobs. That is a major area of concern.

I mentioned that nearly 1.2 million jobs have been created since this Government came to power. Perhaps it is difficult to visualise what an increase of a million jobs means. Let us look at the Fraser Government's record. From November 1975 to March 1983, which is longer than the period of the Hawke Government, 334,200 jobs were created. Putting it another way, in a shorter time than the Fraser Government had at its disposal, Labor has provided three times as many jobs. I repeat: from 1975 to 1983, 334,000 jobs were created and, in less time than that, the Hawke Government has created almost 1.2 million jobs. If one compares the last 5 1/2 years of the Fraser Government with the 5 1/2 years of the current Hawke Government, the contrast is even more marked. In their last 5 1/2 years the Liberals and Nationals as a government created 242,500 jobs-less than one-quarter of the greater than one million jobs created under Labor's first 5 1/2 years.

One might ask what all this has to do with the alleged matter of urgency which has been proposed by the Opposition. It has a great deal to do with it. Employment is of vital importance to Australian families. It is often easy to underestimate the number of people who are affected by changes to employment patterns. The one million-plus jobs created under the Hawke Government's economic policies directly affect just over three million people-those who have the jobs and members of their immediate families who are dependent on them. So we are not just looking at the one million who have jobs; we are looking at about three million in the community who have been affected. Many people who have jobs now would not have had them had the previous Government's policies been followed. One may ask how many families had joy in the last 12 months of the Fraser Government. Many did not. In that period of the Fraser Administration there was no increase in the number of jobs available in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 406, which requires honourable senators not to read speeches. I believe that the honourable senator is reading his speech. I ask you to request him not to do so.
—Standing order 406 has been debated many times in this chamber. I prefer to consider that Senator Colston is using copious notes.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. It is necessary for me to use copious notes because I do not keep figures in my head as Senator Walsh does. I can use the figures just as effectively, but I need to have them in front of me. I was saying that during the last 12 months of the Fraser Administration there was no increase in the number of jobs available in Australia. Actually, the situation was even worse than that. During the last 12 months of the Fraser Administration the number of employment positions in Australia fell: 186,900 jobs vanished. Again, the number of people affected by the loss of those 186,900 jobs was greater than that. Half a million people-those who lost their jobs and members of their families-were affected directly.

SPEECH.PARA: When I look at the Fraser Government's dismal record and the Hawke Government's positive record on job creation, I am reminded of an educational report entitled Promise and Performance. I am not quite sure whether Senator Boswell was in Queensland during his primary school days-he was probably in Western Australia-but if he had been in Queensland he might have heard of the report Promise and Performance. The report was based on a longitudinal study of students who had shown promise, as measured by academic achievement, in their final year of primary school in Queensland and whether their performance in later years matched their earlier promise. Those who are listening in Queensland and are of my vintage may remember that we used to have an examination called the scholarship examination. Based on the 1951 scholarship examination, the promise of various students was measured and their performance was measured later.

Today the Opposition may be full of promise when it talks about future directions but, given the unlikely event of a coalition victory at the next Federal election, how would that promise be backed up by performance? I expect that the performance would be dismal. One has only to look at the previous record of the Liberals and Nationals to see that. As I have outlined, that record was, to put it quite mildly, dismal. Just as past performance is a good indicator of future performance in many fields, so too is it in government. There is every reason to expect that the employment record of a future Liberal-National government would be equally dismal.

Before leaving the issue of employment, which is of vital importance to Australian families, I mention that between 170,000 and 200,000 jobs have to be created each year in Australia just to accommodate those persons entering or re-entering the work force. Labor has done far better than that. It has been able not only to accommodate these persons but also to create extra jobs. When the Hawke Government gained office in March 1983, 9.9 per cent of the work force was unemployed. Under the Hawke Government's policies, this figure has dropped to 6.9 per cent. I would like to see unemployment drop far lower than that. There is still room for improvement, but the statistics show that Labor is heading in the right direction. Unlike the Liberal Party of Australia, Labor does not have to conduct a weekend function to try to convince its Party faithful that everything now is all sweetness and light. We are moving in the right direction and the people of Australia who have jobs because of our policies are well aware of that fact.

The Hawke Government is well aware that, without adequate educational opportunities being made available to our young people, employment prospects could be stunted. Not only do we have to look at our employment record, we have to look at our record of providing educational opportunities for the young people of this country. To this effect, the Hawke Government has been actively pursuing a policy of encouraging more students to stay at school longer. It is not satisfactory for students to leave school early in the hope of finding unskilled employment. Such employment is not nearly as plentiful as it was. In the past, young males often went into the same calling as their fathers, and that calling may have been an unskilled job. They cannot do that now, because such unskilled jobs are not available in the same quantities as they were. It is necessary for young people to gain more skills at school before they actually seek jobs. Jobs are available in Australia, but job seekers require skills and, sometimes, highly developed skills. By encouraging students to stay at school longer, we will have a much better-educated work force, which will allow us to compete with overseas countries and thus increase the prosperity of the nation as well as the workers and their families.

This is what we are attempting to do with our educational policies. We are trying to get young people to stay at school longer; to develop the skills they need so that they can have jobs which will improve their quality of life and that of their families and enable them to make a contribution to Australia. We are encouraging young people to stay longer at school, but this is often not enough. Low income families, unless they receive some financial assistance, find it hard to contemplate sending their youngsters to school when the young people could leave school, have an unskilled job, or draw an unemployment benefit. It is unfortunate that in times gone past, the children of low income families have not been able to take advantage of higher education or even education beyond the year 10 level for the final two years of secondary school. It has been necessary for them to go out into the work force, take an unskilled job and unfortunately remain unskilled for the rest of their working lives.

For this reason, the Hawke Government introduced Austudy, which has been made available not only to tertiary students-as was the case under the old scheme-but also to full time secondary students. I am a little concerned that some low income families are not aware that their sons or daughters, once they reach the age of 16, can receive this benefit to stay at school. In 1989, a 16- or 17-year-old student, living at home, will be able to receive a maximum rate of $53.55 a week, subject to an income asset test, which I will mention in a moment.

Higher rates will be available for older students and for those living away from home. These payments which are of extreme assistance to those students and their families, are income and assets tested, thus ensuring that the benefits are provided to families in need. If students from these families can, with Austudy assistance, gain greater skills and thus a more financially rewarding job, surely the whole family will benefit.

Some scant mention was made of the family allowance supplement which was introduced by the Hawke Government. This supplement was introduced because we, as a government, could see that some of the most needy families in Australia were not necessarily those on some benefit or pension, but those who were bringing into the home a fairly low weekly wage. The family allowance supplement provides people on a low wage with extra assistance for their children. This tax-free supplement is on top of the family allowance money which people already receive.

Many people have been helped by the family allowance supplement. For instance, a family with one child and an income of $300 a week or less can receive a supplement of $22. This amount will be increased early in the new year. Increased amounts are paid when the child reaches 13, 14 or 15 years of age.

We had some difficulty, when introducing this scheme, in contacting all of those people who would be eligible. This is not an easy group to contact. However, many people are now benefiting from the family allowance supplement, which we have introduced, as a result of the great efforts that have been made to contact them.

I reject the urgency motion that has been moved this afternoon by the Opposition. The Hawke Government has looked after families in Australia. The Hawke Government has positive policies and the Hawke Government will be returned at the next election because the people of Australia definitely know what the Hawke Government is doing for them. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I read in this morning's newspapers that Mr Howard was going to rely on unrestrained personal greed in a fully deregulated market to get us back to the good old days, I wondered whether the private enterprise displayed by the Bond Corporation, for instance, which had a tax liability of only one per cent this year, needed more incentive. Again in this morning's newspapers we saw that incentivation and free market forces had combined to break the one per cent barrier. I am sure that the Opposition parties and the Government are pleased with themselves. I, like others, read that three corporate taxpayers, Qintex Ltd, Adsteam and Equiticorp Australia Ltd paid tax at the levels of 0.11, 0.43 and 0.8 per cent of their gross earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: By comparison, the tax burden on pay as you earn taxpayers has increased steadily, taking in a greater proportion of the family's income. The Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) has documented the fact that a single parent in public housing can face an equivalent marginal tax rate in excess of 140 per cent, a classic poverty trap. Yet after the 1986-87 Budget, the Liberal and National parties, which have brought us this urgency motion today, voted with the Government to delay by six months legislation designed to ease poverty traps of a similar nature, making pensioners wait for their cost of living adjustments for another six weeks. That delay is still in operation, at the expense of Australia's pensioners. The same Opposition brings us this urgency motion today, slamming the Government, whose actions it has supported, and pushing its own barrow. The Opposition is firing its first parliamentary shot in the salvo launched yesterday by its Leader, John Howard, its `back to basics' campaign. An article in the Australian Financial Review this morning was headed `Opposition woos the family'. The Age this morning pointed to the family and family values being the cornerstone of this `back to basics' push. But the Age editorial this morning asked the crucial question, which is also raised by this motion. It states:
When Mr Howard speaks of supporting the family, what sort of family does he mean? Do single parents, de facto couples or homosexual relationships qualify?

I could ask whether my father-in-law qualifies. He is a single, elderly person living in a retirement village. I could ask whether my mother qualifies. She lives in a non-nuclear family with my sister and her family. We should consider the question, `What is a family?'. I refer honourable senators to the social justice statement of the Anglican Church of Australia put out in 1986, to which I have previously referred in this place. It points out that everyone belongs to a family, or has belonged to a family at some stage during life, that it is not easy to define what `family' means in modern society, and that there are many variations. It suggests that one general definition of a family is `one or two adults living with one or more dependent children'. An even simpler definition is `where kids live'. The document states:
In determining a christian view of the family, it is important not to suggest that there is a functionally optimal family . . .
I hope that Opposition senators are listening to this. The Age this morning, quoting the Liberal and National parties' document Future Directions, under the heading `The Family', stated:
Although government should not penalise alternative lifestyles, it has a responsibility to ensure that the family unit has the legal, financial and social support necessary to sustain it.

I suggest that the Opposition look very closely at the exhortation by the Anglican Church that we should not assume that one type of family is functionally optimal as opposed to other types of families, or there will be rank discrimination, as I suspect there will be in any case. The Anglican Church's social justice statement goes on to say that the church has a habit of speaking of the ideal family. The Future Directions statement does just that. It also has on its front cover a picture of such a family. The Anglican Church's statement goes on to say:

. . . we need to approach family life as it is actually experienced. There are external pressures on it in Australia today: unemployment, poor nutrition, homelessness, emotional and physical violence, work demands and poverty. There are internal pressures: violence, incest, child abuse and immature relationships. Then there is the place of family in its immediate neighbourhood: whether the community gives support to or ignores vulnerable families, and provides services for them.
The family is the most economic way for people to live, from the government's point of view, because resources are shared voluntarily and at almost no cost to the State.

The statement goes on to suggest that that is why universal payments to all families with dependent children are desirable, a sentiment which I support. The statement points out that families transfer wealth among themselves and between generations and provide great opportunities for each other in terms of skill development. Dr Don Edgar, of the Institute of Family Studies, points out that the family remains the most central unit of social interaction and economic exchange in people's lives. He also points to the fact that unemployment affects family life, not just the economy. He goes on to say that the family is the major socialising agent of society, the `crucible of competence' in society. So we must look at the family in the broadest possible way. I doubt from the evidence thus far whether that is what the Opposition is doing.

Only 26.2 per cent of the total population lives in families of two parents with dependent children under the age of 15, the sort of family pictured over the shoulder of John Howard yesterday as he delivered his Future Directions statement. What about the rest of Australia? I refer to the Background Discussion paper No. 23 of the Social Security Review. It examines types of families with dependent children, which is a subset of all families in the first place, assuming that those dependent children are under 16 years of age. Only 37 per cent of all families with dependent children-which leaves out single parent families and family groupings of elderly people who no longer have dependent children-are two-parent families with one parent employed; 41 per cent are two-parent families with both parents employed at least part-time; 15 per cent are single adult families, and 7 per cent are two-parent families with both parents unemployed. There is not a lot of uniformity.

The Australian Democrats do not argue with the concept of the importance of family life. But, as Dr Don Edgar points out, a great deal is wrong with our system, with policies and their implementation, which indicates a failure to understand all of the influences on the structure of family life. He says that structural changes in family life must be understood if child poverty is to be eradicated.

These changes have included the downward fertility rate as a result of differing attitudes to having children and to changes in contraception availability; the changing role of women, which has economic and social consequences and which still enshrines a great deal of economic inequity as far as women are concerned; the social and economic costs from the breakdown of marriage; the rigidity in education and training, which limits employment opportunities, particularly for women, and is at the expense of access and flexibility for people to get into the work force; and the attitude to child care-that it is too costly, we cannot afford it and therefore we cannot provide it.

We need to look at some important current facts about family life. Last year's figures showed that 55 per cent of female-headed sole parent families lived in poverty, 19 per cent of married couple families with three or more children lived in poverty and 41 per cent of families with four or more children lived in poverty. There is also the alarming estimate that one in five Australian children-that is, nearly 820,000-are growing up in a family with an income below the Henderson poverty line. That is probably an underestimate of the extent of child poverty because, although we have certainty of the numbers of children reliant on social security income, we do not have a definitive measure of the number of children living in families earning a low wage or with self-employed parents. Since we must be talking about all families, that must be of major concern.

A recent publication of the Australian Council of Social Service contained a summary of Alison McClelland's paper to the ACOSS National Congress, which points out that according to the August 1987 figures 1.4 million people have wage and salary earnings of less than $240 per week and low wage earners are likely to be women, juniors, part-time or part year workers, clustered in certain industries-the wholesale and retail trade, manufacturing, community services, finance, property and business services. It also cited figures within some families. Fifty-six per cent of income units containing a low wage earner had total combined incomes of less than $20,900 a year. Twenty-five per cent of parents of young low wage earners living at home had combined incomes of less than $15,500. Fifteen per cent of income units containing a low wage earner were below the poverty line. These are figures of families whose needs must be addressed by coalition policy as well as by government policy; we must not forget this.

In that context, I referred earlier to poverty traps surrounding people on pensions and benefits. The recent EPAC report, Income Support Policies, Taxation and Incentives, pointed out that poverty traps exist also for low wage earners. The family allowance supplement has been lauded here already, and will be further during the debate, but let us not ignore the fact that it has had the effect of increasing the equivalent marginal tax rate for a significant number of low income working families in the range where this payment is being phased out. This is a classical poverty trap. Of course, this is experienced only by families with dependent children. Further, other income tested transfers for taxpayers with dependent children raise their equivalent marginal tax rate, that is, payment such as Austudy, subsidised child care and the like. So it is not all beer and skittles, even if one does have a job and is not on government benefits.

There has been vast documentation on this, including a very good paper on child poverty, recently presented in Melbourne by Jenny Tretheweyn of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, in which many of the major causes of child poverty have been clearly defined. If we are to do something for families, I suggest that this is a priority. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made that comment in the past. But the question is whether we can meet that priority. These causes are an increase in the rate and duration of unemployment in families with children; the growth in the number of sole parent families; housing costs; the inadequacy of income support for families with children, and the effects of wage restraint on people with low incomes.

I wish to say a brief word about increased unemployment. This increase has been substantial in the past two decades. While the Government tells us a lot about increased employment under its administration, we must realise that between 1983 and 1988 over one-third of jobs created in Australia were part time. These figures are from the Family Research Bulletin of the Mission of St James and St John. As we know, part time employment does not fill bellies unless it is supplemented somewhere else in the family; it does not come with pro rata benefits; it goes largely to the young and to the female; and it is not adequate. So I challenge the Government's figures there. The trend to unemployment and to this inadequacy will continue as long as the Government and the Opposition parties are prepared to accept a 7 or 8 per cent level of unemployment as an economic necessity and an inevitable component of its deregulated market economy-which attitude has taken the place of Government responsibility to its citizens in recent times.

If we look at other aspects of the problems facing families in poverty, in particular families with children, we see that there has been a growth in the number of sole parent families. The Government must do more to support families staying together. I regret that it is not refunding the Family Mediation Centre or any other pilot programs in that area, but instead waiting until things have broken down.

Housing is a major area where families need help. All the Opposition talks about is home ownership. But there are many families, especially sole parent and low income families, who cannot afford that. This Government has not been prepared to put funds into housing. Clearly, the Opposition, from the headlines about its statement yesterday, is not prepared to do that either. There is no question that these are the major issues facing this country.

We must not forget wage restraint, which has been carried out by wage earners in this society who have not had the benefit from the last round of tax cuts. This wage restraint is impacting on families and particularly children in our society. I will conclude with the words of Don Edgar who said:
Helping families--
