TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the urgency motion moved today by Senator Chaney, namely,

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The failure of Labor's economic and social policies which have increased the burdens on all Australian families and the need for the Government to adopt policies which provide incentive for individuals, strengthen the family and encourage the growth of private enterprise in Australia.

Before my own remarks on that topic, I must spend at least a moment or two referring to the remarks made by the previous speaker, Senator Powell of the Australian Democrats. I do not often speak in this place in support of the Government, because it is very rare that the Government does anything that we can support; but the fact is that the Government at least has some responsibilities because it is the Government. The Government does not actually acquit its responsibilities very well, but it does have some responsibilities and from time to time it acknowledges that it has those responsibilities, just as we on this side of the chamber know that, after the next election, we will have those responsibilities and we will acquit them. But the party represented by the honourable senator who has just sat down has no responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rentacrats.

—`Rentacrats', as my colleague Senator Patterson says. The Australian Democrats have no responsibilities, and never will have. That is why they feel the freedom to come into this place and to roam all around the ridges of this country talking the sort of stuff that we have heard today from Senator Powell.

SPEECH.PARA: It is because of the adoption in this country over years of the kind of populist rhetoric that we have just heard from Senator Powell that we are in the mess that we are in. It is because of the acceptance of a policy of spending money as though it is going out of fashion that we are in the kind of mess that we are in. That is what produced the mess about which Senator Powell is now so hypocritically complaining. Let us not have any more of that stuff.

I make it clear that I speak today for every National Party of Australia senator in this place when I say that, in the next 12 months or however long it may be until the Government finally calls an election, we will support the kinds of policies which were announced yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, and the Leader of my Party, Mr Ian Sinclair, in Parramatta and we will state the values for which people in these two coalition parties stand.

In his remarks opening this debate, Senator Chaney has already referred to the result, so far as the living standards of Australians are concerned, of 5 1/2 years of Labor government. This result-he was probably too polite to say this but I will say it-has been reflected in every Federal by-election this year. It has been reflected in the Adelaide by-election, which was lost by the Australian Labor Party, with an enormous swing against it. It has been reflected in the Port Adelaide by-election, which was barely retained by the Labor Party, with another major swing against it. It was reflected again in the seat of Oxley with a major swing against the Labor Party of nearly 12 per cent. It was the only seat to survive in the 1975 election in Queensland for Labor and it was almost lost on this occasion. That is what the people of Australia are saying about the policies-to use the words of the motion, the failure of Labor's economic and social policies which have increased the burdens on them. It is against those burdens which those people in those by-elections were protesting, and they voted in the most effective way by putting the appropriate votes in the ballot box.

I say to them, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that if they think what we have so far got has been bad and is bad, there is almost certainly worse to come. The truth is that for the past two years the Australian people have been conned by this Government into thinking that the worst is over. The worst is not over; the worst is yet to come. Whether it comes within the life of the present Government will depend on how quickly this Government scampers off to yet another early election and how quickly the threats to Australia's economy, which are still only external threats at the moment, come to pass. Why do I say that? The facts and the statistics speak for themselves. Last week the Australian Bureau of Statistics issued figures for foreign indebtedness of Australians as at 30 September last. Those figures show that at that date our gross foreign debt-that is, the debts to foreigners of all Australians, including governments, corporations and individuals-amounted to $120.4 billion. That was an increase of $4.2 billion over those three months alone and an increase of $12.2 billion over the previous 12 months.

If others prefer to employ figures for net debt-that is, after subtracting those small debts which foreigners owe to Australians and also after subtracting the gold and foreign exchange international reserves of our central bank-then the net debt of all Australians at 30 September last was $93.3 billion, an increase of $3.3 billion over the three months ended at that time. It was an increase of $10.9 billion over the 12 months. At that time that net debt was equivalent to just over 30 per cent of our domestic product. That compares with an equivalent percentage of just under 10 per cent when this Government came to office.

It is obvious to all honourable senators that the reason we have acquired that enormous net indebtedness to foreigners is that throughout the whole period of this Government being in office we have been running the most enormous deficits on the current account of our balance of payments. Those deficits can be paid for only in one of two ways: either by borrowings from foreigners or by selling off Australia's assets to foreigners. Again, the record, which is still running for this Government in the balance of payments area, is parlous. At the time of the Budget the Treasurer (Mr Keating) estimated that we would have a deficit of $9.5 billion this year. We had a deficit of $5.4 billion in the first four months. The Treasurer is not releasing a revised estimate but he is making it plain that his Budget estimate is now totally out of date.

The truly worrying aspect of this position of our balance of payments and of our foreign debt is that this has been occurring, and is still occurring, at a time when our export prices are as good as they have been for many years and our international terms of trade are better than they have been for a decade. In issuing the national account figures last week, the Statistician specifically said, `The terms of trade index is now at its highest since the June quarter of 1977'. In other words, with our international terms of trade now at their highest level for over a decade, we are in the process of recording a deficit on our external accounts for this financial year which could range somewhere between, I suspect, $11 billion and $12 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are we going backwards?

—The answer is that we are going backwards because the Government does not have the intestinal fortitude to take us forward. What more telling evidence could there be of the failure of Labor's economic and social policies than the position that I have just quoted-the fact that we have a balance of payments deficit of this size notwithstanding the fact that our international terms of trade are at their most favourable level, according to the Statistician, for over a decade-since the June quarter of 1977?

SPEECH.PARA: The matter does not stop there. I hasten to add that it is not just a matter of these rather dry economic statistics. It is not just a matter of economists' jargon. Above all, it is not a matter of mere politics, although this is a chamber for politics. As Senator Chaney has already pointed out, it is a matter which affects the everyday lives of the ordinary men and women of Australia. As Senator Puplick, who will follow me from our side of the chamber, will, I think, say in his remarks about family assistance, it is a matter which vitally affects that area of public policy.

The truth is that it is a matter of the gravest concern for all Australian families and individuals. It means that the Government has been pursuing a reckless course, and is still pursuing it-a course designed simply to cling to power for another term.

TALK.START.PARA: —A gutless course.

—It is a gutless course, as Senator Parer quite properly interjects. It has been doing so in order to allow it to scamper off to another early election around the middle of next year, only two years after the last one in July 1987, propping up demand meanwhile and depending upon favourable export prices to make the balance of payments look better, and then producing a big tax cut next July and having an election before the balance of payments storm-generated, in part, by that tax cut-really breaks, without doing the things that are necessary to have real tax cuts, namely, to cut the Government's own spending. But things have gone wrong. The Government is now in more than a little disarray as a consequence of that.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Keating, who not so long ago was the darling not only of the Government but of the media, is now beginning to come under a little pressure and strain. If I may say so, he is showing it. Nowhere did he show it more clearly than in his media conference, in company with the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, last Thursday when these two Mutt and Jeff characters sought to pour a bucket in advance on the coalition's Future Directions policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't they come unstuck?
—As Senator Boswell quite properly interjects, they did indeed come unstuck. For once the Press Gallery actually asked them a few hard questions.
—And they got cranky.

—Mr Keating, in particular, got exceedingly cranky. In fact, he became positively abusive. He is not used to being tested in these matters. He should join the Opposition, as he will shortly have the opportunity of doing.
—He will be there for a long time.

—He will not be there for a long time; he is not used to opposition. As I said, things have gone wrong. Mr Keating's cart has run off the track; the wheels have fallen off. The Budget has not done the trick. That huge surplus was supposed to produce `downward pressure on interest rates'-and I am quoting from the Budget Speech. Interest rates have been rising ever since two days after the Budget Speech. And they are still rising. Indeed short term interest rates are now just over two full percentage points higher than they were when the Budget was brought down. What we have now is an economy which is sucking in imports at a tremendous rate. The Government is going to apply a short, sharp shock to it. Do honourable senators remember that discredited phrase which used to be applied to the policies of previous governments by honourable senators now sitting on the Government side of the chamber? Do they remember the phrase `short, sharp shock'? That is what Mr Keating is now in the process of applying to the economy-or a short, sharp squeeze, by way of very high interest rates. The point is that it will not be short, although it certainly will be sharp. Indeed, I can already see that sharpness reflected in the most recent figures for private dwelling approvals, which were down by, I think, 8 1/2 per cent in October in seasonally adjusted terms.

SPEECH.PARA: Why are we getting all this from the Government? We are getting it in order to deflate the economy sufficiently by the middle of next year to enable the Government still to go ahead with its promised tax cuts at that time. Therefore, the slightly revised game plan now is to produce a sort of mild recession by the middle of next year in order to make it look as though giving tax cuts at that time, without cutting the Government's own spending, is responsible. That is what we have now. Here we have a government that has been drifting along for nearly two years now, sustained during that time by rising export prices-notwithstanding which our debt continues to mount-and also by the sale of our assets to foreigners at an increasing rate, and which has promised to produce a fistful of dollars from 1 July next year, after which it can have an election. That policy is producing today the equivalent of a credit squeeze in order to depress the economy sufficiently to enable that still to proceed while maintaining some semblance of responsibility as far as the balance of payments is concerned.

Every Australian family which has a mortgage will feel this process in the course of the weeks and months ahead because the Government has got it wrong and is unwilling to admit that it has got it wrong. It is unwilling to admit that Labor's economic and social policies have failed and are in the process of increasing the burden to all Australian families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing could better illustrate the extent to which the Australian Labor Party is out of touch with the real needs of Australian families, particularly working families, than the speech just given by Senator Childs. . . . there was a significant increase in child poverty from 7.9 per cent of all children in 1972-73 to 20.7 per cent of all children in 1985-86.

That report goes on to deal in part with the difficulties and the social problems of some of those families. Let me quote just two of them. One of them says:

However, many of the families most in need (single parent and recent immigrant families in particular) lead a very restricted social existence . . . Many report that this absence of the outward signs of respectability contributes to children's dislike of school and that families withdraw from the whole round of community activities such as children's sport, school excursions, parent-teacher meetings and the exchange of visits with friends and relatives. That is the record of this Government-television or tobacco. That is the record that Senator Childs comes in here and defends-television or tobacco.
The report goes on to talk about the health determinants of poor families. It says:

That is the record of Senator Childs-a social life of tobacco and television and the inability to afford simple medication for their children. That is the record that Senator Childs, from the great vantages of life on Scotland Island, wants to come into this chamber today and talk about.
In this EPAC report, we find, for example:
The dominant reason for increased spending on social security-
about which this Government waxes so lyrical-

the incidence of relative poverty has increased more among younger than older groups;

Just looking through the report and from my own observations, particularly having had the responsibility as shadow Minister in this area for the last year, there have been a great deal more triumphs than failures. One looks at the spectacular performances around Australia and, in particular, on Sydney Harbour on Australia Day. One looks at the international Girl Guides and Boy Scouts jamborees in the course of the year. One looks at the visit of the giant pandas; the bicentennial around Australia air race; the bicentennial Gold Cup soccer tournament and, in particular, Australia's spectacular win over Argentina; the whole Tall Ships program; and the unrecognised but spectacular achievement of Jonathan King and the First Fleet re-enactment voyage.

One looks at a couple of failures. I believe that the travelling exhibition was not a great success. It is important that we now start turning our minds to the next great celebration events in Australian history and this is the centenary of Federation. That is the important matter for people to now focus their attention on. A number of events which have their centenary between now and 2001 will take place. Commissioner of Taxation

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE EIGHTIETH CONFERENCE OF THE INTER-PARLIAMENTARY UNION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the Eightieth Conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU). I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was privileged to be one of the six Australian parliamentary delegates to the eightieth conference of the IPU held in Sofia, Bulgaria, from 19 to 24 September this year. The leader of the delegation was the Hon. Tom Uren; the deputy leader was Mr Roger Shipton; and the other members of the delegation were Mr Peter Cleeland, Mr David Jull and Mr David Simmons. When this report was tabled in the other place Mr Uren said that `this was a happy delegation which worked well together. There was cooperative teamwork'. I endorse that view. Meetings were held prior to our departure to prepare us for the event of the IPU. We were briefed by officers from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and staff from the Parliamentary Library. I was also fortunate to have a briefing with officers of Amnesty International at its headquarters in London en route to Sofia, where I was well advised on the discrimination against the Turkish minority in Bulgaria. I will make another remark about that later. Amnesty had been invited to attend the IPU conference for the first time, with observer status, because the human rights issue was prominent on the agenda. Amnesty was very pleased to be there for the first time.

SPEECH.PARA: Ninety-five countries took part in the conference with a total of 770 delegates, including 455 members of parliament. On the day prior to the conference-that is, Sunday, 18 September-there was a meeting of women parliamentarians. Sixty parliamentarians from 39 countries were present at that meeting, which was held in the Bulgarian National Assembly under the chairmanship of Mrs Lagadinova, a member of the Bulgarian National Assembly. The discussions were very fruitful and ranged far and wide. I think the most important matter discussed was ways of improving the participation of women parliamentarians in the activities of the Inter-Parliamentary Union. In this connection participants considered a proposed amendment to the statutes of the Union which was submitted by the Canadian group, which guaranteed the membership of at least two women on the executive committee, and a suggestion from the group from Zaire for an amendment to the statutes of the Union aimed at ensuring that more women are council members. The amendment was carried. I am pleased to say that the rules of the conference specify that, for the time being, at least two members of the executive must be women. That will provide some catch-up time, as in the 99 years of existence of the IPU there has hardly ever been a woman on the executive committee.

The items on the agenda for the conference dealt primarily with human rights. They dealt with the actions of parliaments in bringing their legislation into line with humanitarian principles on an international basis. They also dealt with the contribution of parliaments to the implementation of United Nations resolutions with regard to the granting of independence to colonial territories and to the elimination of colonialism, racism and apartheid. A supplementary item seeking support for talks towards achievement of comprehensive, just and lasting peace between Iran and Iraq was added to the agenda.

The involvement of the Australian delegates in Sofia was intense. Mr Tom Uren was a member of the drafting committee on the issue of decolonisation and the implementation of United Nations resolutions. Mr Roger Shipton was rapporteur for the drafting committee on the conference supplementary item on the popular uprising in the Arab territories occupied by Israel. All the other delegates had active participation in both plenary sessions of the conference as well as in committee meetings for the subject items. There can be no doubt that people can only be assured of human rights when their elected representatives are themselves guaranteed human rights. The human rights of parliamentarians was another item on the agenda.

I would like to express my special thanks to Mr Fred Peppinick, who was adviser to the delegation from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and Mr Rob Diamond, who was secretary to the delegation from the Department of the Senate. I would also like to thank those who gave us support from the Australian Embassy in Belgrade. Of course, they are all very much in our thoughts at the present time, particularly Mr Hoyle, the Ambassador, Ms Katherine Smits and Miss Christina Bogiatsis; not to mention our driver, Slovodan.

I would also like to place on record my thanks to the people of Bulgaria for their friendliness and hospitality. Travelling in Sofia's trolley buses and trams; strolling through the cobblestoned streets; sitting at pavement cafes and visiting Mount Vitosha together with the locals taking the mountain air on a Sunday-all these were very pleasurable activities of which I retain very fond memories. Glasnost is certainly in the air in Bulgaria, although the House of Assembly, with all the members' seats in rows facing the raised platform which contains the only microphones, is not a prescription for democracy.

Finally, I wish to mention the fate of the Turkish minority, some of whom are in the region of Khardzaly and some of whom are in more northern parts. Not only are they not permitted to celebrate openly their traditional culture, but also they are forbidden to wear their traditional Turkish-style baggy trousers. Worse, and very cruelly, they are being forced to dispense with their Turkish names and adopt Bulgarian names, or lose their jobs. This perhaps is the ultimate `One-Bulgaria' policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill amends several Acts within the Attorney-General's portfolio and a related Act administered by the Minister for Housing and Aged Care.

The Bill contains amendments of a minor policy nature. Other amendments tidy up, correct or update existing legislation. None of the amendments concerns major new policy proposals or sensitive policy issues. None has any significant financial impact. The amendments to the Law Officers Act will have a slight financial impact. They provide for a pension for a Solicitor-General based on a judge's pension, deferred until age 60 and discounted both for shorter term of service and the difference between age at cessation of office and 60 years. The removal of the current entitlement of a lump sum equal to twice annual salary at the end of a 7 year appointment, represents an offset against the cost of the new pension.
The proposed amendments are explained in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my comments to the more noteworthy amendments.
Amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975

Amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act will provide for term appointments as an alternative to the existing situation of appointments to age 70 in the case of full-time Deputy Presidents and to age 65 in the case of full-time senior members. The maximum term of such appointments would be 7 years, but reappointment could be made. At present the option of term appointment is only available for part-time Deputy Presidents, part-time senior members and ordinary members.

The inclusion of term appointments as an alternative to tenured appointments for full-time Deputy Presidents and senior members will provide greater flexibility in staffing the Tribunal, primarily by enabling appointment of members on a short-term basis to handle particular backlogs or initial peaks in work when new jurisdictions are conferred on the Tribunal. The amendments are also expected to result in a widening of the pool of potential appointees to include those who might not wish to consider a career appointment.

A consequential amendment to section 16 of the Act will exclude the application of the Judges' Pensions Act 1968 to term appointees. At present, the Judges' Pensions Act applies to a full-time Deputy President as if he or she were a judge. Part-time Deputy Presidents are excluded, and the amendment means that full-time Deputy Presidents who are term appointees will also be excluded.

Other amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act will ensure that in proceedings before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the States and the Northern Territory will have the same entitlement as the Commonwealth to claim public interest privilege in respect of documents subpoenaed by the Tribunal and questions asked in the course of a proceeding which relate to Cabinet documents or the deliberations of Cabinet, or otherwise support a claim of public interest privilege.
Amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979

One amendment to the Australian Federal Police Act will give greater flexibility in administration, as the Commissioner, and not the Minister, will be empowered to determine the number of officers in the various rank levels of the Australian Federal Police. Other amendments, based on provisions in the Public Service Act will ensure that all persons eligible for appointment have a reasonable opportunity to apply for appointment to the Australian Federal Police. They will ensure equity and fairness in appointments, promotions and transfers, apply the merit principle and prohibit patronage, favouritism, and discrimination on various specified grounds as well as unlawful or any other unjustified discrimination. Also provision is made for review of non-appealable promotion decisions by the Merit Protection and Review Agency.
Amendments to the Customs Act 1901

An amendment to the Customs Act will specifically abrogate the privilege against self-incrimination in respect of a statement furnished to the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy pursuant to a Court order. However, evidence obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of furnishing such a statement to the Official Trustee will not be admissible in civil or criminal proceedings, other than a proceeding in respect of falsity of the statement, or a proceeding for the recovery of a pecuniary penalty. In the latter case it will be admissible only for the purpose of facilitating the assessment of the amount of the penalty. This places information contained in such a statement in the same position as information obtained pursuant to a court-ordered examination of the person.
Amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983
An amendment to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act will remove any doubt that may exist that the Director has the right to seek review of a bail decision.
Amendments to the Family Law Act 1975

An amendment will make a minor jurisdictional change in relation to the application of the Family Law Act in the Northern Territory. It will remove jurisdiction from the Family Court of Australia, in matters arising under a law of the Northern Territory, thereby treating the Northern Territory in the same way as a State.

Other amendments to the Family Law Act will ensure that a lawyer appointed by the Court as a separate representative for a child, in proceedings concerning the child's welfare, has adequate and effective powers to obtain a report by a psychologist or psychiatrist for use in the proceedings.
The repeal of subsection 78 (3) of the Act will enable the Court, in appropriate cases, to make orders that are binding on third parties as well as the parties to a marriage.

Many family law property disputes involve adjudication of the rights of the parties to a marriage as between themselves and third parties, such as banks. As the Act presently stands, third parties may intervene in proceedings under the Act pursuant to section 92, but may not be bound by any order of the Court as a consequence of subsection 78 (3). The present lack of power to make binding determinations about the existence and extent of the rights and liabilities of third parties can be frustrating for both the court and the parties as well as adding to the expense of proceedings. For example, even if a court concludes that particular property does not belong to either party to the marriage but to a third party, the court cannot, because of subsection 78 (3), make any declaration or order in favour of the third party.

The repeal of subsection 78 (3) will also ensure that the Commonwealth and State cross-vesting legislation which came into force on 1 July 1988 has full effect in relation to the Family Court by enabling that Court to determine the rights and liabilities of third parties in proceedings before it where it is appropriate and convenient for it to do so.

This amendment gives effect to a recommendation of the Law Reform Commission in its report on Matrimonial Property and to comments by the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia and the Chief Justice of the Family Court of Australia.
Amendments to the Law Officers Act 1964

Currently, unless a Solicitor-General completes 10 years service he or she is not entitled to a judicial pension. However, under provisions in the Law Officers Act, a Solicitor-General who has completed 7 years service (the normal term of appointment) receives a lump sum payment equal to twice annual salary. This provision was intended to assist a Solicitor-General who is not reappointed at the end of that term to re-establish himself or herself in private practice. While the sum may be adequate for that purpose, it does not adequately cater for the Solicitor-General's security or that of his or her family if the Solicitor-General dies or becomes incapacitated after ceasing to hold office.

Accordingly, the Law Officers Act is to be amended to provide for a deferred pension for the Solicitor-General, payable at age 60, after completing 7 years of service, or on prior death or invalidity, based on similar criteria for a judicial pension. The pension at age 60 is to be discounted by 2.5% per year for the difference between the age on cessation of office and age 60.
Amendments to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987

The Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act was amended by the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1988, to insert new foreign law testimonial immunity provisions intended to preserve the foreign testimonial immunity of witnesses who come to Australia to give evidence, and to confer similar immunity on persons who give evidence in Australia at the request of foreign countries. This Bill amends the Act to make it clear that such immunity will not apply in any case where its application would be inconsistent with the applicable Mutual Assistance Treaty.
Amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987

There are several amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act, most of which have been requested by the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy and the Director of Public Prosecutions in the light of practical experience with the Act. Some amendments provide protection to bona fide third parties whose property interests are affected by registered foreign forfeiture orders, broadly similar to the protection provided in relation to domestic forfeiture orders. There are also a number of machinery amendments that are necessary having regard to experience with the Act to date, dealing with such matters as the meaning of the term `effective control of property', permitting the court to make composite restraining orders covering both known property of the defendant as well as property acquired after the making of the order and abrogating the privilege against self-incrimination with respect to court-ordered statements furnished to the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy. An indemnity, similar to that contained in the amendment to the Customs Act, is included. The opportunity has been taken to generally improve the wording of a number of existing provisions.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT (GENERAL CAPITAL INCREASE) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up part of its allocated subscription to the third general capital increase of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD).

Honourable senators will be aware that the main activity of the Bank, which was established in 1947, is lending to developing countries. Up to end of June 1988, the Bank had lent about $US128 billion to its member countries. This money was largely borrowed from international financial markets. The cost to taxpayers in member countries in terms of paid-in capital subscriptions was only $US7.7 billion. Projects financed covered all the major sectors of economic development with an emphasis on infrastructure facilities in the transport and communication, industry and energy sectors, as well as projects for agriculture, education and water supply. An increasing proportion of Bank loans-27 per cent of funds committed in 1987-88-finance imports in support of structural adjustment programs.

In April 1988 IBRD governors approved a resolution authorising a $US74.8 billion in general capital increase. Capital increases allow the Bank to expand its borrowings on world capital markets and it is these borrowings which largely finance the Bank's activities. The general capital increase will underpin the Bank's operations well into the 1990s and allow the Bank to carry through its programs aimed particularly at the most heavily indebted countries. In 1987-88 the Bank made lending commitments of $US14.8 billion. The general capital increase will allow it to increase its lending to more than $US20 billion per annum by 1992-93.

Under the general capital increase, Australia is entitled to subscribe to an additional 10,734 shares. The Bank does not require full subscription from members immediately and members have until 1993 to subscribe, if they so desire, to the total number of shares allocated to them. The Government has decided that Australia will subscribe to 7,880 shares at an estimated cost over the five years 1988-89-1992-93 of $A35.65m. This is a very small proportion of expected Australian aid expenditure over this period.

The Government has not decided whether Australia will subscribe to its remaining entitlement of 2,854 GCI shares or relinquish them for allocation to other members of the Bank. The Bank's projected higher lending levels are to be achieved progressively over a period of time, a gradual process which should be consistent with maintaining the quality of Bank lending.

Australia is a strong, but not uncritical, supporter of the IBRD. We are concerned that the Bank maintains the high quality of its lending and continues to be cost effective. Australia has criticised the Bank when appropriate with the aim of improving its overall efficiency. In particular, Australia has expressed concerns about the very fast rate of growth of large scale fast disbursing structural adjustment loans, the growing incidence of arrears on Bank loans, and the need to further enhance the Bank's work on environmental matters.

The Bank does have an important role to play in lending to support the adjustment process in developing countries. However, the Bank should not be lending to any country for long term structural adjustment purposes on the absence of a suitable framework of macroeconomic policies for that country. We must avoid a situation in which a country is able to obtain balance of payments financing from the Bank when it has not been able to agree an economic policy program with the International Monetary Fund. Clearly this would subvert the adjustment process.

Furthermore the Bank must encourage effective adjustment and not replace private debt with public debt. The commercial banks must play their full part in the adjustment process. It is essential for the Bank to maintain its preferred creditor status. Without this the confidence of financial markets in the Bank may be jeopardised with consequent adverse effects on the volume and terms of Bank lending.

The Bank needs to pursue poverty alleviation and environmental aspects of its work, but it cannot compensate for all the shortcomings which might exist in national policies affecting the environment, poverty or anything else for that matter. Key issues such as population growth, natural resources, land ownership and government expenditure are sensitive matters of national policy. The Bank can assist in these areas but cannot dictate solutions.

Australia gains substantial benefits from its contributions to the IBRD. Benefits from our aid, including political benefits, depend on developmental effectiveness. The World Bank group, including the IBRD and its soft loan arm, the International Development Association, have a comprehensive and systematic project evaluation system which shows that most IBRD and IDA projects-72 per cent of those evaluated in 1987, for instance-achieve all or most of their objectives. The estimated average return on projects evaluated in calendar years 1986 and 1987, measured by the flow of net economic benefits over time, was 14.5 per cent. These are good results bearing in mind the difficult environment in which the World Bank operates. Developing countries are particularly vulnerable to external shocks, their social and political environment is subject to rapid shifts and they are often short of critical expertise and skills.

Contributions to the IBRD allows us to participate in large development projects and widen the focus of our aid at a relatively low administrative cost. The World Bank group has an important catalytic role in tackling major international economic problems such as protection and debt. The Bank provides a significant forum in which Australian initiatives can be pursued.

Australia's membership of the IBRD also brings substantial commercial benefits. On a cumulative basis, Australia has received almost four times more for procurement by the IBRD than it has given in contributions to the IBRD. Australian cofinancing of IBRD projects can result in significant procurement benefits.

The benefits of IBRD membership have been recognised by Australian governments over the years since the Bank's establishment. The report of the Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program-the Jackson Committee-in 1984 recommended that support for development banks in general and for the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank in particular should be increased in relation to other multilateral funding.
I believe it to be in Australia's interest to continue its policy of support of the IBRD by taking up the 7,880 shares of the IBRD's general capital increase.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
