TALK.START.PARA: —This package of Bills-the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988, the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1988 and the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988-will be dealt with cognately, although they cover numerous matters concerning both income tax and sales tax. We in the Liberal and National parties will be proposing many amendments to these several Bills. We will be moving an amendment in relation to the second reading of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5), drawing the attention of the Senate and of the people of Australia to the fact that this Government is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia, that through the insidious effects of income tax bracket creep this Government has ripped off $7 billion extra from taxpayers each year since 1985-86, and that even though this new bracket creep has brought so much extra revenue into the coffers of the Government, the Government has gone about the business of raising new taxes by imposing, in this Bill, a tax on gold.

SPEECH.PARA: The gold tax will be the centrepiece of our debate tonight. We will be drawing attention to the fact that the Government has been totally misled in its action. We will show that the Government will lose revenue, rather than attract it, by imposing a tax on gold. Notwithstanding the approach we are led to believe the Government is engaged in, that is, of generally trying to lighten the burden on taxpayers, new taxes are continually being imposed. This follows the taxation package which was introduced some three years ago and which imposed taxes on capital gains, fringe benefits and other things.

The Bill as presently drafted amends the sales tax legislation so that it needs to be demonstrated to the Commissioner of Taxation that sales tax refunds given by wholesalers to their customers have been passed on to customers before the Commissioner of Taxation will grant the refunds. This is a nonsense measure. Had the Government chosen to pursue it, we would certainly have opposed it. We are pleased to see that the Government is amending the Bill so as not to include that stupidity. The Government was conned by the Australian Taxation Office on this point and totally misunderstood what it was doing. It has been persuaded by argument from members of the Liberal and National parties and other people in the community to withdraw it. We welcome that flexibility, if that is what it can be called.

Our amendment to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) will be handled by my colleague Senator Michael Baume in greater detail during his speech. However, I want to draw attention immediately to just one aspect of this Bill so that the Government is aware of what the Liberal and National parties intend in this respect. The origin of this Bill goes back to the Budget announcement on 23 August when the Government decided to impose a tax on all wrapping materials for any goods that were sold throughout Australia. However, as usual, the Government bungled the proposed legislation that it introduced on that very day, 23 August, as it omitted to cover certain situations. Later in November, the Government brought in another Bill to correct that technical defect, and that is the subject of this Bill. However, the Government has tried to impose this new technical amendment retrospectively to the date of the Budget announcement in August. That is totally unfair because the Government announced on 23 August that it would propose this tax on wrapping materials and then, on that very day, almost within minutes of the statement having been made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the House of Representatives, it introduced a Bill which spelt out the exact situation. Taxpayers were entitled to read the statement by the Treasurer in conjunction with the Bill introduced then and to decide that that Bill, although defective, would apply. For the Government to argue, some two or three months later, that a subsequent amendment, to implement what the Government had really intended earlier, should be backdated to the date of the original announcement is to impose legislation retrospectively. On that basis the Liberal and National parties will oppose it and we will move amendments to the Bill to ensure that it applies only from the date of the introduction of this Bill and not from the date of the original announcement of 23 August.

These things are, of course, just typical of the kinds of shortcomings to which the public do not generally have their attention drawn and which this Government continually tries to perpetrate. It continually tries to introduce retrospective legislation. It continually tries to legislate by press release. It is so out of touch. It continually tries to bring in new legislation and new taxes and yet tells us that it has not been responsible for the introduction of any new taxes since it came to power in 1983. Of course, that is totally untrue. It really hurts to go to functions and to hear the Treasurer of this country tell such outright lies when he says that no new taxes have been introduced by this Government since it came to power. Everybody knows that new taxes such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax have been introduced since it came to power. We know now that the subject of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) is a new tax on gold. I will come to that in a minute or two.

There are two or three other matters included in these Bills about which we have no complaint. Firstly, there is a rebate of tax on lump sum payments of certain types of income when paid in arrears. Secondly, up to $200 of discounts on shares or rights acquired by employees under certain employee share acquisition schemes will be excluded from income tax. I hasten to add that that concession fits exactly the Liberal and National parties' policy in relation to shares as applicable to employees; consequently, the Government has picked up the Opposition's suggestions in this regard. Thirdly, there will be some adjustment to the imputation provisions as they relate to certain dividends paid before 1 July 1989 by early balancing companies, that is, those that adopt a date of balancing other than 30 June, and transitional ranking credit rules for companies in receipt of those dividends.

One or two matters touch the changed arrangements as announced in May for the deduction of expenditure for the production of films, that deduction being reduced from 120 per cent of expenditure to 100 per cent. We will not be opposing that measure. There are some other minor amendments to the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act.

I turn now to the centrepiece of the Bill, which touches upon the question of gold. As we all know, up to now the proceeds of the sale of gold have generally been exempt from income tax. Dividends received by shareholders of companies that earn their profits from mining and selling gold are, of course, taxable in the hands of shareholders. Currently, that would be maintained under the new system. I will give a little background on this matter, because it is important to get the politics of it correct. As we all know, we had an election in the middle of 1987. It is interesting to recall the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), given in writing at that time. On 7 July 1987-just four days before the election on 11 July that year-he wrote to the Australian Goldmining Industry Council to indicate that there would be no gold tax introduced by this Government. Of course, that falls into line with all the promises made by the Hawke Government about taxes since it has come to power: we saw a promise that there would be no capital gains tax, no fringe benefits tax and no assets test on pensions. We saw this one wheeled out last time, four days before the election-there will be no gold tax. As soon as the election was over, out came the legislation for the gold tax to apply after 1991. By contrast, however, just before the election, on 26 June, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, said:

We are totally opposed to the introduction of a gold tax. As my colleague Senator Peter Durack, Shadow Minister for Trade and Resources, stated in June last year, a Liberal government would repeal any gold tax introduced by the Labor Government. A gold tax would jeopardise the future of many existing mines and prevent the opening of new ones. Exploration and the level of investment in this important sector would also decline rapidly.
We have a particular concern about the effect a gold tax would have on our balance of payments.
That is particularly true, even now. He went on:

Australia's level of overseas debt and the appalling deficit in our overseas trade account make it imperative that we encourage one of the main industries contributing positively to reducing the deficit.

That was the statement made by the Leader of the Opposition on behalf of the Liberal and National parties 18 months ago. It is quite clear that that is a statement of intent on the part of our parties and is clearly the reason for our opposition to this measure tonight.

On the other hand, the Government has shown absolute hypocrisy on this issue. We have heard statements from the Treasurer and also from the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, on 16 November 1986. That date was sufficiently removed from the expected election in 1987 as to be deniable by the Prime Minister later. When announcing this Government's decision to maintain the income tax exemption for goldmining, both of them said:

The Government has concluded that the importance of encouraging active exploration and development, and of maximising production and the consequent export income generated by the goldmining industry, outweighed the arguments in favour of removing the industry's long-standing exemption.
I have just quoted the Prime Minister's confirmation of that on 7 July 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to change that?

—What happened was that the Government had an election in July 1987. Of course, as soon as that election was wheeled off the stage, in came the new tax on gold. As I say, this is typical of the way that this Government behaves. The truth is that the Opposition supports the comments of those two Ministers and the Prime Minister, as they were stated before the election of last year. Our stance has not changed; it is the Government's stance that has changed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us see what has happened in the economy since that time. We are now in an even more precarious balance of payments and foreign debt situation than we were in July last year when the election was held. The current account deficit blow-out in the balance of payments for the first four months of this financial year is running well ahead of Budget expectations and causing considerable concern to the financial markets, resulting in higher interest rates and higher mortgage payments for first home owners. Just recently the Australian Bureau of Statistics released the gross foreign debt figures for the September quarter. This country now owes the rest of the world a staggering $120,000m. That is a fantastic sum which, of course, will have to be paid off by the generations of Australians still to come. Obviously, this tax will hurt that foreign debt situation even further by leading to a closure of marginal mining operations and other mines involved in gold operations. Clearly that will further exacerbate our position in regard to the balance of payments.

By bringing forward legislation now for the introduction of a gold tax in 1991, the Government is introducing a huge element of uncertainty, of unpredictability, into the goldmining industry. Of course, it will lead to distortions in the industry. Goldmining companies will substantially increase their operations before 1991 and cut back thereafter in order to take advantage of the exempt taxation system applicable up to that time. Quite clearly, the industry will suffer its great downturn once the tax comes into effect in 1991. Far from there not being any economic justification for continuing the exemption on gold taxes, there are very valid economic reasons to continue it. I am sure that that comes as a bit of a shock to the Government. I remind the Senate that gold has now risen to be the third largest export earner for Australia, only behind coal and wool. Gold has grown enormously as an export earner in the last several years to take that very prestigious position in terms of our overseas exports. Gold now represents approximately 6 per cent of our total merchandise exports.

What will be the effect of the new tax on the Government's revenue? We have to observe that it is wrong to suggest that the goldmining industry does not already pay some tax. It does pay tax. In fact, the only tax it does not pay is the tax on corporation earnings. It pays taxes on dividends, taxes arising out of goldmining profits and, of course, royalties and things of that kind. The gold tax is likely to lead to a net loss in tax revenue. In fact, a recent study by Ernst and Whinney Services Pty Ltd for the Australian Goldmining Industry Council has estimated that the Government is likely to lose some $443.6m as a result of the introduction of that tax. It is pointed out in that study that for every $1 gained by the Government from tax on goldmining profits, potentially in excess of $2 will be lost by way of direct taxes in other ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—Ernst and Whinney. The study further pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: An examination of the increase in the market capitalisation of the 51 major gold exploration and mining companies which comprise the Gold Index indicates that had the Government imposed a tax on gold mining profits from 1 March 1988, they would have derived current and future tax revenue from various sources of an estimated $363.3 million.

On the other hand, had the Government decided not to tax gold in that way, it would have derived current and future revenue estimated at $806.9m. That means a net loss resulting from the imposition of this new tax of $443.6m. Yet the Treasurer says that there are no economic justifications for continuing with the exemption from tax of the goldmining industry. There are simply no arguments in support of that statement other than his observation that the gold industry is the only industry which enjoys a blanket exemption from paying corporation tax-corporation tax only; it is not exempt from paying capital gains tax or tax on shareholders' dividends. This is correct, of course. The gold mining industry does have an exemption from corporation tax, but there are very good economic reasons, which we now come to, why the industry should be treated differently from other industries.

Gold is, of course, unique. It has a unique economic property and, consequently, should have unique economic considerations. The goldmining industry is also highly volatile and requires a very high level of capital expenditure compared with other industries. But if a corporation tax is applied to goldmining companies, that is going to reduce significantly the opportunity for and the capacity of goldminers to invest, because it takes funds out of the pool of money available for investment in increasing the size of the industry. It is a very high risk industry and a high cost industry, being located in the remotest areas of this continent. Consequently, it is a very difficult industry to operate. Returns are clearly uncertain and, like any export industry, it is very much dependent upon the wide fluctuations not only in the gold price itself but also in the exchange rate.

We have to observe-and now we come to the crunch-that the gold tax exemption has led to substantial employment investment and, of course, increases in exports. If we look at a few statistics to demonstrate this, I am sure this will be clear even to the Government. In 1984-85 the average level of employment in the goldmining industry was 4,184. This year, 1987-88, it is estimated that the total average employment is 7,500. In other words, there has been an increase of something like 75 per cent in employment in the goldmining industry in about four years. At the same time turnover has increased from $614m to nearly $2.4 billion. It has quadrupled in that period. Our export receipts have gone from about $550m-they have quadrupled also-to about $2,100m. That shows what has happened in this industry as a result of the exemption from tax of gold. In that time we have created jobs and brought people into the remote areas of Australia, we have created development, we have exported gold, we have created more wealth for all Australians, our export receipts have quadrupled and total turnovers have quadrupled. In 1980 we produced 18 tonnes of gold, in 1987 that figure increased to 110 tonnes and this year 127 tonnes of gold have been produced. The goldmining industry has jumped, as I mentioned earlier, from being Australia's tenth highest export earner just three years ago to being our third highest export earner. Its enormous contribution is being felt throughout the community and throughout the economy and is attacking at the very root some of the basic problems of our community.

Let me deal with some of the furphies that have emanated from desperate Ministers trying to justify a stupid decision. Senator Cook believes that because a number of new mines have opened since the May economic statement when this first arose the proposed gold tax is not having an adverse effect on the industry. That is misleading and untrue. Quite clearly, if there is a period of exemption applying until 1991, then people will be getting in for their chop in that period. It is after 1991 that the downturn in investment in new plant and mines will occur. So, as usual, Senator Cook is being misleading on behalf of the Government in trying to shore up a desperate argument in support of its case.

Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, is continually arguing that a tax exemption on the gold mining industry supports United States companies to the extent of 35 per cent which, he claims, are owned by them. He ignores totally the withholding tax that applies to dividends that are payable overseas, the benefit to the Australian joint ventures with American companies and the value of new jobs being created as a result of that investment. However, he preaches to us in here every day that it is better to have equity investment in this country rather than loan moneys. I have heard him argue it in Question Time several times in the last week or so, and yet when it comes to the crunch, when people are prepared to put their money into this country and invest in Australia's future, he says that they cannot do that, the Government will impose a tax to make sure that they do not come in-to Australia's detriment, not benefit. Quite clearly, what is happening here is that Australia is cutting off its nose to spite its face. That is what this policy is about and what this Government is about. It simply does not have any idea of a comprehensive policy in this area.

Overseas investment is the key to the future in terms of developing industries such as this. However, Senator Walsh is content to localise his remarks to the very narrow picture of some kind of accounting mentality and ignores entirely the economic benefits that flow from the kind of investment that would be generated. We have demonstrated that export earnings and job opportunities will grow if tax exemption remains. We have demonstrated that the Government's thinking is wrong; it is not going to gain extra money by imposing a tax on the gold mining industry. Through the continual growth of the industry there must be a further growth in the income of the industry, which will in turn generate further taxes by capital gains and through dividends. That is going to lead to further benefits to the community.

The Government claims that what it is doing is going to somehow benefit the Australian community; it is not. It is imposing a greater tax on all other taxpayers in the community. The Government will be collecting $540m less by this means than if the gold mining industry were left tax free. That means that that $450m will have to be found from other taxpayers' pockets. The Government, of course, is very adept at that. The Government knows how it is going to do it; it is going to do it through bracket creep, through more sales taxes on food, in the way that it has been applying sales taxes on food in recent times, and through things like wrapping and the tuck shop, in the way that it taxes muesli bars, chocolate bars and milkshakes. All of those items are the result of this kind of taxation measure, which totally ignores economic and taxation equity and efficiency.

The Liberal and National parties will be opposing those parts of the Bill which introduce the new gold tax when we come to the committee stage of the Bill. In relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) I now move:
At end of motion, add: `, but the Senate notes that:
(a) this is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) through the insidious effects of `bracket creep' an estimated $7 billion has been ripped off Australian taxpayers since 1985-86;

(c) despite the additional revenue gained through `bracket creep', the Government continues to attempt to raise more tax revenue by imposing new taxation on the gold mining industry despite a firm and unequivocal commitment by the Prime Minister prior to the last election not to do so; and
(d) the Keating/Hawke Government should be condemned for its indefensible action in breaking its pledge not to impose a tax on the gold mining industry.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation we are dealing with tonight covers a range of matters: the gold tax, about which we have heard a great deal from Senator Messner; a cut of something like 20 per cent to company tax; and some changes to the sales tax legislation in an attempt by the Government to get it right this time. Senator Messner finished on a note of criticism of the Government for introducing a plethora of legislative measures relating to the tax area with which the Opposition does not agree. I think it is worth while pointing out yet again that many of those measures would not have passed this place had it not been for the support given to them by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I was vastly amused, inasmuch as anybody could be amused by Mr Howard's document released at the weekend, to notice that the Australian newspaper, which covered that document in some detail, noted that among its education measures the Liberal Party is planning, if it ever gets into government, to repeal the tertiary tax. I remind the Senate that the tertiary tax has not yet become law, predominantly because we have not debated the legislation. It might be worth while the Liberal Party remembering that it would not have to worry about repealing the legislation when it gets back into government if it simply opposed it in the first place next week or the week after when it comes before the Senate.

I find it rather extraordinary to read in a newspaper today that an alternative government is planning on repealing a piece of legislation which it is planning on supporting in a couple of weeks. The reason it is planning on supporting this legislation, as it has supported so much anti-social government legislation, stems from the decision the Opposition took in 1983 to pass all of the Government's Budget legislation. In fact, Senator Chaney, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and would-be Prime Minister, I gather, wrote in July this year in the Parliamentarian the following:

It is important to note that since losing government in 1983, the Liberal Party, the main opposition party, has said it believes the government should be able to secure passage of its budgetary measures.
He went on to say:

The official opposition, that is, the Liberal and National Parties, have gone much further than the Democrats in restricting this voting opposition to financial measures. In all but extraordinary cases such as legislation imposing retrospective obligations, the opposition as a matter of principle allowed the passage of financial legislation.

In that article Senator Chaney mentions only as an extraordinary case the retrospectivity of a piece of legislation. Certainly those of us who were in this place during the debates on the bottom of the harbour schemes--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are saying it is not extraordinary when they promise to do something. I agree with that. I say it is not extraordinary. They never keep their promises.

—Those of us who were here at the time of the debates on the bottom of the harbour legislation will remember the flak that those of us who opposed the retrospective element of that legislation copped. Nevertheless, it is an acceptable principle that one does not impose a burden on anybody retrospectively, and that is something, I guess, that we can all live with. To argue that the gold tax is somehow an extraordinary circumstance, notwithstanding the interjection a minute ago from Senator Michael Baume that the Government promised not to introduce it, is simply quite silly. We ought in this place to be looking at legislation on its merits, whether it is a Budget Bill, a May economic statement Bill, or a piece of legislation that the Government said it would not introduce but did. I find it somewhat astonishing that Senator Michael Baume can perceive that element of the Government's actions as hypocritical when he does not seem to see anything even remotely odd about Mr Howard promising to repeal a piece of legislation that has not passed this chamber yet, but will because the Opposition will support it when it gets here. That sort of Alice in Wonderland stuff I think really is extraordinary, and something should be done about the Liberals' attitude in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: So I suggest that the Opposition is not opposing the gold tax legislation because of the Government's broken promise on the matter, although that may be a convenient hook on which to hang its opposition. The simple fact is that as a political party the Liberal Party has, with the Western Australian election coming up, been bought not for 30 pieces of silver but for a few lousy ounces of gold. That is the big temptation-the Western Australian election due in 1989. That temptation has led the Liberal Party to be sold, essentially, to those in the goldmining industry. An additional factor has been thrown up. It was recently announced that Elders Resources Ltd is now among the top 10 gold producers in Australia and I presume that the Federal President of the Liberal Party would take somewhat unkindly the support of the Opposition parties for this legislation.

We have before us in this package of Bills an attempt by the Government to correct an anomaly that has been outstanding for far too long; namely, that goldmining companies, of all companies, are exempt from tax. I find it extraordinary that anybody can justify an exemption from company tax to only one industry when that one industry is a mining industry that produces a luxury metal and, from the point of view of the Australian Democrats, desecrates large amounts of the environment in order to do so. Let us get one thing perfectly straight: this is not a gold tax in the sense that many people seem to think it is. It is the extension of normal company tax to the goldmining industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is dead right.
—Is Senator Walsh agreeing with the Democrats? That makes me worried.

—I do not know whether this makes Senator Walsh a fairy at the bottom of the garden as well. That is what he keeps calling us. Maybe the Minister has turned into Puck. In any event it is a simple fact that this is not an additional tax on gold; it is the removal of an exemption that has existed and has applied only to goldmining companies. It is rather ironic to hear the whingeing that comes from some Australian States because those States themselves--
—Especially Queensland.

—Especially Queensland. We could not expect anything else from Queensland. That sort of consistency is not something we would normally expect from that State. That fact of the matter is that Queensland, like all other States except Western Australia and Victoria, does apply State charges, royalties and so on on gold production. Some of them can be fairly hefty.

SPEECH.PARA: These imposts vary, of course. As I said, the goldmining industry is exempt from paying royalties in Western Australia and Victoria. In other States the royalties levied on gold range as follows: in New South Wales, 4 per cent of value of production; in Queensland, 2 per cent of gross proceeds in excess of $30,000 or 5 per cent of net profit above $30,000, whichever is the greater-they are getting a bit each way there; in South Australia it is 2.5 per cent of the value of production; in Tasmania there is a progressive royalty rate with an option for ad valorem or profit based royalties ranging from 2.5 per cent of revenue or 5 per cent of profits to 3.5 per cent of revenue or 7 per cent of profits; and in the Northern Territory 1.25 per cent of ex-mine value, 2.5 per cent of the same value in the case of Aboriginal land or reserves; and mines that commenced construction after 30 June 1982 are charged 18 per cent of profit before income tax. Those States that are bleating about the damage which is likely to be caused to employment and production in that area need to have a look at the amount they are raking into their own coffers before they start that little exercise. On the grounds that such an exemption is inequitable under any circumstances but particularly that it is inequitable in the area of goldmining, the Democrats will be supporting the legislation.

However, I would have to say that, ironically enough, we also find ourselves supporting the Opposition's attachment to the second reading motion on the grounds that we accept that the Government has reneged on a promise. The fact that the application of a company tax on goldmining has been Democrats' policy for a long time does not absolve the Government from its promise not to introduce it. Inasmuch as the Opposition's second reading attachment is a general bash around the ears of the Labor Government, we are happy enough to support it. But I would like to say to the Opposition parties that, if they feel that they can deny the Government this piece of budgetary legislation simply on the grounds that the Government promised not to do it, they should start thinking a little more closely about some other pieces of Government legislation that have been changed between proposal and implementation-and I include in that the tertiary tax legislation.

The Bills before us also give effect to the Government's May economic statement decision to encourage employee ownership of shares in the companies for which they work. Of course, the Democrats welcome this decision to move down a path that, I might add, we as a party have been advocating since 1977. We believe that employees who have a direct stake in the companies they work for will be inclined to be more productive. As I have said, we have been arguing about that for over 10 years and have put before this place private member's legislation to encourage just that sort of scheme. Our Bill would have gone further than this legislation; nevertheless, we believe that the Government has made a start in an area that has been overlooked for far too long. We applaud the Government for that and will be supporting it. We believe that businesses which give their employees a share in the enterprise and a say in its management should be given generous tax incentives. That is not the case here, but the amendment is at least a step in the right direction because it excludes from income tax up to $200 of discounts on shares acquired by employees.

The Government is also moving in the area of lump sum payments in arrears. The legislation finally moves to overcome an anomaly in the tax system about which I have made representations, and I presume other senators and members of the other place would have made representations to the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Clause 27 gives effect to the Government's decision to introduce a rebate for certain incomes received as a lump sum in arrears. Workers' and accident compensation payments, social security benefits and some salaries paid in arrears currently attract the highest marginal rate of tax because they are paid as a lump sum, notwithstanding how much the taxpayers would have paid had that money been paid out over the period they had been off work, for whatever reason. As a consequence, the highest marginal tax rate applies and they contribute in that year a much larger amount of tax than they would normally have done. If the payments had been received annually and taxed annually, a lower tax rate at the margins would have been applicable.

I have received a number of letters, one of which I will quote from briefly. On 30 September this year a South Australian resident wrote to me and said, among other things, that the income tax system was not working equitably in his case, for this reason: Until several years ago this man's wife had earned from full time employment approximately $27,000 per annum, on which her tax obligation averaged about 27 per cent. When through no fault of her own she sustained an industrial injury which progressively robbed her of her health and prevented her from being able to work full time, she ran into the first of the difficulties. Legal proceedings resulted in her employer reimbursing in a single lump sum the full time salary lost during the years in which she had been ill. The letter goes on:
The total amount of reimbursed back-pay was some $72,500 which together with other earnings for that year-
the year in which the employer finally paid her that lump sum-
came to about $87,000. Her tax obligation on this gross amount was calculated at an average rate of 47 per cent and came to about $39,000.

As he points out in that letter, had she not sustained the inquiry and continued to work full-time as before, she would have earned exactly the same amount of money, but because her income would have been spread over several years, the amount of tax payable would have been calculated at her usual average of 27 per cent. She would have paid about $23,500 instead of the $39,000 that she was taxed. She would have been $15,500 better off. When that arises it is clearly an inequitable system. Fortunately, the Government has finally taken this on board and, as a consequence, because of the amendments before us tonight, this will not happen again. The taxpayer will be able to get a rebate of the extra tax paid. In the future tax will be deducted from such lump sum payments in arrears at a rate of 25 1/4 per cent instead of at a higher marginal tax rate.

The fourth thing that this package of Bills seeks to do is amend the fringe benefits tax yet again. I do wish the Government had got it right the first time. It would certainly help this place. We then would not be confronted every five minutes with an amending Bill to an amending Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not be too bad if they got it right the second time either.

—Yes, we will be generous here and give the Government a couple of goes on very complicated matters. Certainly, the fringe benefits tax was complicated. Gentlemen, please get your act together in more ways than one so that--
—People, not gentlemen; men and women.
—I do beg your pardon, there is a lady in the advisers box, but I was really addressing Government senators-both of them in here tonight.
—The term `gentlemen' still doesn't apply.

—I take Senator Puplick's interjection on board, if for no other reason than to get it into Hansard. Let us go back to this question of getting it right. I hope that this time we have actually succeeded in doing that. This legislation removes, as from July 1986, the requirement for a crew member of an international flight to keep a travel diary so that the employer may reduce the taxable value of fringe benefit associated with overseas travel. While we are on the matter of not getting things right the first time, I understand that the Government is not planning on proceeding with clauses 45, 46 and 47 which I think is eminently sensible because I am blessed if I can see how that scheme would have worked. It tried to ensure that refunds of sales tax overpaid are available from the Australian Taxation Office to the wholesaler only if the consumer who ultimately bore the tax has been compensated for that. I am bothered if I can understand how the Tax Officer believes that the retailer can recoup from the customer that part of the price that was the sales tax overcharged in order for the retailer to not be penalising the customer and for the Tax Office to justify reimbursing the wholesaler. The whole thing is like a catherine wheel gone more beserk than most people anticipated. It would have finished up being a neat little revenue raiser for the Government without doing much for the consumer.

SPEECH.PARA: We then have some amendments to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) applying to wrappings, thick shake mixers and accessories to take-away food containers, such as spoons. This legislation is again before us because the Government did not get it right the first time. The sales tax changes were announced in the 1988-89 Budget. They were introduced on Budget night, 23 August, and passed in the Senate on 2 November. One would have thought that even that intervening period would have given those people who drafted it time to have a last look to ensure that all the i's were dotted and the t's were crossed, but no, the legislation was apparently defective and back it comes before us. I wonder just how many mistakes the Treasury will be allowed to make. I am not sure whether this is all because public servants are not being paid enough and they are all zipping off into the private sector where they discover these loopholes and encourage people to take advantage of them. In any event, it brings back a piece of legislation which was dealt with earlier.

I signal to the Government and the Opposition that I will be pursuing an amendment that I attempted to get through this chamber in early November. It is an amendment to the sales tax laws with regard to flavoured soya milk and to computers that have been adapted for use by disabled children. I remind Senator Messner in particular and the Opposition in general that in the debate on that amendment Senator Walsh said that the Government would wear the changes if it had to. I have not heard anything quite as definite from our generous, gentle Minister for Finance in a long time, indicating that if the Senate agreed to those changes, the Government would roll over and have its tummy tickled. Senator Messner should not be walking out of this chamber just when I am trying to convince him that somewhere down the track he has to think again about these amendments and do the decent thing by disabled children. Now he has gone. I hope he will read the Hansard tomorrow and consider the legitimacy--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair is interested in what you are saying, Senator. You might address the Chair.

—Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President; I am thrilled to know that. That is that element of the package dealt with. The final element of the package is, I think, the most extraordinary of the lot. It is the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill. The major purpose of this little exercise is to implement the May economic statement decision to reduce company tax from 49c in the dollar to 39c-to give companies a walloping 20 per cent reduction in tax. The Government is doing this at a time when it is arguing, first of all, that the economy, if it is not actually overheating now, may well be overheating, and when some Government members and certainly members of the business community are arguing that the economy cannot wear personal income tax cuts.

SPEECH.PARA: I also point out to the Senate that the Government is recommending a 20 per cent reduction in company tax this year whilst putting off cuts in personal income taxes, if they come at all, until next year, at a time when the average tax paid by the 200 largest companies in this country is 28c in the dollar, nowhere near the existing nominal rate of 49c in the dollar. This is also at a time when some companies are getting their tax liability down to zero-not a little bit under 49c in the dollar but the whole lot under 49c in the dollar. Alan Bond's company intends paying, and has anticipated that it will pay, nothing in tax next year. Mr Bond justifies this on the grounds that he pays tax to other countries-which is jolly generous of him but it is not doing a great deal for Australia-and that he pays rates and taxes in other areas. I remind Mr Bond, and anybody else who thinks that this is a reasonable excuse, that so do most ordinary pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers. All of us are confronted with taxes, rates and charges of one sort or another. The Government is not using this as justification for lowering the marginal tax rate or increasing the tax free threshold, nor is it allowing the same sort of tax deductibility for these items that once used to apply.

So some of the biggest companies in the country are currently paying very little tax. For years we watched Elders-IXL Ltd pay quite generous tax of about 10 1/2c in the dollar! Holmes a Court's company-Bell Resources Ltd-actually outdid it by about 50 per cent and contributed at the rate of 14c to 15c in the dollar.
