TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) which provides amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 and the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) 1930. The Bill contains 13 different and substantive changes to taxation laws. Although I wish to concentrate largely on the impact the proposals will have on the mining industry in Australia, I will briefly consider some of the other elements, which include employee share acquisition schemes, changes to the Australian film industry and tax imputation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer, firstly, to the employee share acquisition schemes. I commend the Government on its decision to actually take up Senator Chaney's proposal with respect to shares and rights acquired under the schemes for the acquisition of shares by employees. This particular amendment will have the effect of excluding from assessability up to $200 per year of discounts on shares or rights acquired by an employee under certain employee share acquisition schemes. In fact, I hope that this amendment will encourage more companies to issue shares and rights to employees. This is an important feature of the industrial democracy climate that is being advanced by both unions and employer groups at present. In fact, financial involvement of employees in a company means that the employees will gain a direct benefit from increased participation and the company as a whole will hopefully have a more interested and more motivated work force.

An essential element in the future and in the prosperity of Australian industry and the economy is the encouragement of a common purpose and mutual interest between employees and employers. I must point out that not all employee share acquisition schemes have proved beneficial to employees. I quote a noted celebrity case whereby employees were encouraged to participate in share acquisition schemes only to find that company being taken over by a so-called raider. There was a temporary rise in the price of shares of both operations. However, during the crash the raider's shares slumped, the person had to pay tax on the benefit at the date of takeover and he was left without funds to pay his tax and was substantially in debt. So it is not without its risks.

The next element I wish to look at concerns research and development. In fact, clause 12 of the proposed Bill will provide for certain research and development expenditure, incurred in advance for the provision of services, to be deductible over the period during which the services were provided. In order to maintain and improve the competitiveness of Australian industry it is necessary to actively encourage research and development. So no matter how tight economic conditions may appear government and industry must be committed to research and development. I think it is important that these particular incentives have a long term implication and not a short term political benefit. Without a strong and continuing technical research base, Australian industry will flounder and the economy will continue to slide down the ranks of the world economic scale.

Another change affects overseas travel fringe benefits. In fact, clause 6 of the Bill provides an example of just how little care the present Government took when formulating the fringe benefits tax. This amendment will remove the requirement for a crew member of an international flight to keep a travel diary and furnish it to his or her employer so that the employer may reduce the taxable value of a property or residual fringe benefit associated with that overseas travel. I point out that it is ridiculous that a situation of this kind should have arisen in the first place.

I now turn to the Australian film industry. The Australian film industry is one which I am sure all of us here are extremely proud of, for it displays a high degree of inspiration and originality in its works. This is despite the economic constraints it faces when compared with overseas film industries. As testimony to our industry's success, a number of Australian films have been amongst the highest grossing films for the year when released in the United States of America. This Bill will make amendments to section 10b of the Income Tax Assessment Act to reduce the rate of deduction for investment in Australian films from 120 per cent to 100 per cent. The proposed amendment will have the effect of reducing investment in the film industry. This is a highly disruptive and unjust treatment of the film industry as it amounts to an estimated loss of $90m over a four-year period commencing with the 1989-90 financial year. It is vital that the Australian film industry be encouraged and nurtured as it is of cultural and international significance because of its earnings and its ability to facilitate cultural exchange and interest in our nation.

I now turn to the Australian gold industry. During the 1980s Australian gold production rose from 17 tonnes in 1980 to 140 tonnes in 1988. It is predicted that in the financial year 1988-89 production will reach 170 tonnes. In effect, this is a tenfold increase in gold production over an eight-year period. Gold is already Australia's third largest export in dollar terms, being exceeded only by wool and coal. Australia has the potential to become the free world's second largest gold producer, after South Africa, within a decade. However, this depends on the maintenance of the current favourable conditions that have nurtured the present rate of growth.

This rapid expansion experienced over the last eight years is the direct result of a number of factors, not just taxation implications. These factors include new geological knowledge and exploration techniques; improved mining and metallurgical expertise; the depreciation, until recently, of the Australian dollar; a steady US gold price at reasonable levels; and, importantly, the tax status of gold. There is no doubt that the tax status of gold has played a major role in the renaissance of the Australian gold industry, and that has been further enhanced by the fortunate coincidence of other factors. It has been projected that if the status quo is maintained, Australian gold production will be above 150 tonnes per annum over the next decade-over 10 per cent of the free world gold production.

The introduction of the proposed amendment will lead to a downturn in the goldmining industry and associated industries and in the economy generally. It is not accurate to assert that the gold industry is tax free because tax revenue is obtained from two sources that are directly related to the gold industry. For example, tax is presently applied to gold through dividends and future capital gains. Any person who holds shares in gold pays full income tax on the dividends received from that investment. Therefore, gold industry profits are taxed in the hands of the shareholder where they are received by a resident individual. Profits that are retained, although not taxed in the period that they are earned, are reinvested to allow the purchase of new equipment, to finance research, and to permit exploration to take place. Without investment in these areas, the gold industry would not have experienced the exponential growth of the last few years. Let me repeat that gold is taxed.

The effects of the gold tax are many. I admit that the initial reaction to the introduction of the gold tax may appear to be favourable and to the country's benefit, but I point out that in the longer term the lasting results will be quite disastrous. In the short term the mines will tend towards removing high grade ore so that the bulk of the high grade ore reserves will have been removed before the tax actually becomes operational. The period from 1991 onwards to the end of the century will obviously see gold production reduced to a predictable level of less than 40 tonnes per year. The imposition of a gold tax will transform a rapidly growing new industry into a decaying one. There will be an immediate and dramatic reduction in the level of research and exploration for new gold deposits and future gold operations will be in jeopardy. This will have significant ramifications for the gold industry, related industries and the economy in general.

Let us look at the impact of a gold tax on exploration. It is important for us to examine this topic. A first consequence is that a gold tax will not result in increased exploration activity-quite the contrary; exploration activity will be reduced. A gold tax will effectively reduce the profit margin by half which is equivalent to a drop in the price of gold by one quarter. When profit margins start to fall, mining companies, like those in any other industry, exhibit economic rationality and start to cut non-essential costs. One of the first activities to be reduced or cut is exploration. The recent situation in the oil industry is a good example of this.

Mining companies explore in order to replace reserves, not to increase costs and reduce tax. The more limited the cash flow becomes, the greater the risk the companies face by devoting resources to exploration. It is important to actively encourage research and exploration for gold through the present tax system because the benefits also accrue to other areas of industry. Exploration for gold may lead to the discovery of large deposits of other valuable minerals or gems. Recently, a major diamond body was discovered and there may be other major deposits that have yet to be found.

In my State of Tasmania gold is no longer mined as a primary source but is produced as a by-product of copper mining operations at Mount Lyell and at the silver, lead and zinc mines on the west coast. However, there has recently been a considerable amount of exploration in some areas of the State with the suggestion that some groups are looking to commence mining for gold as a primary product in the foreseeable future. At least two of those mines will not proceed if this gold tax goes ahead. If this tax goes ahead I am sure that any new efforts to mine gold in Tasmania will cease. Let me refer briefly to the concept of high grading. With the level of high grading that will persist until the tax becomes effective, what sort of gold industry will remain to support a chronic balance of payments deficit?

This proposal will also have an effect on social security payments. It is likely that, as a result of the tax, many of the smaller producers will be forced out of the industry as it will no longer be viable for those mines to continue. This will have the direct result of increasing the level of social security payments in some of the more remote mining areas. Many small miners are not qualified for other forms of work. In addition, they are usually living in isolated areas where there are very few alternative job opportunities. I question whether these additional welfare costs will be less than the benefit derived from the new taxation system. There is also the inequity in that while the Government is introducing taxes on gold in relation to companies under other provisions for gold explorers, individuals will still retain their tax-free status. Here we have an anomaly between the taxing of prospectors in the gold mining industry and the taxing of incorporated companies in the same industry.

Let me turn now to the effect that that tax would have on our export revenue. I question whether the Government has really considered the loss of export revenue that will result from the tax and the impact that this will have on our balance of payments in the future. The main market for Australian gold at present is Hong Kong, although significant quantities are exported to West Germany, Japan and New Zealand. The gold tax will result in a reduced level of gold production. This will mean that there will be less gold available for sale on the export market, which means reduced export revenue.

It has been estimated that revenue from oil exports will be on the decline in the next couple of decades. It is therefore vitally important that Australia starts to consider alternative ways of deriving export revenue from other industry sectors. From this point of view it is very beneficial for Australia to have a large and healthy gold industry during the 1990s. The dramatic growth in the gold industry has meant that there have been more exports, more jobs, greater economic stimulus for Australia's manufacturing and service industries, and more revenue for the Government. Quite frankly, it would be folly to introduce a gold tax at this stage of the industry's growth. But apart from loss to government and loss to export earners, there would be loss to other support industries.

Besides all of the more obvious direct tax effects that a floundering gold industry would have, it is necessary to consider the other needs that such a tax would introduce. In fact, there are many towns that exist almost solely because of the gold reserves found in their areas. Take for example Kalgoorlie in Western Australia that was built around the eastern gold fields. Without extensive investment in gold towns, these will be severely reduced in future. This will mean that a lot of the superstructure needed to maintain these towns will be no longer needed. There are at present gold refineries in Perth, Kalgoorlie, Sydney and Port Kembla, which refine gold bullion to 99.9 per cent purity in bars of varying weight. Less gold extracted will mean less work for the refineries and a loss of economic efficiency for the industry generally.

I now wish to turn to dividend imputation because there are a number of amendments which provide for transitional imputation provisions from 1 January 1989. I would like to point out to the Senate a potential rort so far as dividend imputation is concerned that I believe the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) should be actively pursuing. Of late we have seen quite an increase in the number of companies issuing shares to their senior executives for perhaps a cent paid up. At the same time, they have gained the full advantage of overrated value in respect of dividends declared on those shares. This is a problem area that the Government should earnestly examine if it is concerned about stopping particularly new rorts in an area of so-called tax reform that it is so very proud of.

In conclusion: the Liberal Party does not support the amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which relate to the gold industry and its taxing. We believe that this would lead to a great reduction of that industry and have a deleterious impact on the economy of the nation. I strongly urge honourable senators to vote against this new tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak only briefly on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988, the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1988 and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 which are currently being debated cognately. I wish to address my remarks only to the proposed gold tax. I believe that Australians believe in a fair go for all. This is part and parcel of our Australian culture. Nobody likes paying taxes. Taxes can be palatable only if they are applied equally and fairly. People understandably get upset when they learn that someone such as Alan Bond, who has been paying a tax rate of only about 2 per cent for the last two years, will not be paying any tax at all for the next year. Western Australian people understandably also get upset when the Government uses public money to help the few, and especially the privileged few. The Australian Democrats believe that re-imposing a tax on gold will correct an anomaly. Business people who are not involved in gold and pay as you earn taxpayers believe that this will restore some equity to the taxation system. Certainly, small business is not given enough of a fair go. In my own State of Western Australia and in other States small businesses are going to the wall because of too many State and Federal taxes. The Government certainly should look to providing more incentives for small businesses, but this should be done on an equitable basis right across the board. The gold industry stands out as a privileged anomaly.

SPEECH.PARA: The exemption from gold tax first became law in 1924, when the goldmining industry had declined and was in the doldrums, suffering the after-effects of wartime regulation and from an officially determined price of gold which was low; and gold has been exempt from taxation since then. A number of reports in more recent years have advocated that the withdrawal of the tax exemption for the profits of goldmining companies should take place. Some of those reports were the Commonwealth Committee on Taxation report of 1950-52; the Coombs Task Force report of 1973; and the Industries Assistance Commission reports of 1975 and 1977. Later we had the report of the Gutman Inquiry into the Taxation of Gold Mining. The Gutman report states:
Today's situation is very different. Gold production has risen at an annual rate of about 25 per cent in the past five years and next year is expected to reach its highest level in 77 years.

The Gutman report, which was published in August 1986, in the main recommended the removal of the tax exemption and pointed out that a tax exemption did little to boost the goldmining industry for half a century, from the mid-1920s to the mid-1970s. This was a period when conditions were depressed and profits were low. As Senator Watson said, times have changed and the goldmining industry since the late 1970s has been on the rise. Senator Watson gave some of the reasons for that. One reason is the new techniques used in goldmining. Open-cut mining is used and goldmining companies are going back over land which had been depth mined previously. It is more profitable, with open cut mining, for companies to reach the seams with a lower yield.

Another report also advocates that gold should now be taxed as are other mining industries. I refer to a report by the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics on primary industry assistance in an economy-wide context. This was released as a discussion paper in April 1988. It found that the preferential treatment of the gold industry by income tax exemptions impeded the efficient allocation of resources to other industries within the mining sector.

As I said, the tax exemption was a necessary incentive in the past to maintain the viability of the industry in the face of diverse factors. If it is expected to be so now, we would expect other gold-producing countries also to have a blanket tax exemption of profits on their gold industries, but this is not the case. At present Australia is the only major gold producer in the Western world which has a blanket tax exemption of profits from goldmining.

It is estimated that at least 35 per cent of the goldmining industry is under foreign control. Profits attributable to this sector of the industry which are exempt from taxation in Australia have for some years been taxed by foreign governments. The withdrawal of the tax exemption will only benefit the Australian Treasury at the expense of foreign treasuries. At present, if companies which currently pay tax overseas because they are foreign companies have to pay tax in Australia, they will not have to pay tax overseas because of our arrangements with other countries of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. It will make very little difference to the larger companies which are overseas-controlled.

The advocates of the continuation of the tax exemption emphasise the disastrous consequences of the psychological impact of the withdrawal of the tax exemption on the goldmining industry after so long a period. However, in the past the industry and investors have adjusted remarkably well to the gradual withdrawal of tax-related concessions-such as the taxation of dividends since 1973 and the setting off of goldmining losses against other incomes since 1983-and new impositions such as the capital gains tax on the disposal of shares since 1985 and the fringe benefits tax since 1986. What is very interesting is that the goldmining industry has shown a remarkable ability, unlike others, to recover very well from the stock market crash of October 1987.

I suggest that there are anomalies in the industry and that it should be reviewed, but in conjunction with other mining areas and businesses. I quote from an article in the Weekend Australian of 19-20 November by Mr John Hyde, an ex-Liberal member of Parliament:
The arguments they-
that is, the Liberals-
are using are nonsense.
The valid arguments against direct taxation in general should not be applied selectively to gold and are ridiculous from the mouths of people who oppose broad-based indirect taxation.
He went on to say:

We can but assume that the Liberal MPs lack of concern for the efficiency of the microeconomy was in this instance deliberate. Economic efficiency was simply less important to them than a West Australian election which, because of the WA Inc. affair, the Liberal Party is already odds-on to win.
Is that what it is all about? He continued:
The Liberals' underlying weakness is lack of faith. When even the most talented people do not believe in what they are doing, they become a rabble.

I am not quite sure that people on my right do believe in what they are doing. I have visited goldmines over the last few months because of the proposed gold tax. I was amazed at the total devastation which is being caused by the goldmining industry. I refer briefly to the Boddington goldmine. The mine is situated in an eastern area of the jarrah forest in the south-west of Western Australia. The land there is totally devastated. Because of new mining techniques, a mining company can literally carve out a whole hillside with remarkable ease. I was amazed to discover that the Boddington goldmine is an enormous hole in the ground which now has alongside it an enormous mountain of dirt. Some 75 kilograms of gold will be obtained from that mountain. The landscape around Kalgoorlie is already like a moonscape. The people of Kalgoorlie have complained for years about the sulphur emissions from the roasters of the goldmines. At last the Environmental Protection Authority has set new guidelines which show that for years people have been exposed to more fumes than is safe. To hear some honourable senators on my right talking, one would think that the entrepreneurs in the goldmining industry are there out of the kindness of their hearts. I put it to the Senate that they are there for profits, and it is only fair that profits should be taxed equitably right across the board.

In the last few years a whole host of reports have shown that there is no need, in this day and age, to continue to have no gold tax, thus creating an unfair anomaly. There are certainly areas of unjust taxation and they should be looked at right across the board. No single industry should be given any advantage over another. That encourages rorts. There is no doubt that many companies are in the goldmining industry simply for that reason. I acknowledge that that is not the case with some small companies, but let their cases be looked at equitably with those of others in the mining industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confine my remarks on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988 to division 5 of the legislation, entitled `Transitional Provisions relating to Tax Concessions for Film Investment'. The purpose of this part of the legislation is to reduce the deductions for investment in qualifying Australian films from 120 per cent to 100 per cent and to remove the exemption from tax for income from such investments. This reduction was announced this year in the May statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and applies to expenditure under contracts entered into on or after 25 May 1988. This Bill also contains transitional provisions to preserve temporarily the higher rates of deduction for films substantially in production or underwritten before 25 May 1988, provided certain conditions are met. The Government says the estimated cost of the proposed amendment is $90m over a four-year period, commencing with the 1989-90 financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: The area of the Income Tax Assessment Act which is being amended is what is generally referred to in the film industry as division 10ba. If one looks at the actual wording of clause 39 of the legislation, one sees that the amendment is being made to section 124zafa of the Act. The fact that the tax Act contains a section 124zafa indicates the unreal and unrealistic complexity of the taxation legislation of this country at the moment.

The history of division 10ba of the Income Tax Assessment Act is very interesting. This provision dates back to the 1980-81 period when, under the previous coalition Government, with the active support of Prime Minister Fraser and the then Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon. Bob Ellicott, film concessions were provided for the first time on the basis of a 150 per cent tax concession for the original investment and a 50 per cent concession on the income earned from qualifying films. That 150 : 50 formula persisted for quite some time. Under successive governments, primarily under the tutelage of Mr Keating, that formula has been whittled down, having moved from 150 : 50 to 133 : 33-that is to say, a 133 per cent concession and a 33 per cent concession on income-then from 133 : 33 to 120 : 20, the situation pertaining before the May statement; and now to a situation of 100 per cent and no concession on the taxation regime applicable to the income from qualifying films.

In the early part of 1988 the Hawke Labor Government was told that there was a major crisis in the Australian film industry. It was told by a large number of people that the film industry was facing virtual collapse in Australia. It was told, for example, that the number of feature films in production by about February 1988 was zero. Whereas in the previous year 64 projects were in progress, by the time that we got to the beginning of 1988 and looked at the prospects for 1988-89 there were no films on the drawing board for that period. This was directly, as was pointed out in an article by John Stapleton in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 February 1988, `because of the Federal Government's inability to decide on a proper method of funding'. That comment was made by Mr Chris Noonan of the Australian Screen Directors Association and it was absolutely correct. We know, for example, the very great importance in an economic sense of the Australian film industry. Apart from Crocodile Dundee, which earned at least $100m last year, Australian films in 1986-87 generated something like $50m worth of foreign sales. The film industry continues to be one of the most important industries as far as creative endeavour in Australia is concerned. It is important not just as a creative industry; it is also important in terms of the cultural life of this country, in terms of the projection of the Australian image and ethos overseas and in terms of the employment it generates, not just directly for film-makers, but for actors, technicians, scriptwriters and people in the processing laboratories, the distribution network and elsewhere.

Throughout the whole of the first quarter of last year this Government was told time and time again that there was a crisis in the Australian film industry. The Government resolutely refused to address the problem. In February even the former Minister for the Arts, the honourable member for Robertson, Mr Barry Cohen, was warning in the House of Representatives that the Australian film industry was in crisis and that absolutely nothing was being done by the Government in response. Film-makers came to Canberra during February. A delegation came to attempt to put the case to the Government for urgent action to be taken. The Government continued to procrastinate. On 18 February, in response to the delegation, the then Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Gary Punch, put out a press statement in which he admitted that there had been a major decline in the Australian film industry. He said:

The level of fund raising for film and television drama is expected to drop from $140m last financial year to between $30m and $40m in 1987-88. This decline is attributed to reductions in income tax rates which have made the tax concessions available for investment in film less attractive to investors.

That was the attempt of the then Minister to say that the decline had occurred because marginal income tax rates were being pushed downwards by this Government; that was why people were not investing in the film industry. That was a disingenuous attempt to cover up the fact that the primary reason for uncertainty in investment in the film industry was the Government's procrastination and its refusal to address the question of the maintenance or reduction of direct financial support through division 10ba of the tax Act. On 18 February, speaking on the PM program, Mr Punch had this to say when being asked about why there had been a major drop in investment in the film industry:
We always knew there'd be a problem with 10ba, with the reduction of marginal rates of tax. I don't think anyone on the Government side thought it would be this severe.

If nobody on the Government side thought it would be that severe, that arose only because the Government was not listening. The Government had been told consistently in the latter part of 1987 and in the early part of 1988 that the film industry was facing a crisis and that the difficulty was likely to persist. It persisted throughout the next couple of months. An article by Kathryn Bice which appeared in the Australian Financial Review on 26 April 1988 made the point that only $47.09m had been secured for nine feature films, four mini-series and one telemovie under division 10ba tax concessions, which was the principal financing mechanism behind the industry renaissance during the 1980s. On 25 May, in the May economic statement, the Government made an announcement that there would be a new method of funding Australian films. This was eventually to emerge as the Australian Film Finance Corporation. The Treasurer said in his May statement:
. . . an Australian film finance corporation will be established as a wholly-owned Commonwealth company to fund qualifying Australian film and television productions:
The corporation will be authorised to make subordinated or ordinary equity investments in film projects with a minimum overall private sector participation of 30 per cent . . .

As I shall have cause to discuss in a few moments, that statement by the Treasurer has led to some very considerable degree of confusion. Nobody is quite sure what is meant by the phrase `a minimum overall private sector participation of 30 per cent'. They are simply not sure whether that means a participation in each funded project of at least 30 per cent or an overall private sector participation in the whole film financing scheme throughout the course of any one financial year of at least 30 per cent.

We were in no way enlightened by the press release put out by the former Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, on 25 May-the same day. He said that the Corporation would be provided with some $70m and that `the private sector is expected to increase its stake in the industry'. Again there were no figures and we received no guidance. A hotline was established in the Department of the Arts and Territories and people were supposed to ring and ask the officers on the end of that hotline what the meaning of this new film tax concession arrangement was. I actually rang the following day to ask the officers whose telephone number was given in the press release what it meant. They had absolutely no idea what the whole thing meant. We have not been enlightened by the Government at any stage since. What we have had is the propaganda apologists for the Labor Party trying to justify all this.

An article appeared in the 9 June edition of the film industry magazine Encore quoting the then Minister, Mr Punch, as praising the scheme. In the Minister's words, the scheme is `a much solider commitment'-presumably the honourable gentleman meant `more solid'-`than anything else in the May mini-Budget'. With the greatest of respect, if that commitment was more solid than anything else in the May statement one shudders at just how solid anything in the May statement actually was. The article went on to say that this represented `a great coup for the junior Minister'. I was even more suspicious of this article when I saw that it was written by the then editor of Encore magazine, a commentator by the name of Irina Dunn, who now graces this chamber in a somewhat different capacity. Ms Dunn, as she then was-as the lawyers say-regarded all of this as a great coup for the Minister. We will see how much of a great coup that actually turns out to be.

As I said, the Treasurer's May statement about that 30 per cent participation was the source of a great deal of confusion. That confusion has been replicated by a number of comments that have been made on the film finance arrangement. For instance, Kathryn Bice in an article in the Australian Financial Review of 25 November 1988 said:

To apply for corporation funds, a producer will have to secure private sector participation worth at least 30 per cent of a project's budget. The corporation may then choose to invest in or make a loan to the project provided the details of the loan pass muster.

That is what one might think was the purport of the Minister's statement. It is not so. I pursued that matter at some length in the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee D on 11 October 1988. We had as a witness Mr Blunn, the Secretary to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I asked Mr Blunn whether it was necessary for every single project to attract 30 per cent of private sector investment. I also asked Mr Blunn whether it would be possible that the investment would not need to be anywhere around the 30 per cent figure. On page D130 of the Estimates Committee Hansard for that date I said:

I was going to pick a figure of 90 per cent, actually, not 100 per cent. It could be decided that there was a compelling national interest or significance that a film, in fact, would fall below the 15 per cent, but the figure would be at the discretion of the board, somewhere between 99 and whatever.
Mr Blunn replied:

It would not necessarily be at the discretion of the board. We are in fact discussing at the moment the possibility of there being an involvement of the Minister, where those provisions would be applied, but that is not finally settled.

In other words, Mr Blunn was quite happy to admit that in fact the Film Finance Corporation could pick any figure in which it would permit private sector investment to be below 30 per cent. While Mr Blunn indicates that a general rule of thumb might be 15 per cent he also makes it quite clear that in the national interest it could be decided that the Corporation would put in 90 per cent or 95 per cent of the cost of the project.

I then asked whether, with the $70m allocated under this scheme, the Corporation could end up putting out $70m in the first couple of months of the year and that those projects which got in first would get the largest amount of funding. I asked whether, at the end of the year when there was virtually no money left in the kitty and somebody came along with a very worthy project, the Corporation would have to say, `Sorry, we would like to fund your film but in fact we don't have any money left'. I took issue with Mr Blunn and with Ms Santamaria from the Department about that. I asked whether people could be told, `There is no money in the kitty for the project this financial year but go ahead and make the film and we will give you the funding in the next financial year'. The Corporation would not be able to enter into any contractual arrangement but on a sort of wink, wink, nod, nod basis it would be able to encourage people to make films on the basis that money would be provided next year. In fact, both Mr Blunn and Ms Santamaria made it clear that that in fact is a perfectly correct interpretation of the way in which the Corporation could go about its business. Therefore, there is a considerable amount of difficulty in planning within the industry. For example, I said to Mr Blunn regarding the operations of the Corporation:

They are not in a position of saying to somebody, `We think that is a great project; we will put $5m into it. We do not have the $5m at the moment, but we will have the $5m in three months. Therefore, we give you a commitment that you will have the $5m, but you will not have it until we have it, three months down the track'.
Mr Blunn replied:
I imagine that that could happen.

In other words, the whole confusion which continues to attend financing in the film industry has not been resolved by this new scheme provided for by division 5 of the Bill before us this evening. The annual report of the Australian Film Commission for 1988 makes the point equally clear when it states:

Private sector participation in the FFC's production portfolio will be critical to achieve the production target of $120m. In its first year the FFC will be expected to secure an overall private sector level of participation of 30 per cent in its portfolio.

To achieve this level of private participation and in acknowledgment of the highly speculative character of film and television production, the FFC may subordinate its equity participation and extend a preferred position on returns to the private sector participants. Participants will be drawn from such sources as financial institutions, underwriters, venture capital investors, television networks and distributors. The degree of subordination of the FFC's equity will depend on negotiations on a case-by-case basis and the commercial circumstances of each project.

In other words, we do not have any clear indication of how the Film Finance Corporation will operate. The film industry remains in a state of crisis as a result of this confusion and lack of guidelines. Mr David Court, who helped develop the Film Finance Corporation model, was specifically commissioned by the Australian Film Commission to prepare a paper on future funding options for the film industry. On 24 October this year he was reported as criticising the Film Finance Corporation, firstly, because its establishment had been delayed and, as a result, he said, was unlikely to be able to provide funds for more than one Australian film by Christmas, that is to say, six months after its starting date. In fact he criticised the whole thing as looking simply like a revamped operation of the Australian Film Commission, whose record in this area has been the subject of some degree of criticism. Mr Court's views, which are among the most informed in the industry, ought to be taken very seriously.

Let me, for example, draw attention to one particular problem that has already arisen. According to the Budget, the Film Finance Corporation is to be funded to the tune of $70m in this first year. The Federal Government is at the moment being pressured by the French and German governments to provide $17m towards a $29m science fiction film called Till the End of the World. The maker of this film is a distinguished film maker, Mr Wim Wenders. He in fact has quite an established track record in Europe for making films. We know, for example, that problems arose with the certification of this film as to whether it had enough Australian equity and Australian artistic content. That was a point of dispute: the Film Commission did not believe that it had sufficient Australian participation in the actual making of the film. Mr Wenders is known for a large number of films, including the very distinguished film called Paris Texas, which showed in Australia some years ago.

We know that the French and German governments have made representations to the Australian Government. It is believed that the West German Chancellor, Dr Kohl, made direct representations to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We know that Senator Richardson got a letter from the French Minister for the Arts, who glories in the name of Mr Jack Lang and who wrote to Senator Richardson to draw his attention to the fact that there was a possible `long-lasting negative effect on the development of film cooperation with your country, to which I personally attach great importance', and that that would be a consequence of this film not proceeding with an adequate level of public support from the Australian end. Here we have the prospect of $17m of the scarce $70m being diverted for that purpose.

I am equally concerned about the fact that, once again in the best film bureaucracy tradition, the Film Finance Corporation has decided to find itself quite reasonable headquarters. It has not gone to some down-market establishment; it will have one of the most spectacular addresses in the whole of Australia. It is to have premises at No. 1 Pacific Highway for which it is to pay, according to the answer that I was provided with in the report of Senate Estimates Committee D, at least $213,942 by way of gross annual rental. One would have thought that a fairly struggling organisation, trying to look after a fairly struggling group of Australian film makers, could have found a place that would not have cost the best part of a quarter of million dollars a year in gross rent. But undoubtedly the difficulty of making these decisions will be accommodated only if one can have the sorts of views one is likely to get from No. 1 Pacific Highway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that include the fit-out?

—No, that is just gross rental, Senator. We do not know what sorts of orange boxes members of the Film Finance Corporation are going to be sitting on during their operations. Lastly, I wish to express my very great concern about the board and the people appointed to the board of the Australian Film Finance Corporation. The Chairman is to be Kim Williams, a person whose support for the Australian Labor Party has been public and unerring. It is to have as its part-time directors a number of people, including Mr William Gurry, Dr Patricia Edgar, Mr Jack Thompson, and Mr Anthony Hartnell, a former Labor adviser and a partner in a firm of solicitors who are also the solicitors for the Australian Film Commission. It is also to have on the board Mr Kenneth Allen, Mr James Spigelman- a name well-known in both media and Australian Labor Party circles-Miss Gabrielle Kelly, and Mr Christopher Lovell, whose experience in the film industry may be extensive but one suspects that the fact that he is a partner in a firm called Holding Redlich and Co. may be purely coincidental.

SPEECH.PARA: There will be problems of a conflict of interest in terms of who asks whom for money. Mr Williams, the Chairman, is the chief executive of a company formerly known as Taft Hardie Pty Ltd, now known as Southern Star Pty Ltd, in which role he is apparently responsible for the production activities of McElroy and McElroy, Sullivan/Oliver Productions and another as yet unnamed production entity. Mr Jack Thompson has recently announced that he is forming a film financing and production company called Pan Australian Films in association with a number of Sydney lawyers. Dr Edgar, for whom I have a great deal of respect, heads the Australian Children's Television Foundation, which one would expect to be a major applicant to the corporation for film funding.

I, therefore, say that I am not impressed with the extent to which the board has been overloaded with people whose responsibilities are considerable and whose qualifications appear to be just as much directed towards their active support, membership or participation in the activities of the Australian Labor Party as those of the film industry. There are on the board of the Film Finance Corporation no producers of films. There is a splattering of merchant bankers, financiers and lawyers, but the board is singularly defective in terms of people who actually produce and make films. I am extremely disappointed with the way that the board has been constituted. I do not believe that that augurs well for the operations of the board.

As I have said, the Film Finance Corporation and its guidelines and operations are still shot through with an enormous degree of uncertainty. One does not know from any government statement or from any information that can be gathered from Ministers, from departments or Estimates committees, what the rule about 30 per cent private sector participation is. One does not know whether that is on a project by project basis or on a global basis. It appears to be on a global basis. That will inevitably lead to a situation in the early part of a financial year where films will be financed with a figure lower than 30 per cent of private sector investment. In other words, the corporation will put in a greater amount than 70 per cent. As a result of that, we will have a situation at the end of a financial year where private sector investment will have to be a great deal higher because there will not be money available within the $70m allocated for that year. It will mean that those who get into the system early will do better than those who come at the end of the financial year. We will have that silly scrambling for money in the film industry that was one of the worst features of the old 10ba production operations. The guidelines are not there in a coherent fashion to allow people to make planning an effective tool within the financing of Australian films in the years to come.

I believe that the Film Finance Corporation model will fail. It will be a betrayal of the Australian film industry. The difficulties that the industry has suffered during the early part of this year will continue to be replicated. Far from proving to be the saviour and friends of the ailing film industry, this Government and this model, introduced as a result of division 5 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988, will be a nail in the coffin of the Australian film industry and will be to the eternal shame of the Australian Labor Party.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Antarctica-Euphemisms in Language-Mr Peter Ross-Trade Union Training Authority

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. Under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much attention has been focused in this chamber over the last two weeks on a part of the world that normally receives very little attention from politicians-namely, the Antarctic. The reason for this attention has been the tabling by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, of the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities. This convention is the result of essentially secret negotiations which began in 1981. It replaces the voluntary moratorium on mining which has been in place since 1977. If ratified, the convention will facilitate the exploitation of mineral deposits in the Antarctic. The convention was opened for signature for one year from 25 November 1988; from 25 November 1989 it will be open for ratification. Sixteen of the 20 nations involved in the negotiations must sign to ratify the agreement. The 16 signatories must include the seven claimant states and both superpowers. If one of the claimant states or either of the superpowers refuses to sign, the convention will not become operative.

SPEECH.PARA: In tabling this document, Senator Evans drew attention to Australia's primary objectives in the Antarctic. He summarised these as being: to maintain the Antarctic region free from strategic and political confrontation; to preserve Australia's sovereignty over the Australian Antarctic Territory; to protect the Antarctic environment; to take advantage of the special opportunities Antarctica offers for scientific research; to be informed about and able to influence developments in a region geographically proximate to Australia; and to derive possible economic benefits from the living and non-living resources of the AAT. Yet we need to question whether this convention, the most recent to be negotiated by the Antarctic Treaty nations, will be in either Australia's interests or the interests of the Antarctic continent itself. It will, if it comes into force, change the nature of the continent and Australia's place in it forever.

Most of us think of the Antarctic as a vast icy wilderness, the scene of heroic exploits and great explorations. This continent, which covers 10 per cent of the world's surface, is the coldest and driest place on earth. It is a harsh and dangerous environment given to unpredictable and extreme changes in temperature; to winds of more than 250 kilometres an hour which arise without warning; and to pack ice strong enough to crush the hull of an ice strengthened vessel in minutes.

Senator Evans drew attention to the need to maintain the political and strategic stability of the Antarctic region as well as Australia's position as a claimant state. We should consider, therefore, the nature of that stability. The Antarctic Treaty was negotiated in 1959 as a result of United States initiatives. This arose from concerns about geopolitical tensions that were generated by competing sovereignty claims in the area and by a desire that was engendered by Cold War rivalries to prevent a dominant Soviet influence in the Antarctic. The Treaty, which came into force finally in June 1961, established the Antarctic as a zone of peace. The Treaty emphasised that the continent should be used only for peaceful purposes and that it should not become the scene or object of international discord. Military activities are prohibited under the Treaty, as are nuclear explosions and the disposal of radioactive materials there. The Treaty thus established the world's first nuclear free zone.

Seven states lay claim to part of the Antarctic. Australia's claim of 42 per cent is the largest. Others claiming sovereignty over the continent are New Zealand, the United Kingdom, France, Chile, Argentina and Norway. The claims of Chile, Argentina and Britain overlap and have in the past been a source of conflict. A further 15 per cent of the continent is unclaimed. The United States and the Soviet Union maintain a basis of claim; that is, they maintain the right to lodge a claim at some time in the future.

The nature of these seven claims is complicated by the fact that they are not mutually recognised in international law by all other Treaty states or by non-signatories. Australia's claim, for example, is recognised only by New Zealand and Britain of the signatories. In turn, Australia acknowledges the legitimacy of the United Kingdom and New Zealand claims. However, the Treaty, in article 4, puts all claims on ice, so to speak, so that all parties, whether claimant states or not, are able to maintain their position regarding those claims and therefore avoid open conflict. The Antarctic Treaty system has thus become an excellent example of international cooperation.

Twelve nations signed the Treaty in 1959. There are now 41 signatories. Twenty-two of them have decision making or consultative party status. Those parties include both superpowers and representatives of both Eastern and Western blocs, as well as of the Third World. However, the political stability that has characterised the Antarctic continent and which Senator Evans identifies as being so important to Australia will be threatened if the minerals convention comes into force. The Minister has stated that the convention was negotiated precisely in order to protect the tradition of peaceful cooperation in the Antarctic. Yet the moves towards commercial competition for resources, and especially for strategic resources, between privately owned mining companies will threaten this political stability. It is likely, moreover, that conflicts over sovereignty will arise once more, especially where those claims overlap. The resulting instability could well adversely affect neighbouring countries such as Australia. Exploitation of resources could exacerbate tensions between rich and poor nations as the former retain control over the region's resources. Australia's control over the AAT will be weakened if this convention comes into force. The pro-mining nations have already shown their strength in the negotiations for the convention. Australia's efforts to have an anti-subsidy clause written into the convention were not successful largely because of the pressure of the pro-mining nations. Should mining be permitted to go ahead, Australia would have little control over the activities of non-Australian companies mining in the AAT and would derive little benefit from such activity. In the absence of an anti-subsidy clause Australian resource industries could find themselves having to compete on the world market with subsidised ventures in the Antarctic. There would be nothing to constrain unfair economic practices in the form of a subsidy, and the way would be open for operators to commence prospecting in the Antarctic without the requirement of commercial viability.

The Minister has also drawn attention to the need to protect the Antarctic's unique and fragile environment. This vast continent is the world's last great continental wilderness. It plays a crucial role in the generation of stable global weather patterns and it provides a pure baseline zone for monitoring global pollution. Yet the Antarctic environment has already been threatened by a hole in the ozone layer which has probably been caused by human activities. The Antarctic ecosystem is susceptible to irreversible damage because of the simplicity of the food chain. There is little room for adaptation to change. Lichens and mosses that grow on the 2 per cent of the continent that is ice free can take hundreds of years to grow to the size of a 20c piece yet can be destroyed in a few short seconds by a careless footstep.

The Antarctic environment has already suffered from human intervention in terms of the both overexploitation of marine resources-the seals, the krill, the whales and the fish stock-and the disruption of the ecological systems. The great whales are already near extinction and exploitation of krill could threaten the food source of marine mammals and thus their very existence. The bird life has to compete with human beings for the very small amount of ice free land. It has already been shown that the presence of humans has interfered with the nesting activities of the penguins in that the penguins do not tend their eggs while human beings are present. The rubbish from the scientific bases, including foodstuffs that are thrown out, machinery, metal storage drums and old tyres, has spread disease amongst the wildlife, and construction activity has already damaged the penguin rookeries.

The Treaty, and especially the conventions negotiated by the Treaty nations, is intended to protect the environment, not destroy it. The issues of environmental protection and resource conservation have been at the forefront of the debate in the consultative meetings. A brief perusal of the reports of the consultative meetings will show that the recommendations on the impact of human activities on the environment, on the flora and fauna, on pelagic sealing, and on marine living resources, especially in the protected areas, have been a prime concern. For example, the 1964 Agreed Measures for the Conservation of Antarctic Flora and Fauna, the 1972 Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals and the 1980 Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources have had one thing in common: they have focused on questions of conservation and protection of resources and the environment. Unfortunately they have not always been as successful in practice as their clauses would have us believe or, indeed, as environmental organisations hoped they would be. Nevertheless, they do show that these clauses have been environmentally motivated.

Not so this recent convention. It breaks with that tradition in that it is an exploitative convention. If signed and ratified it will put into place guidelines that allow exploration and exploitation of minerals in the Antarctic and the Southern Ocean. Protection for the environment is given scant attention. There is no provision for unlimited liability, while limited liability provisions are to be negotiated under a separate protocol. Indeed, even in the face of limited liability, one might ask: to whom could liability be directed for the destruction of the unique environment? I believe that the conservation organisations' fear is one that is justified. If the Antarctic is to be opened to mining the environment could certainly be irreversibly damaged. There is an obligation under the convention to clean up the damaging effects of mining but there are still no specific details for the rehabilitation of the environment. Yet how can such a fragile and susceptible environment ever be returned to its original state? We have only to look around us at mining in Australia to see how even a sturdy environment has suffered.

What sort of damage could be done to the Antarctic environment? The scraping of the ice caps along the caps of the exploratory wells could result in the uncontrolled release and spillage of many gallons of oil. A single drop of oil takes months to be broken down in the Antarctic environment. It is also of concern that an operator would not be liable, under the convention, for damage caused by an event that constituted a natural disaster that could not reasonably have been foreseen. In the Antarctic it is very difficult to predict unforeseen damage to the environment as a result of the weather.

It is true that the nature and extent of mineral deposits in the Antarctic are not yet fully known. Some say that there is virtually an eldorado to be exploited. Others say that the technological and natural barriers to removing minerals are so great that mining, if it occurs at all, will not happen until the next century. Offshore petroleum extraction is widely regarded as the form of exploitation which is most likely to occur first in the Antarctic. Deposits of offshore minerals have also been found, especially coal, uranium, copper and gold. The size of such deposits is not known and the difficulties of extracting commercially viable quantities are likely to be insurmountable, given present technological expertise. But technology changes rapidly and this may not always be the case. Exploitation of offshore hydrocarbons poses special problems. The impact of these activities could be felt far from their specific locations. For example, a major oil spill could be carried right around the continent with the prevailing Southern Ocean currents.

There are no adequate cleaning up techniques for removing oil from pack ice. Antarctic bird life and sea life would be vulnerable to such a spill, especially during the breeding season. Local pollution could produce changes in the sea ice which could have a significant effect on both large scale atmospheric circulation and local biological productivity. Small scale tourist activity is already having a detrimental effect. The massive logistical support required for minerals activity would only compound this problem.

The Minister has indicated that the aim of the negotiations was not to encourage minerals activity but that they proceeded on the basis that the continent would remain closed to minerals exploitation unless a specific decision were taken to open it up. Yet once the convention is in force the strength of the pro-mining nations-the United States of America, the United Kingdom, France, West Germany and Japan-is likely to prevail in the commission to be established by the convention. The pressure of those states, combined with the lack of an anti-subsidy clause, could well result in initial prospecting as soon as the convention is signed.

The Minister identified Australia's objectives as also being to take advantage of the special opportunities for scientific research. The Antarctic Treaty reinforced the work done in the 1958-59 International Geophysical Year by establishing the Antarctic as a continent for science to encourage international scientific cooperation and provide for the free exchange of the results of that scientific research. It is on the basis of scientific research that a signatory state may become a decision-making party within the treaty system.

Yet the nature of scientific venture in the Antarctic will change if the minerals convention comes into force. There will be a refocusing of research towards exploitation technology and away from the wide range of scientific research currently being carried out. Furthermore, the results of such work would become the sole property of the operators and sponsoring states under the confidentiality of data provisions. Thus five nations could effectively lock up the scientific research resources of the continent. In a number of respects, therefore, Australia's interests and principal objectives will be undermined by this convention.

For the convention to come into effect Australia, as a claimant state, would have to sign. If Australia does not sign, the convention will not become operational. It has been asked: what difference would signing or not signing the convention make? If there are such problems associated with exploiting resources is it likely that there will be a rush for resources? To this I would have to say that once a set of regulatory guidelines is in place, especially without an anti-subsidy clause, the likelihood of companies beginning exploratory prospecting is very high indeed. Furthermore, it is unlikely that Australia would be able to resist pressure from pro-mining nations to open up areas for mining. Others have suggested that, if the resources are there and exploitable, mining companies will go there regardless of the existence of regulations, in which case, that argument continues, would it not be better that there was a convention? However, the voluntary restraint policy that has been in effect has worked well and could continue to do so, especially if strengthened and given some kind of formal status.

If there is no convention in place, mining companies would be unable to secure insurance to cover their activities there. The international political situation is also likely to continue to act as a constraint on such activities. The Antarctic Treaty requires signatories to exert efforts to ensure that no-one engages in any activity in the Antarctic contrary to the principles or purposes of the Treaty. With a moratorium still in place mining would be unlikely. Furthermore, those nations which oppose mining would regard any such action as a unilateral breach of the Treaty and that would doubtless lead to conflict. Given any internal weakness in the treaty system, the challenges to the Treaty which have been mounted by Malaysia and other countries in the United Nations would be likely to gain more credibility. None of the Antarctic consultative parties especially would wish to draw attention to such internal divisions or to encourage moves to have the control of the continent taken out of their hands and lodged with the United Nations.

What are the alternatives? Surely it is time for the implementation of a conservation strategy to ensure that Australia's interests and particularly its environmental responsibilities in the Australian Antarctic Territory are protected in perpetuity. Such a strategy should be promoted within the Antarctic Treaty system as a whole. This wild and pristine environment should be protected and maintained in the interests of all humankind, rather than being available only to those who are able to exploit it. There is no reason why such a strategy should alter the nature of Australia's sovereignty claim or its interests or objectives in the continent. On the contrary, this would provide Australia with a unique opportunity to lead the world in global environmental protection.
