SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the Senate's attention to the matter of euphemisms in language which are frequently used to cloak reality. I draw upon the work of Miss Carol Cohn who wrote a paper entitled, `Sex and Death in the Rational World of Defense Intellectuals'. She published this paper from the Centre for Psychological Studies in the Nuclear Age of the Harvard Medical School. In 1984 Miss Cohn attended a summer school in Washington on nuclear weapons, nuclear strategic doctrine and a variety of associated subjects taught by defence intellectuals. Her studies continued long after the summer of 1984, however, because she found herself quite morbidly fascinated by what she discovered, particularly in this matter of language being used as a smokescreen for reality. She said that the defence intellectuals were mostly men who used the concept of deterrence to explain why it is safe to have weapons of a kind and number it is not safe to use.

SPEECH.PARA: I will quote a little bit from her paper because I think it is important to get this right. I do not want to be accused of exaggerating the points she has made. These are civilians who move in and out of government, working sometimes as administrative officials or consultants, sometimes at universities and think tanks. They formulate what they call `rational systems' for dealing with the problems created by nuclear weapons: how to manage the arms race, how to deter the use of nuclear weapons, and how to fight a nuclear war if deterrents fail. It is their calculations that are used to explain the necessity of having nuclear destructive capability of what George Kennan has called `levels of such grotesque dimensions as to defy rational understanding'. At the same time, it is their reasoning that is used to explain why it is not safe to live without nuclear weapons. In short, they create the theory that informs and legitimates American nuclear strategic practice.

When we look at the particular language used to discuss missile systems, we see that Miss Cohn became so hooked into the system which she saw operating that she coined a new word. She called this specialised language `techno-strategic'. She said:

I have come to believe that this language both reflects and shapes the nature of the American nuclear strategic project, that it plays a central role in allowing defense intellectuals to think and act as they do, and that feminists who are concerned about nuclear weaponry and nuclear war must give careful attention to the language we choose-whom it allows us to communicate with and what it allows us to think as well as say.

This is the all-pervasive nature of the situation in which Miss Cohn found herself. The language reflects the thinking and that is where some of the danger lies in legitimising and accepting that nuclear deterrence is a reasonable position for any human being to hold. She talked about the world of these defence intellectuals being somewhat bizarre; bizarre because it is a world where men spend their days calmly and matter-of-factly discussing nuclear weapons, nuclear strategy and nuclear war. The discussions are carefully and intricately reasoned, occurring seemingly without any sense of horror, urgency, or moral outrage. In fact, there seems to be no graphic reality behind the words as they speak of `first strikes', `counterforce exchanges' and `limited nuclear war', or as they debate the comparative values of a `minimum deterrent posture' versus a `nuclear war-fighting capability'. She said that this extraordinary language was used to legitimise the whole concept of nuclear war and preparations for nuclear war. She said it was an elaborate use of abstraction and euphemism, of words so bland that they never forced the speaker or enabled the listener to touch the realities of nuclear holocaust that lay behind the words. She said:

Anyone who has seen pictures of Hiroshima burn victims or tried to imagine the pain of hundreds of glass shards blasted into flesh may find it perverse beyond imagination to hear a class of nuclear devices matter-of-factly referred to as ``clean bombs''. ``Clean bombs'' are nuclear devices that are largely fusion rather than fission and that therefore release a higher quantity of energy, not as radiation, but as blast, as destructive explosive power.

``Clean bombs'' may provide the perfect metaphor for the language of defence analysts and arms controllers. This language has enormous destructive power, but without emotional fallout, without the emotional fallout that would result if it were clear one was talking about plans for mass murder, mangled bodies and unspeakable human suffering. Defense analysts talk about ``countervalue attacks'' rather than about incinerating cities. Human death, in nuclear parlance, is most often referred to as ``collateral damage''; for, as one defence analyst said wryly, ``The Air Force doesn't target people, it targets shoe factories''.

Some phrases carry this cleaning-up to the point of inverting meaning. The MX missile will carry ten warheads, each with the explosure power of 300- 475 kilotonnes of TNT: one missile the bearer of destruction approximately . . . 400 times that of the Hiroshima bombing.

Ronald Reagan called the MX the `peace keeper', which totally denies the destructive power of that weapon. A nuclear submarine was perversely called `Corpus Christi', the body of Christ. I find it hard to believe that such is the nature of euphemism in the defence planning community. Miss Cohn further states:
Feminists have often suggested that an important aspect of the arms race is phallic worship, that ``missile envy'' is a significant motivating force in the nuclear build-up.

Opposition senators may well laugh. They should listen further; they will be rolling in their seats in just a moment. I advise them to take this seriously because it reflects the underlying thought patterns that pervade the minds of the people who sit and plan the use of nuclear weapons. Carol Cohn said:

I have always found this an uncomfortably reductionist explanation and hoped that my research at the Centre would yield a more complex analysis. But still, I was curious about the extent to which I might find a sexual subtext in the defense professionals' discourse. I was not prepared for what I found.

I am quoting here verbatim because, as I said, it is important that I am not accused of exaggerating. There are the words of a person who sat and listened to these people and who made a detailed critique of what they said. She states:

I think I had naively imagined myself as a feminist spy in the house of death-that I would need to sneak around and eavesdrop on what men said in unguarded moments, using all my subtlety and cunning to unearth whatever sexual imagery might be underneath how they thought and spoke. I had naively believed that these men, at least in public, would appear to be aware of feminist critiques. If they had not changed their language, I thought that at least at some point in a long talk about ``penetration aids,'' someone would suddenly look up, slightly embarrassed to be caught in such blatant confirmation of feminist analyses of What's Going On Here.13

Of course, I was wrong. There was no evidence that any feminist critiques had ever reached the ears, much less the minds, of these men. American military dependence on nuclear weapons was explained as ``irresistible, because you get more bang for the buck.'' Another lecturer solemnly and scientifically announced `to disarm is to get rid of all your stuff.'' (This may, in turn, explain why they see serious talk of nuclear disarmament as perfectly resistible, not to mention foolish. If disarmament is emasculation, how could any real man even consider it?) A professor's explanation of why the MX missile is to be placed in the silos of the newest Minuteman missiles, instead of replacing the older, less accurate ones, was ``because they're in the nicest hole-you're not going to take the nicest missile you have and put it in a crummy hole.'' Other lectures were filled with discussion of vertical erector launchers, thrust-to-weight ratios, soft lay downs, deep penetration, and the comparative advantages of protracted versus spasm attacks-or what one military adviser to the National Security Council has called ``releasing 70 to 80 per cent of our megatonnage in one orgasmic whump.'' There was serious concern about the need to harden our missiles and the need to ``face it, the Russians are a little harder than we are.'' Disbelieving glances would occasionally pass between me and my one ally in the summer program, another woman, but no-one else seemed to notice.

There is a lot more. If honourable senators are interested in getting a copy of this paper I will be pleased to provide it to them. Miss Cohn went on to detail bizarre experiences she had while involved with this defence course, like being invited to pat a missile, usually a sign of affection as one pats loved ones like children or dogs: pat a weapon with fondness and, presto, its lethality disappears. There is another section headed `Fathers, sons, and virgins', another on male birth and creation, another on God and the nuclear priesthood, with lots examples of language being used as a shield against reality. Miss Cohn's analysis of the power of euphemism, to put it mildly, where life-destroying weapons are concerned is worrying, because those of us who want to challenge the military planners' thinking to a certain extent have to use their language in order to understand where they are coming from and to have any credibility in the eyes of our adversaries.

In case honourable senators think that this is all absolutely far-fetched and removed from our backwater here in Australia-removed from the planning of megadeaths; thankfully that is so-I draw their attention to an article in, I think, the Canberra Times at the weekend entitled `Sleazing on with the Cordies of Legoland'. The translation is: life with the officer cadets at the Australian Defence Force Academy (ADF). There is actually a dictionary of Lego lingo. It can be found in both the Australian National Library and the Defence Academy Library. Tony Wright, in this very interesting article in a weekend newspaper, said:
It is probably fair to say that it would be the most vulgar dictionary in any library in the land.

It is a language created by a tightly-bound sub-culture of young men who see themselves as separate and possibly superior to those in the outside world. They are driven by urges common to most groups of young men-urges sharpened by the tough discipline of the academy to the point that much of the language revolves in the sphere of escapist fantasy.
He went on to say:

Those whose sensibilities are tender should probably not read on, because Lego Lingo is not for the faint-hearted. For a start, it is sexist, profane and racist in the extreme. Indeed, the language appears to display enormous contempt for both women and Asians, among others.

I will not quote the puerile language used by the Cordies of Legoland, but I wanted to draw attention to this subculture. We learn a great deal about their outlook on life from the language used by the Cordies of Legoland. I think that the Lego lingo dictionaries are a fair warning that racism and sexism are alive and well in the ADF Academy, which I think is regrettable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently the Senate has witnessed a remarkable and regrettable series of allegations against individuals by members of the Opposition which are pushing the bounds of simple decency. Typically, people against whom such allegations are made are helpless to defend their good names publicly. So I seek to redress one of these miserable attacks against a constituent of mine, Peter Ross, of the Fitzroy River region in the Kimberley, Western Australia. The pattern is familiar: a set of circumstances is identified, a senator-in this case Senator Crichton-Browne-leaps to the worst possible conclusions and, on the basis of his own hostility towards certain communities and people, proceeds to attempt to destroy a reputation in a wholly unprincipled way.

SPEECH.PARA: Peter Ross is not an Aboriginal, but is married to one and is a close ally and supporter of the people of a number of groups in the Fitzroy area. Senator Crichton-Browne quotes auditors' reports and other reports and deduces a litany of misappropriations. In the course of his diatribe, Mr Ross becomes a `thug' and worse. This is unforgivable calumny of a good, generous man, most of whose life and much of whose resources have been devoted to enhancing the quality of life and dignity of his black friends and relatives to whom, incidentally, Senator Crichton-Browne refers as if they were half-witted incompetents. Nothing could be further from the truth.

There may be technical deficiencies in accounting procedures amongst some of these remote and isolated communities in the Kimberley and elsewhere. On the whole, they are managing their book-keeping remarkably well. One of the great satisfactions of the last few years has been to see young Aborigines acquiring accounting and computing skills and becoming very competent in the way in which their funds are being administered. Of course, every responsible parliamentarian insists upon proper accountability and I am no exception. However, one needs to travel the region with humility and compassion to comprehend just how devastating has been the effect of Europeanisation upon the traditional owners of the land. Consider the naked contempt and hostility repeatedly shown not only towards the Aborigines but also towards those who work with them. Let us not forget, or forgive, the role of the Liberal Party of Western Australia in such episodes as Noonkanbah and Turkey Creek, and the appalling abuse of electoral law, not to mention morality, exposed by the Court of Disputed Returns not so many years ago. Perhaps the Junjuwa, Kalumburu, Balgo and Wangkatjunka books are not meticulously kept. They should be-I am not defending any lack of competence there. However, internecine rivalries in the area are not unknown. Many of the assertions made suggest considerable ill feeling, which is hardly a basis for such wide-ranging accusations.

This I do know: Peter Ross has put far more into the well-being and development of the Fitzroy communities than he could ever have taken out of them. His history is that of a guide, counsellor and mentor; a rough, tough and forthright champion of the Aboriginal right to dignity and self-determination; a down-to-earth, practical person who resolves problems as they arise, in the harsh and beautiful Fitzroy region, with the wisdom of his decades of experience.

I wish to quote from a recent article by Jerry Pratley in the West Australian. I am not asking the Senate to take my word for this, though I happen to know Mr Ross and people who have worked closely with him for many, many years. The article stated:
Mr Ross-
when made aware of the accusations-
. . . said that he was so well respected by the Aboriginal community that he was the only white man in the Kimberly allowed to take part in circumcision rites.
He had worked to overcome alcohol and juvenile problems in the town, had fostered 18 Aboriginal children through his own home and helped find good jobs for each of them.
A Fitzroy Crossing police officer who did not wish to be named said he `could not say a detrimental word' about Mr Ross.
`He takes juveniles, young fellows that are running off the rails, into his house all the time and straightens them out,' he said.
`He's a good man, a real good-hearted man. We think he's a bloody good bloke and he doesn't tell lies.
`He's always running around taking them (Aborigines) out to the communities because he knows that if they stay in town they get on the drink.
`He'll drive 300 kilometres to take a load out to one of the communities then be back 10 minutes and there will be another mob that need taking the other direction.'

I greatly deplore the tendency which has arisen here to get into Hansard, and often on the air, allegations which in many cases are very wide of the mark and sometimes quite unsubstantiated, but which leave the individual with very little in the way of redress. I am glad to have this opportunity of putting on the record my feelings about Mr Ross and his contributions to Aboriginal communities.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to deal with the Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA), an organisation which has just lost $1 1/2m. I have not seen in the media any announcement that it has lost $1 1/2m. Perhaps it is not the sort of announcement that this Government seeks to make, but behind the annual report of this organisation there is some kind of financial disaster which I think the Government owes it to us to explain.

This organisation has set out on a massive expansion program at the same time as the Government is cutting its funds. I notice that under section 8 of the Trade Union Training Authority Act the Authority must comply with any directions given by the Minister for Industrial Relations. The report says that the Minister gave no such directions to the Authority this year. Apparently, it set out on a massive expansion program without having received any Government instruction to do so, resulting, as I said, in a loss of $1.5m compared with a profit of $103,000 in the previous year.

As with the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, by reading the annual report one would not know that. One has to read in detail the accounts at the end of the report before one finds out what is really going on with this extraordinary organisation. The report is full of excitement and expansion and positive comments. The year produced, it says, a very substantial growth in the volume of training carried out. It says that the number of student training days increased to 60,462-a growth of 20 per cent over the previous year. It says that the number of participants attending courses increased by 33 per cent.

This great concentration on expansion and the positive things that are happening is all very well, except that it does not tell anything like the full story. TUTA says that it is further extending the development of individual courses relating to individual enterprises, with the appointment of a number of national industry training officers who will liaise with unions at a national level to develop more closely coordinated industry-based programs at the colleges and centres.

What concerns me in particular is, firstly, why TUTA is doing all the things that it is doing and, secondly, why it has lost so much money. Certainly there are large question marks over many of the things TUTA does. For example, the report says, regarding the provision of information kits, that materials in the report Australia Reconstructed `have been prepared both in the form of kits to assist training staff and as handout material for course participants'. I remind the Senate that Australia Reconstructed is a discredited Australian Council of Trade Unions document full of absolute nonsense-which this Government, for example, has basically ignored and rejected-about what the ACTU sees as some kind of approach for Australia. The Trade Union Training Authority is apparently so under the control of the ACTU-which is funded, of course, by Australian taxpayers-that it trots out this line.

It is of some concern that most of the people attending TUTA courses are public servants. Public sector attendances totalled 54 per cent of those who attended TUTA courses last year. That raises the serious question of who pays for these public servants while they are attending these courses. Of course, it is the good old Australian taxpayer. I wonder what sort of hidden or additional costs exist, because that particular cost does not appear in the report here. However, the report does say that it regrets that the Australian Government has cut its grant. It says:
It is a matter of grave concern to the Australian Council therefore that cuts in TUTA's allocation have been enforced for 1988-89.

They did not take place in the year covered by this report when it lost $1.5m. The cuts are for 1988-89. The consequences of that are very clear: either TUTA has to find other ways of making a large amount of money or there has to be a massive reduction in its activities. It would be interesting if the Government would come clean and say what is going to happen. It is interesting that the Council sees an immediate need to increase the number of people trained to 30,000 a year which, I must say, involves a considerable increase in the number of people being trained at present. Perhaps the Government and TUTA can come clean and tell us how they are going to achieve that.

On the question of coming clean I really want to look at TUTA's accounts. After the loss of $1.5m its fixed assets-its non-current assets-are no longer covered by its capital accumulation. In other words, it has had to borrow money which is now invested in its buildings, plant and equipment and so on, which is a reversal from the previous situation. There have been massive increases in many of the costs involved. For example, expenses have gone up from $8m to $9m, although its revenue has fallen from $8.8m to only $8m. The taxpayers of Australia who fund this Authority have every reason to request a decent sort of explanation. Why, for example, did TUTA have investments of $1m anyway? What were these investments? These investments, by the way, have been sold. TUTA has had to call on $447,000 of cash in hand to cover its $1.5m loss. What were these investments and why was there a loss on their disposal? These are questions that someone in TUTA or in this Government-if they care-might be prepared to let us know the answers to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is it that we get these reports only after Estimates committees' proceedings have concluded?

—Absolutely! As Senator Puplick says, it is remarkable that a report such as this, which is clearly misleading and which leaves an enormous number of questions unanswered, comes out only after we have dealt with the appropriations for the Department of Employment, Education and Training. In fact we dealt with them last Thursday. It is a disgrace that on the next sitting day after we dealt with this matter this report was tabled.
—Buried in the 33 papers that were tabled.

—As Senator Puplick said, it was buried in the 33 papers. It is also disheartening to see that, while the Trade Union Training Authority put out this pap, Australia Reconstructed, as part of its training kits, these publications were put out at a loss of $50,000. Perhaps people were reluctant to buy that sort of garbage. That might explain why it has suffered that kind of loss.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many other matters to be raised. I am wondering why, for example, debts outstanding for more than three months have doubled during the year. I am wondering whether TUTA should not apply the same success that it has to running its bar account to its other activities. In fact, it managed to make a profit of $5,879 on its bar trading which tended slightly to offset the $1.5m loss on its total activity. Unlike the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, TUTA appears to know how to run that end of the business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Drink more and print less and they will do well.

—That is an appropriate comment from Senator Puplick. The other thing that I think is well worth noting is that in the Senate Estimates committee hearing I did in fact ask some questions about TUTA, about the extraordinary manner in which it keeps changing the location of the office of the National Director. When this organisation started, I think back in the Whitlam years, its headquarters, and those of its director, were in Wodonga. I have to say that under the Fraser Government that then changed to Canberra. Under the present Government it moved to Sydney, and it has now been moved to Melbourne. I am wondering when Perth, Adelaide and Brisbane will get a look in as the headquarters of TUTA. Every time that organisation moves it costs squillions of dollars. At the Estimates Committee hearing I asked why on earth this move took place. I was assured that there were sound economic reasons that involved efficiencies and cost savings of some substance. I then asked for an indication of those. The reponse stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Melbourne premises of the new national office are larger than the Sydney offices of the National Director.
I suppose they should be because the national office encompasses quite a few other things. The reply continued:
The Melbourne Office now incorporates the national administrative function previously located at Wodonga-
I might say that the Clyde Cameron College still remains at Wodonga, so the central training operation is now removed altogether from the administration-
and in addition provides a base for a group of national industry training staff.

All this was at a cost to TUTA in 1987 of approximately $20,000 per year less than the cost of the Sydney premises of the National Director alone. This was seen as a compelling economic justification of the decision to locate in Melbourne. The departmental officer then goes on about the operational point of view and so on and how important it was for the office to be nearer the Department and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, presumably to get its political instructions from both the Minister and the ACTU. What was not said in the response appeared in footnote No. 17 to TUTA's accounts where it was revealed:
. . . several staff were retrenched-
because of these moves; because of restructuring-
during the period . . . This involved total expenses of $333,019 and included payment for accumulated entitlements plus amounts totalling $193,493 pursuant to a redundancy package . . .

Is that not extraordinary! That amount of $333,000 is that cost which is glossed over and does not appear in the reply given to me about the economic benefits of moving. That was the cost of making that move and of making those amalgamations and stream- lining the operation. I can only hope that this extraordinary rapidity of moving offices ceases because, quite frankly, it seems to be taking far more money overall than this organisation appears to be able to make, even out of its bar trading.

I now want to refer to the fact that this organisation has also been in breach of a requirement that it must obtain ministerial approval prior to entering into contracts involving payments of amounts exceeding $100,000. The Attorney-General's Department this year has advised TUTA that this provision should be interpreted to include contracts involving investments of funds. I do not know why it should not have in the past. However, in the light of this the Authority has been advised that the provisions of paragraph 47 (a), which require this kind of approval, were breached during 1987-88 on a number of occasions. I do not know what the consequences of those breaches were. But it is worth noting that the proceeds of disposal of non-current assets, presumably the assets which involved breaches of this requirement, involved a loss of $24,000. I think in the circumstances, having made a loss, having breached the requirement of the guidelines, there is an obligation on this organisation to explain what on earth it has done and why it has done it.

There are many other matters of major concern in this report which I will not respond to tonight, except to say that it is clear that TUTA is facing a financial crisis. It cannot continue at the same rate of loss because it does not have any more investments to dispose of to cover a loss of $1.5m. It does seem that the Government has an obligation to say firstly to TUTA itself, and secondly to the taxpayer, who has been funding this organisation at enormous cost each year, just what on earth is going on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight in the light of comments made by Senator Giles, who vigorously sought to defend one Peter Ross, whom I had cause to refer to some little time ago in respect of the finances of the Aboriginal communities in the Kimberleys. I thank her for bringing to my attention the newspaper to which she referred. Whilst I would not bother to refer it to the Committee of Privileges I see that Mr Ross, in response to my comments, was reported in the paper as having said, `I will bare knuckle the bastard one handed'-intimidating stuff. That frankly sums up the point that I made. I understand that is typical of Mr Ross's conduct and that is the type of conduct that Senator Giles is seeking to defend. It is symptomatic of the complaints I have had about Mr Ross by a number of Aborigines in the north west, not the least being young people, who are mindful of the fact that he happens to be for the moment, for better or worse, a justice of the peace (JP), and who have been threatened by him to the effect that because he is a JP he will deal with them in his own way. On separate occasions he has threatened them physically.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it clear to Senator Giles, who does not seem to have the facts at her fingertips, that I was not making allegations about Mr Peter Ross; I was referring to documents, not the least being an audited report to members of the Wangkatjungka Community Inc., and it was that impartial auditor who claimed in his statements that Mr Ross had misappropriated funds, that he had taken food for his own benefit and booked it to the community, that he had flown at least twice to Derby by charter and booked it to the community, that he had taken 34 cartons of beer and booked it to the community and that he had booked up items of equipment for his own home and charged them to the community.

It was the auditor, and not I, who referred to the fact that the gross profit of the store was 8 per cent during the period when Mr Ross was a project officer, and drew the conclusion that goods were being paid for but not received, stolen from the store, or not correctly paid for and the moneys banked. That was the proposition put to us by the auditor. The auditor made the point, and not I, that when Mr Ross was in charge of the community the level of consumption of diesel fuel went up in the cooler months, when the air-conditioners were not being used, and decreased in the hotter months when the air-conditioners would have been used. It was the auditor, and not I, who claimed that Mr Ross was paying Mr Alan Lawford as the powerhouse operator during March, April and May, when Mr Lawford was not a resident at Wangkatjungka. It was the auditor, and not I, who made the point that a separate person, the primary school teacher at Christmas Creek, was being paid by Mr Ross for doing the actual work.

It is the records of the Association that show that Mr Ross drew $7,355 in his own name and in his own handwriting on Wangkatjungka cheques, for his own personal loans. It is the records that show that Mr Ross returned no more than $800. The records of the community show that a further $12,192.20 was drawn in cheques in Mr Ross's handwriting, for which there is no satisfactory explanation. There are certainly no receipts, no invoices, and no benefits for the community. It is the records-and not I-that show that on six occasions there was overpayment in wages. On one occasion it was $40, on another occasion $180, on another $180, on another $40, on another $180, and on another $500. The significance of that is that the wages are paid to illiterate Aboriginals in cash and the cheques are drawn and cashed by Mr Peter Ross. I draw no conclusions as to where the difference went or who got the difference of the overpayments, but that is what the records show; it is not my claim. That was under Mr Ross's responsibility.

The complaints about Mr Ross's conduct do not come from me. The first comes from the Chairman of the Kimberley Land Council, writing to Mr Clyde Holding, who was then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. He says:

Concern has been expressed to us by various Aboriginal communities in relation to Mr Peter Ross, Project Officer Junjuwah community. We have been informed that on a number of occasions he has accompanied mining companies on visits to other communities in an advisory capacity to the mining companies. He has also visited communities advising them not to have dealings with the Kimberley Land Council. We do not consider that these activities would fall within the normal duties and responsibilities of a project officer.
The significance of Mr Peter Ross acting as an agent for the mining companies is that he was getting paid for it. To continue:
It is our understanding that Project Officers are funded to assist communities in mechanical and practical day to day tasks.
I would have thought that that was a fair definition of duties. To continue:

We are concerned that Mr Ross is using his position in Junjuwah community and that he is maintaining his position by unacceptable practices. We feel that the community may need assistance from your Department to deal with a situation which is detrimental to the interests of the community. The Kimberley Land Council is concerned that all Project Officer positions be reviewed regularly by DAA, and representatives of other Aboriginal organisations, particularly where reports of improper conduct have been alleged.
We require urgent action to investigate Mr Ross's conduct and interference in the affairs of other communities.

That is pretty straightforward from the Chairman of the Kimberley Land Council, who, I would have thought, would have had the best interests of the Aboriginal community at heart and would have been inextricably and intrinsically tied to the Aboriginal community in the Kimberleys.

TALK.START.PARA: —He does not send his copies to Senator Giles.
—No, he does not. I will not press the matter for the moment, but it is a pretty sorry response they got from the Minister and not one that satisfied the Kimberley Land Council.

SPEECH.PARA: The other correspondence I will raise tonight is that to Mr Clyde Holding, former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, from the Chairman of Marra Worra Worra, Fitzroy Crossing:
Re: Project Officer's Position-Wangkatjungka Community-Xmas Ck

An extremely serious situation exists at Xmas Cr whereby the outgoing Project Officer from the Junjuwa community, Fitzroy Crossing, has been lobbying intensively-with another community's resources-for the Xmas Cr job . . . In the course of this lobbying, Aboriginal organisations and resource personnel have been maligned and slandered.
This is about the Mr Peter Ross who was defended tonight by Senator Giles. The Chairman of the Marra Worra Worra group says:

In the best interests of community development, we are hopeful that all the applicants for this job will be given an equal chance to present themselves to the community so that an informed decision can be made.
Mr Peter Ross has been telling Wangkatjungka people that he already has the job-seriously jeopardising people's sense of power in the situation.
His Junjuwa job has been neglected while this lobbying has been going on.
The Chairman then proceeds to say:

Serious discrepancies occurred at previous Junjuwa elections whereby young children were rounded up and encouraged to vote for Mr Ross' candidate. Rifles and cars are used to currie favour with key people . . .
At one night meeting called by Mr Ross, it appears that an attempt was made to install a new community chairman without many key community members being present-including the existing chairman.
The feeling in Fitzroy Crossing is that the community is being divided up, confused and exploited for this individual's personal gain.

It also appears Mr Ross is associated with a Western Australian company called Can Aussie which offers a consultancy service for mining companies. Old men are taken up in planes and asked to sign releases for mining companies.
Serious errors have been made using this method. Kim Akerman-
I will quote the people just so that we can get it on the record-
or Peter Bindon of the Museum of Western Australia can be contacted for details-
that is, if Senator Giles bothers-
John Clark-Liaison Officer, Department of Mines, can be contacted for confirmation of his mining activities.
He concludes by saying:
Community morale is very low at present. Please give this matter your urgent consideration.

Mr Ross has been waging a concerted and highly public campaign to thrust himself onto the community in recent times in the course of which I have borne the brunt of his criticism. In the course of this campaign I would not be surprised if Mr Ross makes a direct approach to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) as he has threatened to do and has done in the past. That is the conduct of Mr Ross, as described by the Chairman of the Marra Worra Worra Association. As I say, the previous correspondence was from the Kimberley Land Council. I believe that the record sits. Nothing that Senator Giles said tonight has changed that, or will change that.
I will mention the policeman that Senator Giles made something of tonight. The article states:
A Fitzroy Crossing police officer who did not wish to be named said he `could not say a detrimental word' about Mr Ross.

TALK.START.PARA: —He dare not.

—Yes, he dare not. He may well know about a previous officer in charge, a previous sergeant of that police station, who started to inquire into Mr Ross's financial dealings. He suffered the sharp brunt of Mr Ross's attacks. This particular unnamed officer stated:

SPEECH.PARA: He's a good man, a real good-hearted man. We think he's a bloody good bloke and he doesn't tell lies.

TALK.START.PARA: —He would not put a name on it.

—There is no name but he does use the plural `we', so he is presumably speaking without their authority-we will soon learn about that-but on behalf of his colleagues. I would be very concerned if this exoneration, if this judgment of innocence, is a reflection of the superficial conclusions drawn by officers of the Western Australia police force. If this peremptory dismissal of allegations made not by me, but by others as outlined, were to be found to be the standard depth of findings and conclusions by the Western Australia police force, then one would have cause for grave concern. The truth is that I know that not to be the case and I find it all the more disappointing that gratuitous comments of that nature would be made of an officer of the Western Australia police force in the face of substantial evidence in respect of such serious allegations.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to question seriously how such an officer would conduct himself in the event that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs concluded on the evidence presented that a prima facie offence had been committed. I just wonder whether that officer would write on the file, `We think he's a bloody good bloke and he doesn't tell lies,' and close the file, or could we expect a proper inquiry by this officer? My view is that his comments are stupid, ill-formed and gratuitous and they reflect very unfairly and improperly upon his colleagues. I hope that that is not how he conducts himself in his normal course of investigations.

I conclude by saying that if Senator Giles judges what I have read out tonight-I have been brief to relieve my colleagues of pain-those breaches of propriety as technically deficient, or as records `not meticulously kept', to quote her on both occasions, I find her values and her judgments very surprising.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what occasions has the Prime Minister raised the issue of the Export Enhancement Program (EEP) with President Reagan.
(2) When and where was the EEP raised with President Reagan and on each occasion which EEP transactions were raised by the Prime Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Since 1983 the Prime Minister and the Government have actively sought to influence United States policy on agricultural subsidies and other protectionist measures which affect Australia's trade performance. The Prime Minister has personally raised the issue of the Export Enhancement program (EEP) with President Reagan on six separate occasions:
(i) In a letter dated 6 June 1985 which urged that the EEP be targetted in a way which minimised damage to efficient and competitive supplier countries such as Australia.
(ii) In a letter dated 20 January 1986 which raised concerns about the US Farm Bill including the impact of the EEP on the world wheat market.

(iii) In a letter dated 25 March 1986 which noted US Administration efforts to limit the impact of subsidised US agricultural export sales on Australia's exports, and indicated that remaining concerns, principally with wheat and beef, would be raised during the Prime Minister's forthcoming visit to the US.

(iv) During White House discussions with President Reagan on 17 April 1986 at which it was requested that EEP wheat sales be targetted away from Australian markets and those of other non-subsidising exporters and that recipients of EEP sales be asked to ensure that imports from non-subsidisers were not reduced.
(v) In a letter dated 21 July 1986 which expressed concern at possible extensions of the EEP to the USSR and China.
(vi) During White House discussions with President Reagan on 23 June 1988 which referred to Australian concern about rumoured EEP wheat sales to Indonesia.
